PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and refers to a question I asked last February relating to the embezzlement of funds at the Australian Embassy in Tehran. Firstly, can the Minister state whether all files relevant to this matter were available to investigators? Secondly, has the Finance Department's investigation into the matter been completed? Thirdly, is the Commonwealth Police inquiry continuing? Fourthly, when can the Parliament expect a full report on the matter ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — As far as I am aware, the files that were requested by my Department were made available, and my Department made a report which was forwarded to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I understand that he forwarded the report, and any other matters he wished to refer, to the Australian Federal Police. I understand that the Minister is to make a statement very soon. I would think that it will be within the next day or two that he will be in a position to make a statement on the matter. I shall check to see whether there is anything I can say about it later today.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General and refer to the Trade Practices Commission inquiry into the future of stock exchange regulation. This follows a question I asked on the same subject earlier this year. Is the Minister concerned at the statement last week by the South Australian Attorney- General, Mr Griffin, that if the Commission's determination banning fixed brokerage fees were accepted, some 21 brokers could leave Adelaide, forcing the closure of that stock exchange, resulting in a loss of some $1m in stamp duty revenue, and a set-back to State development? Does the Minister recognise that the closure of the Adelaide exchange would also result in national companies removing their head offices from Adelaide? Given the possible detrimental effects of the Commission's determination on South Australia's development, does the Government recognise this fact and will it do all in its power to ensure that the Adelaide stock exchange is not forced to close?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware of the matter raised by Senator Jessop and, in particular, the concerns that have been expressed by the South Australian Attorney-General, Mr Griffin, about the impact on the South Australian stock exchange of the determination of the Trade Practices Commission in regard to access to stock exchange and brokerage rates. This concern has been expressed in a number of States and by State Attorneys-General. The Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities has already discussed the matter. It was decided during a telephone hook-up we had two or three weeks ago that the concerns about the impact on State stock exchanges, particularly in Perth, Hobart, Adelaide and Brisbane, would be expressed by the individual Attorneys, or by one of them on behalf of the others. The Trade Practices Commission has before it a draft determination, the one about which concern was expressed. The Trade Practices Commission was scheduled to hold last week-and I have no reason to believe that it did not do so-a pre-decision conference on the matter. I assume that Mr Griffin and perhaps some other State Attorneys expressed their views to the Trade Practices Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The process before the Trade Practices Commission is that it has issued a draft determination and is scheduled to hold a pre-decision conference at which it will be giving consideration to that matter and no doubt other matters that are placed before it. I do not know when it will make its final determination. Against that, of course, appeals are available to the Trade Practices Tribunal. However, the matter is certainly one which is under lively consideration of the Ministerial Council which will meet briefly on Friday of this week. I have no doubt that the matter will be discussed there. I am watching the matter very closely on behalf of the Federal Government and I will no doubt be taking it in the form of a submission to Cabinet in the near future. At this stage I am awaiting the final determination of the Trade Practices Commission before taking any further action at the Federal level.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General, and he will not be surprised to hear that it concerns matters arising out of the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which was tabled yesterday. Will the Attorney immediately table in each case, with the names and other identifying characteristics of individuals erased, the following opinions received by the Government, all expressing the view that criminal prosecutions or civil proceedings for misfeasance could lie against those involved in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, namely, the opinions of Mr Brinsden, Q.C., in January 1975, and again by Mr Brinsden, Q.C., in June 1975 ; by the unnamed Sydney Q.C. in early 1976 on the Norfolk Island matter, referred to on page 40 of the Costigan report; by the police investigators into the Perth matter in November 1976; by Mr Traill, Q.C., in July 1978; by Mr Ormiston, Q.C., and Dr Spry, Q.C.-a joint opinion in 1978-as referred to at page 75 of the Costigan report, if there is any uncertainty about that one; by the Melbourne Q.C. who was briefed by the liquidator of Keirad Pty Ltd in September 1978, the opinion referred to by Mr Lionel Bowen in the House of Representatives the other day, if there is any uncertainty about that one; by the Solicitor- General, Mr Byers, in July 1982, and, for good measure, the opinions submitted by the Law Institute of Victoria in December 1980 to the same effect from Mr Forsyth, Q.C., and Messrs Russell and Davies, Q.C.?

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Attorney also table on exactly the same conditions any memorandum or any other document containing a reasoned opinion by Mr Gleedman of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, who apparently, despite what Mr Costigan described as his total incompetence in matters of law, both criminal and civil, was of the opinion that prosecutions would not lie; the letter from the Crown Solicitor to the Commissioner of Taxation dated 3 April 1979 which, in Mr Costigan's words, did not condescend to particulars, and, finally, the further letter of 29 September 1980 confirming that advice by the Crown Solicitor, again without descending to detail? I also invite him to table any other opinions, reasoned or otherwise, which he may have in his possession which have not come to public light and which bear upon this issue. Finally, in responding to this question will the Attorney-General explain how it was possible for him to say, as he did on the Nationwide television program last night, that there has been a serious and genuine conflict of expert legal opinion on the question of whether prosecutions would lie under the law as it stood before the passage of the Government's own legislation in 1980?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans mentioned a large number of documents in his question. I will have to give consideration to the extent to which any of these can be tabled. I remind the Senate of the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the fact that the Crown Solicitor has always followed the rule that opinions and so forth that have been given on matters referred to him by the Australian Taxation Office for legal action arising under the Income Tax Assessment Act are not made available to Ministers. Senator Evans will be aware that the Income Tax Assessment Act specifically refers to Ministers. That is the rule that has always been followed and Mr Costigan, of course, emphasises that fact very clearly and definitely in his report. He points to it as one of the problems that Ministers are faced with in administering the law in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, as it appears from my response to the report that I tabled yesterday, the Government has decided that action should be taken in relation to both possible criminal proceedings and possible civil proceedings. It is not the rule and it would be foolish indeed to table opinions which will or may well be used as the basis for legal proceedings. We never do that and I see no reason why in this case there should be any difference. I am sure Senator Evans would realise that we do not make available--

TALK.START.PARA: —If all identifying characteristics are erased--

—Wait a minute. It is not just a matter of identification, it is also the sorts of arguments and so forth that opinions contain. Of course, these are not made known to those who are to be sued or prosecuted. There are very considerable reasons for that attitude to be taken.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a miscellany of documents in this case. They are not all just opinions . Senator Evans even asked for a police investigator's report. Good heavens, who would ever dream of making public a police investigator's report in regard to a case about which he is asked to consider whether he should take prosecution proceedings? That is really the most absurd request that I have ever heard.

In the last part of the question, Senator Evans referred to a somewhat lively debate that we had last night on the Nationwide program as to the opinions, as I understand it, that had been received. Advice had been received from Mr Brinsden in the case referred to by Mr Costigan. There may have been some other opinions that had been received but I certainly have not been aware of them. I was not aware of anything on the specific point of criminal proceedings until after the McCabe report was put down. The view of the Crown Solicitor was not that of just the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth and his staff. It was a view that had been formed by the Crown law authorities in Canberra after discussions they had with the taxation officials. They formed the view that the existing criminal law was not really suitable or adequate for the specific proceedings that were recommended by Mr Brinsden.

Certainly the view expressed by Mr Brinsden was different from the view that had been expressed by others. including the Solicitor-General, whose report we obtained after the McCabe report and before the Costigan report. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, and I decided to take action and obtain the Solicitor-General's opinion and indeed another Sydney silk's opinion, seeing the view which was being expressed by Mr McCabe and which had been expressed by Mr Brinsden was very different from the view which had been held by the Crown Solicitor's Office . But they are very able lawyers in the Crown Solicitor's Office, as Senator Evans would readily admit.

TALK.START.PARA: —For example, O'Sullivan.
—And Gleedman?

—I am talking about the Crown Solicitor at that time, Mr Neaves, the present Crown Solicitor, Mr O'Donovan and others in that office who have been concerned with the matter. They had formed the view that the best way of tackling the problem that was revealed was by introducing a specific law creating new and specific criminal offences. That law was ultimately passed and is now known as the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. That was no light opinion given by a junior officer in the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth or anywhere else.
—A pity it was not supported by recent arguments. It did not condescend to particulars, did it?

—That was the reason I said that lawyers differ. Of course they differ. Senator Evans and I differ on everything, but lawyers differ considerably on what are the suitable legal remedies on a particular case. That was the basis on which I expressed the view in our discussion last night.

—Mr President, I have a short supplementary question. Did I understand the Attorney-General to say, in the latter part of his reply, that the Federal Commissioner for Taxation, or at least his senior legal officers, came to share the apparent view of the Crown law office at some stage that prosecutions would not lie? If he did say that, would he please give now chapter and verse for that assertion?

—I am sorry. I said that discussions were held between the senior taxation officials and the Crown law authorities. The taxation officials, of course, acted on the advice given by the Crown law authorities.
—And they were appalled by the rubbish they were getting and they never believed a word of it.
—That is not so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the fourth interim report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and I ask the Attorney-General: Is it a fact that a major component of the report relates to the unnamed promoter of a system of taxation evasion and fraud? Did the Royal Commissioner provide to the Government the name of that promoter and if not does the Government know the name of that person? In any event, I ask for an absolute assurance that the Government will take all possible steps to prosecute any person who has engaged in tax evasion and fraud under the existing Crimes Act and the existing income tax assessment law irrespective of any attempt to recover tax evaded by the introduction of what may be regarded by some people as objectionable retrospective taxation laws?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Under the new powers that we gave the Royal Commissioner-as he recommended-in the last session, he obtained access to tax records in these matters. He is now empowered to pass that information on to the Attorney-General and his Department for the purpose of considering prosecution and also to make a report to the Government in general terms, which he did in this case and which report has been tabled by the Government. The case Senator Rae mentions is one that has been dealt with and is the same as the Perth case which the Deputy Crown Solicitor and the Crown law authorities are well aware of and have been aware of for many years. As I said yesterday, and I re-affirm it today, the position is that the Government decided-indeed the Treasurer and I decided-prior to the tabling of the Costigan report that we would pursue such criminal remedies as were available under existing law at the time, that is, the law as it was before the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was passed.

ANSWER.PARA: We have decided also to set up a special task force headed by a special prosecutor to undertake this very large effort that will be required. That task force also will be charged with the duty of looking at the pursuit of civil remedies, irrespective of any other laws that may be proposed to the Parliament on the subject. That, I thought, was clearly stated yesterday. However, I take the opportunity provided by Senator Rae's question to reaffirm today that the special task force will be concerned with the pursuit of all remedies that are available at the time, regardless of any further laws such as the Crimes ( Taxation Offences) Act that have been passed or may be proposed in this area.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate again concerns the escalating costs of the new and permanent Parliament House. Can the Leader of the Government say whether the assessors' final report on the project announcing the winning entry in June 1980 stated:

QUESTION.PARA: We are as satisfied as we can be at this stage that the competition winner's cost estimate is generally credible and realistic and that there will be no really significant increases . . . as the building proceeds . . .

Was it not announced here last week that the cost has escalated to $370m as of March 1982, an increase of almost 2 1/2 times the estimate announced by the assessors, even though inflation during the period concerned has been only of the order of 41 per cent? Is it not a fact that if cost escalations occur during the six years to completion of the building at the same level as they have done so far, the final cost of that building will reach $1,332m? Is it a fact that the Government has decided to allocate a further sum of $82m for telephones, furniture and art works for the building, that this amount also will be increased at the inflation rate and that on this assumption those items would cost the nation about the same as the total cost of the Sydney Opera House? In what way are such costs appropriate for a nation with our present problems? Finally, will the Government, before it is too late, appoint an independent commission of Australian architects and engineers to monitor constantly and publicly the progress of this project so that no more of these $40m and $50m cost escalations in real terms occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I repeat that the decision to build the new Parliament House is a decision of this Parliament. Secondly, the overview of each of the steps in the building of this Parliament House is done by a joint parliamentary committee of this Parliament. Thirdly, the design feature, the furniture and the fittings are all supervised and agreed upon by that joint committee of this Parliament. Also, I remind honourable senators that Mr President, either yesterday or in very recent times, made a statement upon the controlled costs of the Parliament and emphasised that in fact very strong control measures had been undertaken. I visited the site, met with representatives of the Parliament House Construction Authority and discussed the costs. I was assured by them to my own satisfaction that there was a strong cost control, at least as strong as that which applies to any other construction. I am not aware of the figures that Senator Mason put forward. Of course, there will be cost increases year by year in terms of inflation. It was always known that that would be so and that the costs as originally quoted were at the nominal cost of the particular time. It was also known that the building costs would not include furniture, fittings and the general artwork and that that would be covered by a separate estimate. That has been known. That is in fact under the overview of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the New Parliament House. Having said that, because I have no way of being precise on the figures given by Senator Mason, I will refer the question to the appropriate Minister and get a specific reply. I repeat that this is a decision of this Parliament. It is supervised by this Parliament in a bipartisan way, and Mr President himself has indicated, by statement from the Chair, the control of costs.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister assured, with respect to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the New Parliament House which is supervising this project, that it has the same expertise, knowledge, authority and background to supervise the costs of this program as the independent commission of architects and engineers which I propose would have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Mason had known the history of this undertaking he would know that expert bodies have been established at all points -an expert body in terms of planning the architectural and structural design, an expert body in judging that design, and a statutory body with expertise set up to conduct the situation.
—That is what the Construction Authority is supposed to be.

—Yes. A parliamentarian ought to know that any parliamentary committee has available to it all the expertise that it wishes to call upon, and that the old saying that the expert should be on tap and not on top is very relevant to this Parliament. In fact the situation is that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the New Parliament House is able to call upon full expertise.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Parliament that the Chairman of the Parliament House Construction Authority, Sir Bernard Callinan, is not only one of the most distinguished Australians but also is one of Australia's greatest civil engineers of the old firm of Gutteridge, Haskins and Davey Pty Ltd. That firm has been responsible for some of the major constructions in Australia, with a remarkable record of cost control. I repeat that if Senator Mason has questions he wants to press in this matter I suggest that he seek an invitation to go before his peers and put his questions to that parliamentary committee.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES TEACHERS FEDERATION CAMPAIGN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Has the Minister noted an article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald entitled ' Teachers' campaign ''deceitful''?' Will the Minister instigate an investigation by his Department into the claims of the New South Wales Teachers Federation in their $900,000 advertising campaign that education standards in government schools are rising whereas Professor Chipman claims that the survey by the Federation does not provide a basis for drawing any conclusions at all about state schools as it was based on all schools, including private independent schools, considered together?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the campaign to the extent that the New South Wales Teachers Federation attempts to make people aware of the value of education. If it wants to promote the value of government school education then I think all honourable senators would endorse that as well. But the campaign being run in New South Wales is deceitful to the extent that the Federation wishes, without actually saying so, to re-awaken the state aid debate that was resolved in this country 15 or 20 years ago.
—Thank God for that.

—My colleague says: 'Thank God for that'. This Government has given more in real terms to the total recurrent support of government schools throughout Australia than was given in the last year of the Labor Government. It is not possible for the New South Wales Teachers Federation to assert that we are abandoning government schools or that we are abandoning the government school system. That assertion simply does not hold up. It is possible to say that the resources applied to government schools have improved in real terms. It is possible to say that the Karmel resource targets were reached for government schools in all the systems. It is equally true to say that in the non -government sector those resource targets have not been reached, that students in the non-government sector still work with worse resources than their colleagues in government schools.

ANSWER.PARA: It is important that we do not confuse the standards of education with the standards of resources. I think Professor Chipman was talking about standards of education. In order to understand those we need regular testing. It is a matter of some regret that I am having difficulty in getting co-operation, particularly from teachers federations, to a national testing program that would help us to answer just that question of standards of education. I hope that we will get those tests on a regular basis. The people of Australia are entitled to know whether public education is delivering what they expect and what they think it should.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction and concerns the experimental building station. Is it a fact that the Government has decided to dismantle the EBS? If so, what are the reasons for doing so? Is it proposed that the work of the EBS will be undertaken by some other unit of the Government? Finally, what arrangements will be made for reprinting publications of the experimental building station?

—I have some information on some of the matters touched by Senator Robertson. In connection with the decision to dismantle or sell off the experimental building station, I have to advise that that was a decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions last year and that decision is now being implemented. The disposal is being handled, I understand, by an interdepartmental committee. At present the operation is being leased as a going concern and a number of conditions have been laid down to ensure that advisory services will be maintained. The Government has decided to provide a minimum of $1m per year for the next three years for public interest research in the area of building regulations and standards. Further, I understand that nine organisations have registered as expressing an interest in leasing the operation . It is expected that proposals will be invited from registrants in the latter part of this month, which will have to be fairly quick. In general terms, the matter is under active consideration. On the one or two points that I did not touch in my reply I will seek to obtain further information for Senator Robertson.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the depressed state of both the economy and the people of Poland who are subject to martial law, experiencing shortages of food and clothing, and suffering restrictions and limitations foreign to the majority of Australians. Will the Government ensure that all possible action is taken to alleviate the poor standards of living existing in Poland now and ensure that Australia takes an active part in preventing suggested trade sanctions and embargoes by other nations against Poland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government is well aware of the depressed state of both the economy and the people of Poland, particularly since the imposition of martial law. The Australian Government, conscious of Poland's economic situation, has done nothing to impede the flow of private humanitarian aid to the people of Poland. It will be recalled that last week in this place we had a discussion on these matters and at that time we refered to the Government' s cash grant of $1m to the national 'Help Poland Live' appeal. At the same time the Government has endorsed the actions of allies who have imposed sanctions on the Polish Government in response to the imposition of martial law. It is the Government's view that the responsibility for creating a situation in which these sanctions no longer apply rests with the Polish military council and also with the Soviet authorities who continue to apply pressure. Regrettably, they have yet to show any genuine intention in that regard. I conclude by saying that it is this Government's intention to do whatever may be of assistance and certainly not to exacerbate the problems which are presently being suffered by people in Poland at this time.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, relates to the question directed to him yesterday by Senator Scott concerning drought relief. I ask: Is it a fact that between 1971 and 1978 the Commonwealth met all expenditure by a State in a year on agreed measures necessitated by major disasters in excess of a base amount set for the State? Is it a fact that between 1971 and 1978, under the then Commonwealth-State arrangements, New South Wales had to meet only the first $5m and that thereafter everything spent on drought relief was met by the Commonwealth? Did the present Government alter those arrangements to provide for a doubling of the amount that in the first instance each State had to contribute-in the case of New South Wales from $5m to $10m-and that in respect of any State expenditure thereafter the Commonwealth would contribute not the total amount but only three-quarters thereof? In view of the serious drought conditions throughout Australia, particularly in New South Wales, and in view of the national conference on drought relief that is being requested by the Prime Minister, will the Minister recommend to the Prime Minister and to the Government that they seriously consider reverting to the pre-1978 relief arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during Question Time I indicated, in much less detail , that the present contribution requirements of State governments dated back to 1978-79. I understand that the position prior to that date was along the lines outlined by the honourable senator in his question. The arrangements since have been fixed and have worked, I believe, to the general satisfaction of the States, although there have been special arrangements from time to time as drought conditions have deepened in a particular State. As I mentioned at the close of Question Time yesterday, the Prime Minister has now communicated with all Premiers-I believe telexes were sent yesterday morning-drawing attention to the deepening severity of the drought and suggesting that discussions between the Minister for Primary Industry, whom I represent in this place, and relevant State Ministers should be held on an early date.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth has certainly shown that it has been prepared to be flexible within the framework of the 1978 arrangements. For example, for New South Wales , which as the State with the largest population has the largest base amount to meet, namely $10m, the Commonwealth has already made a $10m interest free loan. So that, in current budgetary terms, the State contribution has been met on an interest free loan basis. That is one example of a variation in order to meet a particular situation. I do not think that I should attempt to predict the degree of flexibility in these arrangements that the Commonwealth might be prepared to consider embarking upon. In general, I believe, it has regarded the formula as established in the late 1970s as fairly satisfactory. However, it certainly accepts that the present drought is one of very great severity which is bearing down very heavily on both grain producers and those who are dependent upon the pastoral industry. I will refer the honourable senator's suggestions to the Minister for Primary Industry for consideration. Of course, from time to time I will also report to the Senate on the results of any changes on policy in this area.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DIESEL FUEL: REMOVAL OF EXCISE EXEMPTION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether he is aware of the additional costs which the removal of the Federal Government's diesel fuel excise exemption will have upon farmers in Western Australia, given that the great majority of grain is transported by Westrail which, in turn, will be required to pass on its additional costs to its clients. Secondly, is the Minister aware of the additional electricity charges which will be imposed upon consumers in rural and remote parts of Western Australia, where many electricity plants are fired by fuel oil? Thirdly, is the Minister aware of the additional freight charges which will have to be passed on to people in the north-west of Western Australia who rely upon the Western Australian State Shipping Service for cartage of their goods? Fourthly-I think this was in part answered yesterday by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle-if there is to be a rebate, will the Minister give an assurance that the changeover from the exemption system to a rebate system for farmers will be carried out with a minimum of difficulty for farmers, that paperwork will not be cumbersome and that the claim for rebate will be refunded promptly so as to minimise the temporary out-of-pocket costs for farmers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent Budget contained an announcement about changes in the administration of the exemption from diesel fuel excise. The situation which had applied to that date came to an end, in part because of the Government's concern about the abuses which were occurring with respect to the pre-Budget exemptions. It was announced in the Budget that henceforth users will have to pay the duty but that certain users would be entitled to claim a refund. Those users are those in the agricultural, mining, forestry and fishing industries, those who use diesel fuel for domestic use, and hospitals, nursing institutions and aged persons' homes. That does mean that those who could claim exemption and now cannot will of course be carrying an increased burden. That includes a number of significant State authorities. So, yes, I am aware of the changes which were announced in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the second major point in Senator Crichton-Browne's question regarding minimum inconvenience, I can assure him that the Government is concerned to minimise the paper work which farmers and others have to indulge in to claim the rebate. The matter has received very careful Government consideration and at this stage I think the Government is still in the process of finalising the precise administrative arrangements which will apply. I can assure the Senate that one of the major considerations in the Government's mind in designing that system has been to keep the procedures as simple as possible. That has to be done in the context of the old system, whereby those who were exempt simply had a number and therefore bought their fuel duty free by lodging the number with the supplier. That system was open to abuse, and was abused. People who were not entitled to the exemption obtained duty free fuel and that was a position that the Government believed could not be allowed to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer explain why the current Budget has made no attempt to reimburse the States so that they can reduce the iniquitous tax on labour, namely payroll tax? Would she agree that a reduction in payroll tax would immediately stimulate production and thus contribute directly to a reduction in unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Premiers met with the Treasurer and the Prime Minister at their usual Premiers Conference prior to the Budget. At that time no decision was taken to change the arrangements with regard to payroll tax , which is a tax levied by the States and Territories themselves. Arrangements for the distribution of funds, specific purpose grants and so on were discussed and made at that time. To consider payroll tax as being the only difficulty in regard to employment is to overlook the fact that it is but one cost in the cost of labour or the cost of production. A number of other things bear very directly on costs and it always seems to me to be passing strange that everyone suggests that the removal of payroll tax, or the levying of payroll tax by the Commonwealth or some other form of raising this amount of revenue, would somehow be the answer to the unemployment problem. As I say, it is but one cost and the States have it within their powers to choose to raise funds in some other way if they feel it is more appropriate or they could perhaps in their own ways, in conjunction with the Commonwealth, look at all the costs of production, including costs of wages that are paid by employers and by governments. So whilst I do not argue that payroll tax does not contribute to costs, I do argue that it is but one cost and other things should be looked at as well.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Government's latest catchcry is wage restraint. I ask the Minister how his Government can compare the salary of the Prime Minister with that of a worker on a wage of, say, $180 a week and expect both to show the same wage restraint. Does the Minister not agree that buying a home and food and clothing for the family is common to the man on the highest salary scale and the one on the lowest? When will the Government place some control over prices of essential goods? Surely restraint on the tax on petrol would be one way the Government could begin, instead of blaming unions and workers for the utter mess it has made of the economy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout the whole community there is a recognition of margins for skill for all people, be they professional people or national leaders, including the judiciary and heads of the Public Service. There is no attempt to compare the wage or salary of such a person with that of a person who is on, shall we say, a lower or average weekly wage. Of course, it is clear that persons on higher wages have particular advantages. That is and always has been the main situation. I have to say when referring to the Prime Minister's salary, Ministers' salaries and salaries of parliamentarians generally, that over the last seven years of this Government Ministers and members of parliament have repeatedly undertaken wage restraint. Their wages and allowances have been fixed by the Remuneration Tribunal. I think that is a situation that is accepted by all sides of this Parliament and that it would be regarded as fair. Nevertheless , decisions have been made that Ministers and members would receive less than the Remuneration Tribunal had allocated. That has been done in the interests of restraint.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the last Remuneration Tribunal finding, the Government indicated to the Tribunal that for top public servants, the judiciary, heads of statutory bodies and parliamentarians, it would be good to have wage restraint. That was adopted at 7 per cent. The Academic Salaries Tribunal, under Mr Justice Ludeke, also did the same in respect of higher wages with the aim of showing wage restraint.

Clearly, in all the factors that have been examined, and in every country in the free world, there has been a recognition that if wages rise unduly, they will force up prices and create unemployment. After all, I think it was a former Labor Treasurer, Mr Crean, who said that one man's wage increase is another man' s job. That has been indicated. Of course the present Government understands the common need for human beings to have higher living standards. It was governments of this faith that brought to Australia policies that established the highest rate of home ownership of any country in the world. We intend to continue that.

The policies have worked. The recent Budget, which has been widely acclaimed, has been aimed at assisting both the lower and the lower middle income earning levels. The Budget was aimed specifically to home in on families, particularly families with a single working spouse and children, and to give to them the greatest benefit; hence the assistance for interest on home loans; hence the increased spouse allowance; hence the increase in the family allowance. As the Budget has pointed out, such an average family will receive a net gain, after discounting for the increases in indirect taxes, of about $16 or $17 a week.

I remind Senator Elstob that prior to the Budget the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions had indicated that if tax concessions were to be available to the community, there would be grounds for wage restraint. All I can say is that the Government has fulfilled those requirements, and there is now a logical onus on everyone to carry out that restraint.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that a few years ago the question of the crown of thorns starfish and the infestation of the Great Barrier Reef was a matter which attracted the attention of many Australians. —I have already sent it to your Department.

—Senator Missen said that he has supplied a copy to my Department. Perhaps he sent it to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and not the Department of Education. —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to Budget Paper No. 3 and in particular to the section dealing with labour and unemployment. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.
