QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE ACTIVITIES OF THE FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he and his Cabinet colleagues have finished their reading of the Costigan report, the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I ask this question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate rather than the Attorney-General because I feel that the Leader of the Government in the Senate is speaking for the Government and for the Cabinet. I ask him whether he has seen the cry from the heart from Mr Costigan on page 118 of his report where he says:

QUESTION.PARA: No community can tolerate a group within it that regards the taking of a man's life is permissible provided he belongs to that group. Far less can a community afford a section who not only hold that belief, but acts upon it.

I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate-I know it is early; the report has been brought down only for a matter of hours-whether the Government has any plan at all to stop this murder and mayhem which has been headlined in the newspapers and which is a scandal and a disgrace in a country such as this.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read the Costigan report several times. Indeed, it repays very careful reading. Unlike members of the Australian Labor Party I have read the whole of it and not, selectively, chapter 3. I have noted that the main thrust of the report is the revelation, brought about by the action of the Government in setting up the inquiry, of the terrible wave of crime of a wide variety being perpetrated within the membership of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It takes some selective bias and partisanship by honourable senators opposite that they were able yesterday to venture into that report without noting that it centred basically on the fact that the violence and bloody murder, the intimidation, the false pretences-in fact, every kind of crime-and the organisation of crime in that union, had been revealed. The reaction of the Labor Party is simply an indication to the community that it is not interested in the royal commission's report.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate that the inquiry was set up to look at the allegations made by the public that there was murder, that there was violence, that there was brutality and intimidation and that there was corruption. It was set up by this Government and its terms were widened by this Government so that there could be full exposure. Indeed, yesterday it was completely revealed that the setting up of that inquiry was fully justified.

Quite apart from the proposed establishment of the crimes commission, the joint prosecutors and the various other devices, there is now a clear revelation to the community that we have within one section of the trade union movement a cesspit which must be cleaned up. It is one of the major tragedies of our society that a great movement-the trade union movement-should, at this moment, be under scrutiny because one very major union has been found to be in itself virtually an organised Mafia. The setting up of this royal commission has been fully justified. The remedies which have been taken and those which are to be taken will pursue all the problems mentioned in all sections of the report. Anybody who has breached the law will be pursued. We make that abundantly clear. We have set up methods of investigation but heavily--

TALK.START.PARA: —How far will you be behind in the pursuit?

—I think it does the Labor Party no good to be selective again. I would not want to wonder how many members of the particular union hold tickets in Labor leagues and in branches of the Labor Party. The Labor Party should not be selective; nor should it forget that the only reason for the exposure of this matter is Liberal Government action. Not a single activity occurred during the period of the Whitlam Government even though the Costigan report states that for three years under the Whitlam Government this was known. Not a single prosecution was carried out. The report states these things. Nothing was done by the Whitlam Government at all to clean up that section of the trade union movement. Indeed, the McCabe-Lafranchi report, which the Labor Party continues to refer to, was instituted by a State Liberal government, so the facts that are now before the public and the means of pursuing these people result from actions by Liberal governments. The Whitlam Government was reminded that it was the protection of section 16 of the taxation Act which covered these matters and prevented full disclosure. Nothing happened under the Whitlam Government. The answer, of course, is very clear. This Government and the past State Liberal Government of Victoria have enabled these exposures to be made and we will pursue them to the full.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving a motion to censure the Government for its grave failure in the administration of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion, and ask that Standing Order 127 be set aside to enable the full pursuit of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion of Censure

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Government for its grave failure, and the failure of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer in particular, in the administration of legislation relating to criminal and civil offences against the tax laws resulting in multi-billion dollar frauds against the Commonwealth, and calls for the resignation of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer.

If there is anything charitable about this motion it is that it censures the Government for failure-failure equalling incompetence. Of course there is an alternative view, which is not expressed in the words of the motion but which can be expressed, and that is not only that the Government has failed but also that it has never tried in relation to the matter with which I want to deal. Before I go on to deal with that matter let me deal with a couple of canards that have been perpetrated in this Parliament today relating to the commencement of the tax avoidance industry in this country.

The first point I want to make is that it is very easy to say that because in 1973 an astute officer of the office of the Commissioner of Taxation detected a number of schemes which were frauds on the Commonwealth, and that because that was the chronological date, that is when it all began. But of course the key thing is illustrated best by the report of the royal commissioner, Mr Costigan, when he refers to the fact that opinions and a brief for prosecution in relation to this matter:
. . . were found relegated to a bottom drawer where, I was told, they had rested undisturbed for the past five years.

He was told that in 1981. Of course the key date is August 1975. That is when people in this Senate were blocking the Budget of the Whitlam Government. For five years after that the documents remained in a bottom drawer with nothing being done.
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —We authorised a prosecution in August 1975.

—Of course, as Senator Evans points out, a prosecution was authorised in 1975 by the Whitlam Government. Seven years later, under this Government, nothing has been done about it. If honourable senators want to hear why, they must just listen for a few minutes and stop shouting silly interjections.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is this: The royal commission is called the Royal Commission on the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. If Ministers come into this place and say that the Labor Party or any of its members condone the activities of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union they are perpetrating a lie, because that is not so. We do not condone them for a moment. In setting up this royal commission the Liberal Government indulged in a quite legitimate persecution, as it has turned out, of some of the members of a particular trade union. The Liberal Government launched a tiger which has turned round and bitten it right on the nose and that is the problem it faces today. Let me remind government senators about the Liberal Government. It came into office in 1975 and one of its great slogans was: 'We are going to end the great tax rip-off'. It came into office on that slogan and it will go out on that slogan because under this Government the biggest tax rip-off in the history of this country has been perpetrated as a result of incompetence and inertia by this Government and two of its Ministers in particular-the greatest rip-off in the history of the country.

It is important, I believe, to establish the environment in which this vote of no confidence in this Government is moved. Environments, we are told, are very important. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) said that. He said that the climate of opinion was not right to take action on this matter. Let us look at the environment in which this motion has been brought forward today. After seven years of Fraser government we live in a society, under a Prime Minister who is going to govern 'for all the people', where anyone who robs a bank of $5,000 goes to gaol for about eight years. If one defrauds the Taxation Commissioner of $250,000 one might have to pay an extra penalty if the Attorney-General and the Treasurer and the public servants under their direction bother to get off their backsides and do anything about it. That is the sort of society in which we live under this Government.

We live in a society where the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), in his own defence, says that there are not two million people, living in poverty in Australia. No, he says, there are only 1 million people, which presumably is a matter of great pride to the Fraser Government. We live in a society in which there has been a massive shift in the taxation burden from the rich to the poor. In 1981-82 pay-as-you-earn taxpayers paid 45.4 per cent of the total tax take compared with 41 per cent in 1975 when this tax rip-off Government, as it was calling itself, came into office. We live in a society where the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) comes into the Senate and claims that this Government has ended the tax avoidance industry. What authority does she cite for that proposition? She cites a man who is named in the McCabe-Lafranchi report as being up to his ears in tax evasion. That is the man whom the Minister for Finance cites in this Parliament as authority for the proposition that the Fraser Government has ended the tax avoidance industry. My God, there is something about quoting the Devil for one's own purpose! There has never been a better example of that than that quotation made by the Minister for Finance and the Treasurer in the other place a few days ago.

We live in a society where gross inequities are being perpetrated, where the number of companies has proliferated and the tax which they pay has fallen in relation to the total tax take. Why has all this happened? Do not take my word for it; take the word, for example, of Professor Mathews. At the beginning of this year he said:
The taxation system has disintegrated and become a major instrument for distributing income from the poor to the rich.
That is what this Government expert said about the taxation system and how it has developed under this Government. He went on to say:
If the same enthusiasm were to be shown by the Commonwealth for controlling revenue collections as for controlling Government expenditures, higher rates of taxation would be unnecessary.

He said that higher rates of taxation would be unnecessary if the same enthusiasm had been shown. Of course, that is an understatement. Not only would higher taxation rates have been unnecessary but also taxation for the ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayer would have been less and I believe there are plenty of figures which establish that fact. But the key point in Professor Mathews statement is contained in the words 'lack of enthusiasm'. This Government has had no enthusiasm for pursuing its friends in the tax avoidance industry-no enthusiasm whatsoever. We will come to the details of that in a minute. But right under the noses of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer there was a proliferation of the tax avoidance industry. There was a whole range of consistent legal opinions to the effect that that industry could be stopped- legal opinions which were available to this Government and which this Government chose to ignore. But, as I said, it is lack of enthusiasm which is the important factor.

It is not as if the Fraser Government is an insensitive government, insensitive to the feelings of the electorate, unastute about the importance of taxation as an instrument in society. It is not as if it is that sort of government at all. If it is not administratively astute to the importance of taxation, it has always been politically astute about that subject. Need I remind honourable senators of the 1977 election, the election which was going to be the tax reduction-recovery election, the election in which one could dial a tax cut and find out what one was going to get from the Liberal Party if it were re-elected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator knows that-

—Senator Walters, there were a lot of people in this country who did not have to pick up their gold-plated telephones. They did not pay any tax anyway because of the proliferation of tax avoidance schemes. They did not have to dial a tax cut; that was a service offered to the ordinary people of this country. Those taxation cuts were taken away from them four months later when higher taxes were implemented. This is the Government which has been so astute about the importance of taxation that twice it has promised the introduction of tax indexation. Why did it promise to do this? According to the Prime Minister ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) it did so to keep governments honest. This Government has taken away indexation after having promised it. That is how honest and astute this Government is about the real burden of taxation in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The interim report of Commissioner Costigan in relation to these matters reveals the extent of the incompetence, deception and corruption within the Department administered by the Attorney-General and for which he is responsible. But it does more than that. It casts gravest doubts on the veracity of the Treasurer and the Attorney-General in their public statements as to the extent of their commitment to stamp out tax avoidance in this community. We saw the commitment of the Treasurer in June 1982 when, asked what is at fault in the question of tax avoidance, he said: 'Community attitudes are at fault'. This is a man who is a Deputy Prime Minister of this country, a so-called leader, one would have thought, of opinion. What he is saying, of course, is that the Government has lost confidence in the veracity and integrity of people and they, not the Government, ought to be dismissed. He is saying that community attitudes are at fault. This undertaker's clerk who keeps the receipts for the Prime Minister of this country hides behind a screen. He is like the Duke of Plaza Toro: 'In different things of martial kind, when there is any fighting he led his regiment from behind'. The Duke of Plaza Toro found it less exciting. The Treasurer finds it very unexciting to pursue the tax avoidance industry and he hides behind that cloud.

TALK.START.PARA: —The quote is wrong.

—A major point-Senator Baume says the quote is wrong. For goodness sake! The quote is wrong-that is a real important subject for debate. My veracity stands on the fact that my quote is wrong! The veracity of this Government stands on the argument I am putting forward, if honourable senators opposite would bother to listen to it. If we examine the record and the report of the Royal Commissioner we find that this Government and the two Ministers in particular have fiddled while this country's taxation system burns. That is what has happened.
—There is another misquote.

—It established, of course, gross corruption and negligence in the Attorney-General's Department and soon, I have no doubt, Senator Archer will address his mind to the great issues of the day. The report outlines the extent of the tax avoidance industry. It exposes the humbug of the Treasurer's claim that existing laws before 1980 were ineffective to combat tax avoiders. It reveals, of course, the indolence and lack of will by the Attorney-General and the Treasurer to act when these enormous rip-offs were taking place under their very noses. Of course, ultimately it is an indictment of the competence of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer. They are not fit to be Ministers in this or any other government. The only honourable course is for both of them to resign, which this motion calls on them to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Look at the lamentable history of this affair. It is contained in chapter three of the Commissioner's report. It reveals that in 1973 and 1974 a diligent officer of the Taxation Office found a set of facts and a method of prosecuting a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme. That was referred to the Deputy Crown Solicitor' s Office in Perth. By the end of 1975 the basis of a prosecution was established to the satisfaction of the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Federal Police. This satisfaction was supported by a clear opinion sought and obtained from Mr Brinsden, Q.C.

Of course, when we talk about the basis for a prosecution, we are talking about the basis for a prosecution of a scheme, a pilot scheme if you like, which has led to the loss of millions and millions of dollars-hundreds of millions of dollars in the words of the Commissioner-to the revenue of this country. That money might have been spent on improving the lot of pensioners, on preventing the sales tax increases which took place in the Budget and which imposed a burden on the ordinary people. It might have been spent in a variety of other ways to improve the social cohesion and sense of justice in this community. Hundreds of millions of dollars might have been spent on those things for which this government has never been able to find the money.

But that whole process foundered in the Attorney-General's Department, in the Perth office of the Deputy Crown Solicitor, because no prosecutions were ever launched, no money was recovered and nothing was done. The responsibility for what Commissioner Costigan calls the 'lamentable history of non-prosecution' is shared by all levels-the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth, the central Crown Solicitor's office in Canberra-and goes all the way to the Crown Solicitor himself. The responsibility, if we accept the standards of the Fraser Government as laid down by the master, goes to the senior levels of government itself-to the Attorney-General, the Treasurer and the Deputy Prime Minister.

I ask the Senate: Can Ministers escape responsibility for the grossly inadequate supervision of the prosecution by and administration of their Departments? If taxation were such a crucial issue and if this Government were concerned, why did the Attorney-General not say to his Department: 'What are we doing about this?'. The Attorney-General will say, as he said on television: ' They could not tell me anything because of section 16, the secrecy provision.' What a load of rubbish! Of course they could have told the Attorney-General what was being done. The secrecy provision only protects the names of individuals. It does not protect a Minister from being told what is being done by his Department .

TALK.START.PARA: —He knew the names; that is why he didn't prosecute them.

—There are all sorts of theories about that, Senator. I do not necessarily subscribe to them. The fact of the matter is that the Attorney- General clearly cannot have made any inquiry because, of course, he was not concerned. Yet this Government, as I said, has talked more about the tax evasion industry in the last year or two than any other government in Australia's history, but all that talk has been just words.
—And done more.

—I hope Senator Archer will have time to make a contribution to this debate and will say what has been done. He should read the Commissioner's report which shows what has been done. It is extraordinary for the Minister to claim that he did not know what was going on. The substance of the actions could have been revealed to him without any names being revealed.
— Did your Attorney know in 1974?
—Section 16 cannot provide an excuse for the Attorney-General to escape responsibility for any of these events.
—Why don't you answer the question? Did your Attorney know in 1974.

—I do not know, Senator Walters, but it was known in 1975 and a prosecution was authorised. That is more than this Government has done in seven years. The Royal Commissioner establishes, if Senator Walters wants figures, that the cost to the community of tax avoidance as a result of these schemes is enormous. Mr Risstrom, the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association, estimates that it is up to $5 billion. Professor Mathews says that it is $5 billion but the Commissioner of Taxation says that it is at least $1 billion. Were not the Attorney-General and the Treasurer aware of these figures? Were not they aware of any of those figures which have been talked about in the Senate now for two and a half years? Were not they aware of the reports of the Commissioner of Taxation which identified the loss through these schemes in 1977 -78, when this Government was in office, as being $4 billion? Each year it went up progressively under the Senator Walters Government. It went up progressively until, in the last report, it was nearly $1.000m.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the crude figures which people who are as astute as Senator Walters might have read if they had bothered to be interested. Of course, that is the whole problem; the Government is not interested in this issue. The Attorney- General and Mr Howard, the Treasurer, knew all this. Why did not the Attorney- General take an interest in what was going on in his Department as a result of the existence of the test case in 1975? Did he not know? Did he not care? There has been a solid factual foundation for that test case, in Mr Brinsden's opinion , in the opinion of the Costigan Royal Commission and in the opinions of four independent Queen's counsel. There was no basis in law or fact for the abandonment of the prosecution by the Crown Solicitor in 1979. It was due to incompetence. It was due to lack of will to prosecute. The Deputy Crown Solicitor, the Taxation Office, the Australian Federal Police and the Crown Solicitor had all been advised of the solid basis for the prosecution of that test case.

How can two Ministers say in the Parliament that they did not know, were not aware or were unsure of the basis of action? There has always been a solid legal foundation for prosecution of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It was availble for criminal prosecution under the Crimes Act, at common law, under company law and under State crimes Acts. A vast body of legal weaponry was available to an Attorney-General with the will to prosecute. The passage of the 1980 legislation , the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, was not necessary to stamp out these schemes. The Royal Commissioner said:
The answer lies not in new laws but in enforcement of the old.
Let us look at the role of the Treasurer in this affair. He has always said that the old laws were ineffective. In a Press release on 28 May this year he said:

I have been advised by the Taxation Office that prior to the prosecution of the December 1980 Act there were no effective avenues for prosecution under the then existing law either Commonwealth or State which could have been pursued.

I heard the Prime Minister talking about this a little while ago. He has found a new scapegoat-officers of the Attorney-General's Department; public servants suffering from inertia and things of that kind. That is a confession of 'not guilty but incompetent'. That is what the Prime Minister is saying if he accepts his own standards about government. As the Royal Commissioner pointed out, the old laws were effective; there was just no will to enforce them. This Government knew or ought to have known that the old laws were effective. There is nobody in this country who ought to have known that more than the Attorney-General. Contrary to Mr Howard's Press release, which I have just quoted, there were effective avenues for prosecution under the existing laws. The Treasurer is either misleading the Parliament or he has not informed himself. Either way, he is culpable. There were four other legal opinions which established that there was a basis for prosecution and they were known to this Government. Of course, the Taxation Office knew what was going on throughout this period. It appears in the annual reports of the Commissioner of Taxation. The Treasurer should acknowledge that as early as 1974 or 1975 these opinions were available. In his Press statement issued on 27 June 1981 on the McCabe-Lafranchi report, the Treasurer said:
As a result of further discussion which took place over the period 1976-1979 it became clear that there was no foundation on which the prosecutions could have successfully been launched.

This is an attempt to cover up deficiencies and inaction. The passage of 1980 legislation took place years after Mr Howard must have known that the tax avoidance industry rorts were taking place to the enormous extent they were. What is clear is that this Government knew, in which case it is culpable, or it ought to have known, in which case it is negligent, as early as 1976 about a massive criminal fraud, and it had easy remedies to deal with it. As a result of its failure to use those remedies, the tax burden in this country has been shifted, as Professor Mathews said, from the rich to the poor. Senator Chaney concedes that one million people are living in poverty. The Government had top level legal opinions to support prosecutions but it did nothing.

Senator Durack is the chief law officer in this country. He is responsible for protecting the laws of the Commonwealth. With the Treasurer, he is responsible for protecting the revenue. He is responsible for launching prosecutions. He is responsible for the Attorney-General's Department which, according to the Royal Commissioner, at the Deputy Crown Solicitor level is in a disgraceful mess; it did nothing about these matters. The Attorney of this country did not interest himself in a major test case against tax avoiders. If he had he would have said to his law officers: 'What is my Department doing about this issue?' He would have received an answer, or he should have received an answer. If he did not receive an answer he should have said: 'Well, get on with it'. He knew what the issue was all about. To say that section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act will help him in that respect is to ignore the substance and reality of the issue. He is culpable. He presided over all this mess and, on any notion of ministerial responsibility, he is responsible.

I do not know whether Ministers of this Government have any standards left. But if they do they must be the standards which the Prime Minister set, or has talked about over a long period. This was going to be a Government without impropriety. In 1972 he said:
If a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia-
I interpolate that this is an enormous blunder; I suppose one could call it that . It is an enormous cover-up-worse than a blunder. He said:
If a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia-

I would have thought it was pretty important to Australia. The Prime Minister has been talking his head off about it in the last fortnight. It is important in terms of revenue lost and the burden which is being imposed on the ordinary people in this country. He continued:
and if the Minister were unaware of it, the Minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.

Senator Durack pleads that he was unaware of it. Nobody in this country, other than the Attorney-General, could live in a more blissful state of ignorance. Nobody could live in a more ignorant bliss. He knows that this has been an issue which goes to the social and political morality of this country. We have said it here over the years. The Government cannot impose additional burdens on lowly paid people if it condones this sort of thing. It has been said dozens of times in the Senate alone and it has been said in public. The Attorney's defence to that is: 'Well, I was ignorant. Those fellows in the Attorney-General's Department did not tell me'. He should have found out. It is his job to find out . Of course, the Prime Minister has even higher standards than that, standards which have brought the demise of some honest Ministers. The Prime Minister once said.

The community rightly demand a high standard from the Ministers of the Government. The judgments on Ministers are more exacting and sometimes more harsh than the judgments which might be passed on those outside the sphere of public life. If these high standards were not upheld, the people's confidence in Government-a confidence which is fundamental to Australian democracy-would be undermined.

My God, that has happened. The people's confidence in this Government has been undermined. As I said at the beginning, the Government will go out on the same slogan with which it came in: 'People are concerned to end the tax rip-off'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Button, brings in the Senate this afternoon a motion of censure on the Government for its failure, and the failure of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and myself in particular, in the administration of legislation relating to criminal and civil offences against tax laws, resulting in what he calls a multi-billion dollar fraud against the Commonwealth, and calls for the resignation of the Treasurer and myself. The Government rejects the censure raised against it. In another place this afternoon the Treasurer has rejected the call for his resignation and I reject the call for mine.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion moved by Senator Button has been moved by the leader of the Australian Labor Party, a party which is a newcomer to this sense of indignation which it now tries to portray about tax avoidance. It was when the Labor Party was in government from 1972 to 1975 that the tax avoidance industry in this country began. One of the first and most serious schemes, and what proved to be probably the forerunner in the tax avoidance industry, was a scheme known as the Curran scheme. The Curran scheme was well known to the Labor Government in 1974. The Treasurer of the day, Mr Crean, said that it would close the loophole, but it was never closed by the Labor Government at any time before it went out of office. Now we have this indignation expressed by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, the man who was Treasurer in that Government in 1975 and who allowed the tax avoidance industry really to get going with the Curran scheme. It did nothing whatever--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the Attorney-General please be seated. I ask all honourable senators to extend to the Attorney-General the same courtesy that was extended to the Leader of the Opposition when he put the case for the Opposition .
—Order! I ask that honourable senators give serious consideration to extending the same courtesy. I again call the Attorney-General.

—The tax avoidance industry, as I said, began to show its face in the years of the Labor Government and was ignored by the Labor Government when it knew perfectly well of the existence of one of the first and worst types of tax avoidance schemes; the Curran scheme. Now, at this very late stage, and I will deal more with the role of this Government later, the Opposition is trying to cash in with the widespread and quite proper indignation in the community about tax avoidance. Senator Button in his motion, the form of which has become rather familiar in Senator Button's motions, talks about the failure of the Government to enforce tax laws and criminal and civil laws, resulting in a multi -billion dollar fraud. One would imagine from that that he is talking generally about the loss of revenue. But as he presents his case, he is referring to the particular case which has been highlighted in the report of Mr Costigan's Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Of course, the revenue that may be lost may well be hundreds of millions; nobody knows exactly what the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes amount to, but they are certainly not multi-billion dollar frauds as a whole. The schemes that the Government has tackled and stamped out may well otherwise have resulted in multi -billion dollar losses. The Opposition just picks figures out of the air, without making an estimate of any sure kind. Of course, it makes much better politics to talk, now, about multi-billion dollar losses. As I have said, from time to time the total losses flowing from particular schemes have been assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation. Certainly, they run into hundreds of millions of dollars but not, as far as the Government is aware, figures of the kind that the Opposition is trying to make people believe by reiterating scare estimates of this type.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is also trying to suggest, by its motion, that the loss of all this revenue represents a failure on the part of the Government to administer existing laws. But what is the Opposition's policy in relation to tax avoidance? What policy does it say the Government should adopt? It says that the law should be changed, and changed retrospectively. The Australian Labor Party's answer to the problem of tax avoidance now, having ignored the problem when it was in government and for a good deal of its time in Opposition, is to promise to change all of the existing laws and do so with reprospective effect. That is the Labor Party's policy. Yet today it tries to censure the Government because, it says, the Government has not administered the existing laws; that if we had done so the multi-billion dollar loss of revenue to which it refers would have been avoided.

The fact is that the Government found the existing laws inadequate to meet the problem. Senator Sir John Carrick, who will speak later in the debate, will table a schedule of all the changes to existing laws which this Government has introduced under the leadership of the Treasurer, John Howard. Mr Howard is probably the first Federal Treasurer who has had to face such a massive tax avoidance problem, but he has responded to the challenge in a most active, vigorous and successful way. The so-called existing laws had proved inadequate; new laws were needed. The response of the Government was to introduce new laws and, in doing so, it succeeded significantly in stamping out the tax avoidance industry. It did not-and could not-stamp it out by administering existing laws, be they civil or criminal. I repeat, extensive new laws were needed. I am not merely talking about the individual case which Labor supporters seem to think represents the only issue involved. The straw, or bottom-of-the-harbour company is the product of only one of a large number of tax avoidance schemes that were introduced. That massive avoidance was not discovered by the Opposition. It was not discovered by Mr Costigan. The Government knew of the great variety of tax avoidance schemes in existence and acted against them. The schedule of the numerous measures that have been introduced by the Treasurer, John Howard, since 1977, and passed by the Parliament, will reveal the great activity on the part of the Government in changing the laws with the direct aim of stamping out various tax avoidance schemes which had arisen.

We came to government at a time when the tax avoidance industry was getting under way. As I have said, one of its earlier schemes had been ignored completely by the Labor Government. We stamped out that scheme by special legislation. We were also faced with a number of decisions of the High Court of Australia which revealed that the existing laws were not adequate. Time and again the Court's decisions showed that new laws were needed. For many years we had thought that a general dragnet provision, section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-which, briefly, states that arrangements entered into with the object of avoiding tax are null and void-could be used to strike down tax avoidance schemes. But, as a result of decisions of the High Court, that also virtually became a dead letter. What was the response of the Government to those High Court decisions? Numerous individual Acts, which succeeded in stamping out such schemes, were introduced and passed. But the industry had grown so large, had become so flourishing, and had so much wealth at its disposal that as soon as one scheme was stamped out another tended to crop up. Before the Commissioner of Taxation had time to become aware of these schemes, large losses of revenue accrued. The Government decided to try to deal with the problem, since section 260 had proven ineffective, by implementing a new general provision. Over those years a great deal of work had to be done to find a new, better and, it was to be hoped, foolproof section of the Act to replace section 260. That was implemented in new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was passed by the Parliament a little over a year ago. I believe that reveals the very active policy of this Government to deal with tax avoidance specifically, directly and, as has fortunately, proven to be the case, successfully.

I turn now to the specific case that we are discussing. It is one of numerous examples of tax avoidance which came to the attention of the Government over these years. As the Treasurer has said in statements issued during the recess- and again in the House today-the existence of so-called bottom-of-the-harbour or straw company schemes became known to the Government in about the middle of 1978 . They were brought to the Treasurer's attention by the Commissioner of Taxation . At about that time the Commissioner of Taxation had also raised the matter with the Crown Solicitor. There was, as the Treasurer and I have now become aware, this case in Perth. Let me make it quite clear-although I believe the Opposition accepts it as fact-that this case, which had first been referred to the Crown Solicitor in Perth in 1974, did not become known to the Treasurer or myself until after the McCabe-Lafranchi report was brought down this year. That particular case, and the opinion that had been given by Mr Brinsden in that case was--

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is right, why didn't it become known to you? Why didn't you ask the right questions in 1978?

—I simply wish to clear up that fact because the matter has been raised. As I have said, the specific case was not known to us. But in 1978 we knew of the problem. The Commissioner of Taxation had become concerned at the number of cases that had come to his attention. The matter was discussed with the Crown Law authorities and the views expressed by the Crown Law authorities were that there would be difficulties with the existing law, particularly with the criminal provisions as they existed because they were not specifically tailored to that particular type of scheme. Then the Treasurer, this having been brought to his attention, commenced to develop a new law, the toughest law of all-what became the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. That legislation was introduced and passed by this Parliament at the end of 1980. That law was one which did introduce-it is unusual in our tax laws-very specific criminal offences concerned with tax avoidance. That was the response that we took, as a government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer and I are now said to be specifically responsible and I do not deny the general responsibility that we have in this matter. That was the response of the Government to that scheme which had been brought to its attention. It was one of a number of schemes brought to the attention of the Government over those years. The response by the Government was to introduce special legislation. The Government's response to the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes was the development of special legislation, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. On all sides it is recognised that that Act was successful in dealing with those schemes, as other Acts have been successful in dealing with specific tax avoidance schemes. That, coupled with the general provision of the new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act introduced last year, has had dramatic effects on the tax avoidance industry, to the extent that people are now saying that the tax avoidance industry has largely been brought to its knees . It has been brought to its knees because of the constant activities of this Government since it became fully aware of the problem in 1977 and 1978. Since those years this Government and the Treasurer, I believe with a great deal of legal assistance from officers of the Attorney-General's Department and the Parliamentary Counsel, have produced this highly successful stamping out of the tax avoidance industry.

As I have said, Mr Costigan in his third report and now in his fourth report talks a great deal about the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The Opposition seems to be suggesting that this is the first time that the nature of the bottom-of- the-harbour or straw company avoidance schemes has become publicly known. That is not so; they were known to the Parliament. We brought in the legislation in 1980 and the Treasurer, in introducing the Bill, laid out the reasons for it. All that is new in the Costigan report is the recounting of the way in which a particular case had been handled in the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. In answer to questions earlier today and in my statement yesterday I made it clear that the Government does not condone the way in which the matter was handled in either the Perth office or the Central Office of the Crown Solicitor. But it is not prepared to accept as the final proof of the matter all of the findings of the royal commission. The people working in these offices have legal rights and actions would have to be taken in accordance with the existing law before those matters could finally be determined. I do not want to make any further comment on the findings because they are the subject of consideration under the Public Service Act. In the other cases, promoters and operators of these schemes will possibly be subject to prosecution. I have indicated what steps are being taken in that regard.

I would like to say-Senator Evans has made quite a feature of this matter-that the views of the Crown Solicitor and his associates about the adequacy of existing legislation were formed in absolute good faith. They had very good reasons for taking those views. I believe that the advice they gave to the Government that a new law was required was sound and sensible, even though it may turn out as a result of successful prosecutions that the existing law was adequate. We do not yet know whether that will be so. Yet Senator Evans comes in here and pontificates about the matter as though it was all cut and dried that the opinions he has referred to, including his own, will be shown to be correct. Nobody knows that. That is basically why the Crown Law authorities formed the view that new laws were needed. As I have said, the new laws have proved effective. The mere passage of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act was a most effective method of stamping out these practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that? What will happen if you don't prosecute under this Act? You have 14 cases outstanding, according to Costigan. What have you done about that?

—If there are grounds for prosecution under the Act, those prosecutions will be undertaken. The Act has been in force now for over 18 months. Everybody recognises that few schemes have come to light since then, and they are being looked at to see whether there should be prosecutions. That is the Government's response. The Government has a proud record of achievement in tackling tax avoidance. Despite what has been said, the Government has been well served by many dedicated public servants in the Taxation Office, the Crown Solicitor's Office and the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel over these years. The Taxation Office has identified these schemes and brought them to the attention of the Government. The Treasurer responded readily and got the Government to pass special legislation. A great deal of work was done by legal officers in my Department in drafting and advising in respect of legislation. So I think that a sense of perspective is required in relation to the report of Mr Costigan. As I said, I do not necessarily accept all that he has said. Even if one does accept the report, the fact of the matter is that it deals with the performance of a few people only and it is not and should not be seen to be a reflection on the many Crown Law officials and officials of the Attorney-General 's Department who are highly competent lawyers and dedicated servants of the Government and of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the matters with which I have dealt, which will be followed up in much more detail in the schedules that Senator Sir John Carrick will table, completely refute the Opposition's motion, and they are the reason why the Government rejects it and why the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and I have rejected the calls for our resignation. As a result of the work that has been done by the Treasurer personally and by his Department, I believe that we have got on top of the tax avoidance industry. Of course this will require continual vigilance. That is why I outlined yesterday in my statement the steps that the Government is taking to prosecute vigorously if possible--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are still saying 'if possible'.

—Well, we shall have to get counsel's advice, and we are getting that. We shall set up a special prosecutor and a special task force to enforce the laws-the old laws, if that proves possible, as well as, if there is any need to do so, under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. If civil remedies prove to be available, we shall be moving on them, as well. Let me reject completely the notion of resignation that Senator Evans has brought forward. The matter must be looked at in the light of the whole record of this Government.
—You have got it in one.

—Senator Evans is relying on some broad principle. The record of this Government, as I have outlined, and which will be given in more detail by Senator Sir John Carrick, is a record on which we can be judged. It is a record of great activity and of great success in the efforts that we have made to contain the tax avoidance industry and, I believe, as is now recognised, virtually to stamp it out. As I have said, we shall not sit back on our oars as though that is all. This will require constant vigilance. This Government will give constant vigilance and attention to seeing that the tax avoidance industry, which started in the days of the Labor Government, will not be able to continue and to flourish as it has done in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's failure effectively to pursue those involved in the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes from 1976 onwards is the most colossal single piece of maladministration in the history of public administration in this country.
—How do you know?

—It is about time that the Government acknowledged the force of that proposition. The sums of money involved, the losses involved, Senator Chaney-unless you are about to put on public record some losses about which we do not yet know, through your Western Australian mates or by some other means, in the history of Tory government in Australia-have been absolutely phenomenal by any standards. The failure in administration involved has not been simply a matter of minor peccadilloes. These have been no mere temporary or understandable lapses on the part of officials or politicians. This is no mere tuppeny-ha'penny kind of a matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The loss involved to the nation's resources, as Mr Costigan has pointed out, is on a literally incalculable scale. His own estimate is in terms of hundreds if not thousands of millions of dollars. But even if we accept the Government's own very cautious, very self-favouring estimate of only about $450m having been lost , which it believes is potentially recoverable in this area, we are clearly talking about staggering and unprecedentedly large sums of money. It is for this reason that this censure motion is directed in the first instance against the Government as a whole, because it is a failure of government, of Government will and Government competence, that is staggering in its dimensions. It is a failure which acutely reveals the hollowness of the Government's pretensions, repeated again by the Minister today, to be seriously concerned with tax avoidance and tax evasion.

The Government as a whole has sought to avoid blame in this matter by saying, I guess, three things. First, the Government says that there were genuine legal doubts as to whether prosecutions would lie in these matters. Secondly, it says that to the extent that there was indefensible maladministration within the Perth branch of the Crown Solicitor's Office, the two officers most immediately involved and still on deck have now been suspended. Thirdly, the Government says that it is taking a variety of other measures involving prosecutions, the establishment of a special prosecutorial task force and the establishment of the proposed new crime commission to clear away the mess and ensure that it does not recur.

I shall return shortly to the first point about the adequacy of the legal opinions and legal data available on this matter. As to the other points in the Government's defence-a defence extraordinarily feebly mounted by the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) today-this can be said. As to the suspensions of the officers, as to the procedure with the prosecutions that is now contemplated and as to the establishment of the task force, it is a matter of too little, too late. An ounce of effective prevention would have been, here as always, worth a ton of after-the-event cure. As to the establishment of the crimes commission, I believe that this is not so much a matter of too little, too late, as too much, too soon. That is because there is simply no evidence before us, least of all in anything in the Costigan report, that there is any serious deficiency in our existing law enforcement machinery, either on the investigative side or at the prosecutorial level, in terms of the substantive law and the machinery available to implement that law. All the evidence is in fact to the contrary-that the law was perfectly well equipped, and always has been, to deal with these matters; but what has failed has been the implementation of that law.

There is much more that could be said about the failure of the Government as a whole in this matter, the hypocrisy of its leadership in these tax avoidance and evasion questions, its incompetence, its apathy, its lack of will, and its lack of performance. I believe that it is appropriate in the circumstances of this debate to come quickly, as the terms of the censure motion do, to the Ministers most immediately involved-the Attorney-General, who has just spoken, and the Treasurer, Mr Howard.

The nub of the indictment against the Attorney-General can be expressed very simply. In the first place, it is difficult to believe that he did not know what was going on in his own Department, and if he did know what was going on there, he is culpable and obliged to resign. Secondly, if the Attorney-General did not know what was going on in his Department through the latter 1970s, he should have known and should have done something about it, and he is equally culpable in negligence, and equally he should resign. Thirdly, even if he did not know, and even if-which I do not accept-he could not be expected to have known what was going on, then he should offer to resign anyway, because of the magnitude of the disaster involved for the Australian nation as a result of his purported performance of his ministerial duties.

Let us begin with the first propositions-that the Attorney-General either must have known or should have known about what was going on in his own departmental backyard. The Opposition can accept and understand any claim that the Minister neither knew nor could be expected to know of the Perth test case prosecution strategy before 1977-78, even though the scheme which was the subject of that test case strategy was discovered, as we all know, as early as 1973, and even though a prosecution in that crucial test case was authorised under the Labour Government as early as August 1975.

As the Treasurer made clear in his statement on 27 June-this is one of the few things that were clear in his statement-the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes involved remained pretty minor, pretty exotic and pretty fringe in character up until 1977-78. It was not until then that the schemes really took off. It was not until 1977-78 that the avoidance and evasion involved in the operation of these schemes really became a problem of enormous magnitude for the government of the day. There is a quite bizarre logic, as I have pereceived it, on the part of Senator Durack in his attempt to put some of the blame on the Labor Government for the now prosecution of and the non-effective dealing with bottom- of-the-harbour schemes. Out of the mouth of the Treasurer, the Attorney's fellow Minister, came a very explicit and lengthy statement in justification of that Minister's own performance-that nobody could have been expected to move seriously and appreciate the gravity of the issues involved until 1977-78; in other words, nearly two years after this Government had come into office.

As I have said, as Mr Howard has said, and as everyone knows, by 1977-78 these schemes had taken off. They were running at a blinding pace. The reason they were running at a blinding pace was that every one of the promoters around the country who was getting into this area realised there had been a failure of will , nerve or competence on the part of this Government and there had been no prosecutions, no serious remedial action taken, even though it was known that some of the schemes had come to the attention of the authorities. By March 1978 at the latest, there was a clear knowledge-again, on the face of the evidence contained in the Costigan report-of the nature of these schemes and what was involved in them by the senior man in the Crown Solicitor's division, the Crown Solicitor himself, Mr Neaves. By March, April, May 1978 discussions had been taking place at the highest possible bureaucratic level in this area between the Federal Commissioner of Taxation and Mr Neaves, the Crown Solicitor. Clearly there was high level bureaucratic concern or if not concern, then at least attention being paid to these schemes at that time.

I believe we must assume that these discussions also involved the ministerial heads of those departments. Even if one does not accept that-Senator Durack for his own sake has denied it explicitly here in the Parliament today-it is certainly the case that both Ministers were involved by 1979-80 in the general area covered by the test case to which I referred regarding counter-action by the Government against bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Of course, they should have been involved by 1979-80. They should have been involved at least three years earlier. On their own account they were certainly involved at this stage. As John Howard has said, they were involved in working actively on legislative strategies during this period, work which culminated in the probably now unnecessary enactment at the end of 1980 of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act.

It is beyond belief that questions were not asked at this stage, at least and into 1979 by Senator Durack and Mr Howard of their senior officers as to what was going in regard to the prosecution of these schemes under the existing tax law. If those questions were asked it is beyond belief that the Attorney-General for one could have been satisfied with the answers that he was then given. He must have known that a prosecution had been authorised as far back as August 1975 on the basis of high level Queen's Counsel legal advice which was available at that time. He must have known that that prosecution was supported, as I said, by high level legal opinions. He must have known that there were no good reasons , other than incompetence, negligence or corruption, as to why that prosecution had not been subsequently carried through. He must have learnt then in 1978-79 and in the run up to 1980, if not before, of the festering mess in his own Crown Solicitor's division within the Attorney-General's Department, particularly in Perth. I have no doubt that the mess existed in many other parts of this country . I put it on notice now, for the benefit of the Attorney-General, his officers, the Crown Solicitor and the Deputy Crown Solicitors in a number of the States, that in the Estimates committee hearings in this place in two weeks time they can expect a very thorough examination as to the quality of their adminstration of this aspect of the Government bureaucracy.

Two defences are mounted by the Attorney-General and, indeed, by the Government as a whole, to these sorts of allegations about what they either must have known or-if one does not accept that-what they should have known at this period. The two defences are in terms, first, of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and, secondly, the lawyers' opinions which apparently, it is claimed, were divided on the question of the credibility or the possibility of prosecutions in this area. Let me get the record straight in regard of section 16. In relevant part, sub-section (1), states:

For the purposes of this section, 'officer' means a person who is or has been appointed or employed by the Commonwealth or by a State, and who by reason of that appointment or employment, or in the course of that employment, may acquire or has acquired information respecting the affairs of any other person, disclosed or obtained under the provisions of this Act or of any previous law of the Commonwealth relating to Income Tax.
I will not read the whole of the legislative scheme; just the relevant parts. So the nature of the information which is not to be disclosed by any such tax official is:
information respecting the affairs of any person.
There is a specific provision in section 16-sub-section (5A)-which does deal explicitly with the position of Ministers of the Crown. In relevant part, the sub-section states:

For the purposes of sub-sections (2) and (5), an officer or person shall be deemed to have communicated such information to another person in contravention of those sub-sections if he communicates that information to any Minister or to any Minister of the Crown of a State.

The legal point which I am making-I hope not too boringly, but it is crucial to the understanding of the credibility of the Government in this debate-is that the only prohibition on the communication of information to Ministers of the Crown by tax officials is information which is described here as 'such information'. The part containing the words 'such information' is a reference back to section 16 (1) which states:
information respecting the affairs of any person.

It is absolutely clear from any first year law student's interpretation of that legislation that all the officers are prohibited from doing is communicating to Ministers, or for that matter to anyone else who is not expressly exempt, information which identifies the affairs of a particular person. There is not, never has been and never could be in any rational tax legislation any prohibition on the communication of generalised information or information which has been sterilised of the names of the individuals concerned. There has always been communication to Treasurers by senior tax officials of information about the way in which particular schemes have operated. That information has been put forward on the basis of the experience of the tax officers concerned in particular cases, but has been put forward in a way-just as Mr Costigan's report has been put forward-that does not identify the people involved. Let us have no more of this canard about the secrecy provisions of section 16. Of course they stop the revelation of the names of the people concerned. But they did not and could not have stopped the revelation to the Ministers concerned of the nature of the schemes and the litigation strategy that was being employed to deal with them.

The other point that is made in purported defence of these allegations is that the lawyers' opinions were divided. At Question Time today we dealt with what those lawyers' opinions amounted to. It will be recalled that I asked the Attorney-General to table certain documents so that we could all judge for ourselves the credibility and weight of the respective opinions involved. I did make the point then, which I make again now, that the overwhelming weight of the legal opinion, which we know was given in the context of dealing with these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, was overwhelmingly on the side of the capacity of the people involved in those schemes-in the particular cases on which the lawyers in question were advising-being successfully prosecuted under the Crimes Act, the Companies Act or under common criminal law. In some cases it was argued by the lawyers involved that civil recovery under the law of misfeasance would apply. I repeat for the record-because I do not think Senator Durack could possibly have heard what I was saying at Question Time-that the opinions that we know about are as follows: Mr Brinsden, Q.C., in January 1975 advised the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth, which had sought that opinion, that a prosecution in the particular test case could be successfully brought under section 86 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act and that the liquidator could take action successfully for misfeasance to recover the lost tax.

In June 1975 Mr Brinsden, Q.C., gave a further opinion which concerned the sufficiency of the evidence available in that case to sustain a prosecution. Early in 1976 we have a Sydney Queen's Counsel, in a matter referred to by Mr Costigan at page 40 of his report in relation to Norfolk Island, advising again that there could be prosecutions for conspiracy under section 86 of the Crimes Act in these bottom-of-the-harbour circumstances. In November 1976 we have the Commonwealth Police conducting its own investigation and it is not entirely ignorant, or other than suspicious, when it comes to the applicability of the law to particular fact situations. For what it is worth, in 1976 we have the Commonwealth Police confirming affirmatively the ability of the Perth test case prosecution to lie.

In July 1978 we have Mr Traill, Q.C., giving strong advice that misfeasance provisions applied at common law and were capable of being set in train in relation to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Again, some time during 1978, we had the opinion from Mr Ormiston and Dr Spry, two silks from the Melbourne Bar, referring again, dealing again and confirming again the prosecutability, if you like, of these cases under the law of misfeasance. In September 1978 we had an opinion from a Melbourne Queen's Counsel. I have seen it. I know it exists although I am unable to say who the author of it is because of the circumstances in which it appeared. The opinion was derived by the liquidator, appointed by the Commissioner of Taxation, of Kierad Pty Ltd, again saying that criminal prosecutions could succeed. At the end of 1980 we had some rather self- interested opinions of a general nature, but for what they are worth they should be mentioned, from Mr Forsyth, Q.C., of the Melbourne Bar and Mr Russell, Q.C., and Mr Davies, Q.C., from the Melbourne Bar, supplied by the Law Institute of Victoria as part of its lobbying campaign against the necessity for any new legislation in this area. In July 1982 the Solicitor-General's own opinion was supplied to the Treasurer about the applicability of existing provisions, under the Companies Act certainly, and other areas of prosecution as well.

Against all those opinions, 10 in total, all that the Attorney-General was able to muster by way of counter evidence, all that Mr Howard was able to muster by way of countervailing material, were the apparently oral doubts and neuroses of the incompetent Mr Gleedman in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, the utterly generalised and inexplicit, unspecific letter of the Crown Solicitor to the Commissioner of Taxation dated 3 April 1979, a letter which Mr Costigan refers to in his report as not condescending to particulars, and a further letter from the Crown Solicitor dated 29 September 1980 confirming that earlier advice, again without descending to any detail, any reasoned argument, in support of it.

In addition to all of that material, we have Mr Costigan's own very thorough, very rigorous analysis of the law in the text of the report. It just staggers my comprehension that the Attorney-General could still be expressing doubts, concerns, worries for other than self-interested reasons now about the applicability of the law to these particular cases. Unless he is putting himself on the same legal level as the ill-starred Mr Gledman and his successors in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth, that kind of reservation, that kind of qualification, that kind of attempt to raise queries about the applicability of legislation that already existed in this particular area just does not stand up. The most charitable explanation for the Attorney-General's behaviour is that he was not corrupt, not looking after his Perth mates, but simply that he was incompetent in his conduct of his portfolio, that he was incapable to the point of culpable negligence of supervising the affairs of his Department in the interests of the nation.

We have had, of course, another attempt by Senator Durack in what he said to deal with the criticisms, the nub and thrust of the objections that have been put again today by the Australian Labor Party. He said that the Government's record in the area of tax achievement, far from being the kind of disaster that I and others have been saying it is and that Mr Costigan said it is, is a proud record of achievement. We have had a long tirade from Senator Durack today about the multiplicity of efforts by this Government, the multiplicity of legislative solutions advanced by this Government, to solve the alarmingly mounting problem of tax evasion and tax avoidance in this community. All I can say about that is that there has been a great deal of debate in this Parliament on a number of occasions, most recently last week, about the effectiveness of this particular strategy on the part of the Government. There are very different views in existence, which I have no time now to summarise yet again, about the whole foundations of the legislative approach that has been adopted by this Government with its multiple piecemeal attempts to close off particular loopholes long after the horses in question have bolted. But there is not only a legislative objection to the nature of the Government's remedial efforts in this area; there is also an objection based on the failure of that performance at an administrative level. There is no better person to quote in expressing that objection than the Commissioner of Taxation himself who, in his sixtieth annual report, for the year 1980-81, had this to say about the quality of this Government's anti-tax avoidance anti-tax evasion effort. I quote from page 12 of that report, which states:

In the 59th year and earlier Reports I recorded the adverse effect that investigations of tax avoidance activities had upon limited staff resources and collections of tax. Unfortunately I am unable to record any significant improvement for 1980-81. The number of experienced staff required to be allocated to the additional work of detecting, monitoring, investigating and contesting tax avoidance schemes continues to make serious inroads into the resources available for other administrative functions.
Further down the page the Commissioner says:
As a result, some $973m of tax assessed in tax avoidance schemes that are under administrative challenge remained uncollected at the end of June 1981.

Out of the mouth of the Commissioner of Taxation himself comes yet another indictment of the quality of this Government's tax avoidance-tax evasion strategy, if it can be dignified with that label. There can and has been debate, as I have said, about the merits of this or that strategy for dealing with this or that class of tax avoidance problem as it appears, and there will be many such classes of problem that do appear and will continue to appear. The advertisement from Mr Clyne in the financial Press this week must give the lie to anyone who confidently asserts that tax avoidance in this country is now dead .

There may be room for debate on the general level, but there is not and never has been any room for debate about what was the appropriate strategy for dealing with the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The appropriate strategy was to get hold of a test case as soon as one could possibly be found, pick up that test case and run with it, hard and fast, through the courts, with every possible administrative and executive level endeavour behind that process. What was needed, and what was needed no later than 1976, 1977 and 1978 at the latest, were sharp, tough, quick, sure-footed remedial actions-finding the right case, taking that case to the courts and giving it the disincentive effect on other promoters that that obviously would have had. What the Government got from Senator Durack was not sharp, tough, quick, sure-footed remedial action of this kind but action which, at its most charitable, can be described as more like the dithering of an elderly granny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be sexist about it.

—I will add 'grandfather'. The Minister's behaviour was deplorably weak, deplorably late and deplorably insufficient to cope with the magnitude of the circumstances that were presented. The Attorney-General has been, and the record demonstrates it, culpably negligent in the administration of his office, and if the Westminster system means anything his obligation is to pick up his bags and go from that office.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us come to the last point. Even if none of that argument is accepted about the role, the personal responsibility, the personal culpability, if you like, of the Attorney-General, even if he did not know anything about what was going on until McCabe-Lafranchi, and even if we accept that he was entitled not to know anything about what was going on or not going on in the prosecution of these schemes, the same conclusion holds. He should pick up his bags and tender his resignation to the Prime Minister of this country.

The reason is the magnitude of the blunder, the magnitude of the losses that have been involved to the Australian nation, to the taxpayers of this nation and the significance of that blunder, that colossal blunder, to the whole of this country. That puts this case in a very different league from the run-of-the-mill departmental errors that plague the administration of any government, for which Ministers, traditionally in the Westminster system, used to be held liable under the principles of individual ministerial responsibility but which, in current practice, which I readily acknowledge is the case and have said as much in the Freedom of Information Report which I signed, tends not to in fact be the case. But for once in his life I believe that Mr Fraser got the constitutional principles just about right when he dealt with this matter in his 1972 speech- already quoted by Senator Button-to the Australian Institute of Political Science, in the course of which he said, and I will use his exact words:

But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the Minister were unaware of it, the Minister should . . . . accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.

Several qualifications are built into that-if it is a major blunder and if it is of real importance to Australia. How can anyone deny that these criteria were satisfied in this particular case? I ask Senator Sir John Carrick, who is going to follow me, whether he accepts Malcolm Fraser's statement in 1972 as an accurate account of that part of the convention of individual ministerial responsibility these days. If he does not accept it I ask him to explain why not , because there is no doubt about its applicability here. Yesterday the Attorney -General was asked at a Press Conference whether he accepted responsibility for what went on in his Department and he replied, as of course he had to, that of course he did. Today, in the House of Representatives, we had Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, saying that the situation in the Attorney-General's Department was 'inexcusable'. The only honourable thing for this Attorney-General to do, even if we accept-as I do not believe we should-that he did not have any particular personal culpability in this whole sorry affair, is to tender his resignation.

The failure of the Government and the failure of these two Ministers-Mr Howard' s faults have been dealt with much more elaborately in the other place-to administer effectively the tax legislation of this country is deplorable and contemptible. There has never been a bigger administrative failure in the history of this country and there has never been a better deserved censure motion than this.
