Indeed, whether for that reason or whether to deal with white collar crime, the Commonwealth Government has announced that it proposes, with the help of the States, to set up a crimes commission to get to the very heart of crime, wherever it may occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —You got caught by the bottom-of-the-drawer schemes.

—If anyone is caught by the bottom-of-the-drawer schemes it is the Labor Party. Let me repeat what was said by Senator Evans. Of course, Senator Button was not here. Senator Evans's words were: 'Pick up a test case and run hard and fast through the courts'. In three years of Whitlam Government, from 1973 when that Government first knew about it, the case never got to the courts. If the test is that in this time people should have known-
—You took seven more years and then you abandoned it.

—The Costigan report exposes that the Labor Administration did not know about it. Indeed, if that is the case members of the former Labor Government should accept responsibility for the delays in that prosecution. Honourable senators opposite fall down in all their tests. In fact, nobody, with any reality or justification, can challenge the integrity of the two Ministers concerned. Nobody can. These Ministers are people who the community of Australia know to be people of outstanding integrity. They are also people who have very great ability and have had great reformist zeal in what they have been doing. They have carried out those things whereas, of course, the Labor Party did nothing on tax avoidance at all. I have listed the volume of matters that have been brought before this Parliament to pursue tax avoidance. We will pursue each of those incidents to the full. If there are breaches of tax laws and if people owe money to the Commonwealth then we will pursue that. The fact of the matter is that under the previous Government nothing was done; under our Government a very great deal has been done. The Government rejects outright the censure motion. There are no grounds for it at all. On the contrary, this Government and those Ministers should be congratulated because we have initiated these exposures, because we have taken the steps we have and because we have set up remedies and measures to pursue tax evaders and avoiders to the full. We will do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I go on to give the reasons for my support and for the Australian Democrats' support for this motion-indeed before I go on to give the reasons why we approached the Opposition this morning to strengthen its original motion-I cannot let pass some of the more extraordinary statements that have been made by Government supporters in this debate. The first-this is the one which has arisen most frequently-is the statement that because the Australian Labor Government did not do anything in the three years in which it was in Government that is justification for the Liberal-National Country Party Government not doing anything for seven years. That comment, to any parent who is listening to this afternoon's debate, will be depressingly familiar. The comment we hear from just about every playroom in this country is: 'He did it first. Therefore, I am at liberty to punch back'. It is the most childish and the most unsustainable argument of the lot. Then we have the argument that goes: 'We could not hit the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes because there were so many others around the place'. I just wonder how many policemen can argue that they let some particular offender go because they had not been able to collect all the rest in a particular dragnet at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: The third argument that has been put forward is that the lawyers disagreed. We are all used to lawyers disagreeing. The whole criminal system is based on the fact that lawyers will disagree with each other. They are no different from psychiatrists, or for that matter economists or politicians. As Senator Evans has pointed out, the whole question of lawyers disagreeing with each other would have been solved if only somebody had been bright enought or fast enough off the mark to put up a test case or two to test which of the lawyers was right. It would certainly have been a darned sight cheaper to the taxpayer in the long run . Then we had the argument, which apparently has been put forward by the Treasurer (Mr Howard), that the public was not concerned enough about the problem for the Government to feel any need to act.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not know.

—Apart from the fact, Senator Georges, that the public may not have known-I dispute that anyway-I hope we have not yet reached the stage where we are governed by opinion poll. To argue that one does not act until the public is screaming at the doors of King's Hall is one of the most blatant pieces of political expediency that I have heard for some time. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) argued that Mr Costigan puts the point that the Ministers of this Government were denied access to information which was available to Mr Costigan, which brings one to ask the question: 'Why did Mr Costigan get the information that the Ministers did not?' The answer is simple; he had the intelligence to ask a few pertinent questions and they did not.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Government comes up with the argument that it does not accept all of Mr Costigan's findings other than the ones that suit it. That is standard practice; governments are notorious for accepting only selectively recommendations of reports. This Government has done it with everything from Senate committee reports through to the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is entitled to his opinion of some of the opinions that Mr Costigan has put forward. After all, he has a vested interest in rejecting some of them. Nevertheless, it is my belief-I think it is a belief shared at least today by many other ordinary Australians-that Mr Costigan must have had some good reason for coming to his conclusions. If they embarrass the Government, that is a little unfortunate. It is particularly unfortunate, of course, in view of the fact that the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, that we are referring to today-or at least some of us are referring to today-was set up in 1980 by this Government following a series of articles that appeared in March and April of 1980 in the Bulletin.

Those articles contained allegations of corruption on the waterfront. The articles carried headings such as 'Like Nelson, the navy turns a blind eye-and pays up', 'How the Government Condones Waterfront Graft', 'Australia's Most Dangerous Criminal Tells All' and 'the Unionist Who Ignores The Arbitration Act' . The allegations specifically related to the practice of ghosting and also raised the general question of illegal and violent activities engaged in by the particular union concerned. This in itself raises the question of why the Government had to be forced to act by such articles; why it was not sufficiently aware and on the ball to move prior to these allegations being raised in a national magazine. Surely, if a journalist, an investigator such as David Richards, can come up with this information, then the combined forces-even the individual forces-of Government departments ought to be able to come up with them. Mr Costigan pointed out in his third interim report and-he repeated in this one:
. . . the Commission, to the surprise of many, found itself investigating the tax evasion industry.

It had started an investigation into the violence of the painters and dockers, and those investigations and the two million pages of documents it has acquired by truck and other means led it to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth and to some extremely disturbing comments about officers in that Department and the results of their actions. In paragraph 3.21, Mr Costigan states:

. . . I have observed that some officers of the Australian Taxation Office and of the Crown Solicitor have had difficulty in understanding the mechanism for proving intent to defraud in a conspiracy case. At times I have detected comments that no intent to defraud could be present if the Taxation Assessment had not yet issued, so that if the assets of the company were removed before it was issued, and the books of account destroyed to make its issue more difficult, no crime could be established.
That, states Mr Costigan, is quite definitely 'an erroneous view of the law'. He points out also:
It also overlooks the alternative charge of defeating the operation of Commonwealth law, which, as I have said, is also prescribed by the Crimes Act.
On the following page, under the heading 'The Lamentable History of Non Prosecution', Mr Costigan continued:

. . . the Australian Taxation Office in Perth detected the operation of these schemes as early as 1973, and selected one for intensive investigation. The investigation was done by Senior Investigation Officer Mr Todman. It was done competently and diligently . . . By mid 1974 he decided to seek legal advice. He has told me that his past experience with the appropriate officer of the Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth had not been good; accordingly he asked (through his Deputy Commissioner) for an opinion to be sought from a Queens Counsel. In a letter dated 4 September 1974 the Deputy Taxation Commissioner said to the Deputy Crown Solicitor:
'The recovery of company tax in this case and other cases acquired (by the promoter) raises issues which could have far reaching implications on the collection of company tax generally'.
Thus, the Deputy Crown Solicitor was informed of the grave nature of the matter at an early stage.

Unfortunately, it would appear that Mr Todman's apparent lack of faith in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth was to be more than vindicated by subsequent events. As I mentioned in the debate yesterday, Mr Costigan casts considerable doubt on the qualifications and ability of at least three officers of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth and questions the intentions and /or honesty of two of those men.

As has already been pointed out, the matter of these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes first came to the attention of the Australian Taxation Office in Perth in 1973. They were half-heartedly investigated by the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office with the ignored advice of at least one independent Q.C. who delivered his opinion in June of 1975, expressing the view that section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act was no bar to a prosecution. This opinion was transmitted to Canberra to the Commissioner of Taxation in July of 1975 and in August of 1975 the Deputy Crown Solicitor in Perth was instructed that action should be taken as soon as possible under section 86 of the Crimes Act. In paragraph 3.31 Mr Costigan points out:
The Attorney-General, and his supporting staff constituted by the legal officers in the Crown Solicitor's Office, have a role to perform different to-
I would have said 'different from', but never mind-
that of solicitors in private practice, particularly in the case of criminal prosecutions.
I think this is the whole point of the motion that the Opposition has moved today and which the Australian Democrats support. The paragraph continued:

Whereas a solicitor in private practice is bound by his instructions subject only to qualification in very restricted areas, the law officers of the Crown are not. Their primary duty is to uphold the law and to do so notwithstanding the effect it may have on the operation of the Government of the day . . . His basic duty-
Presumably he is referring to the Attorney-General-
was to determine whether it was in the public interest for the prosecution to be instituted.
At the end of paragraph 3.33 the Commissioner states:

Accordingly, by these instructions, Mr Gleedman's duty was to report the matter to the Crown Solicitor. Although the Crown Solicitor entered into the matter personally at a later stage, this was after Mr Gleedman had retired. Mr Gleedman never complied with this instruction.

In fact Mr Gleedman did nothing for the remainder of 1975. According to Mr Costigan, when Mr Gleedman was questioned about this lack of action he said he was 'reading the case', which prompted the rather pithy comment from the Commissioner that he had already read the case presumably to permit him to brief counsel in late 1974. The Commissioner went on to say that when pressed Mr Gleedman indicated a lamentable lack of knowledge about the case that he had apparently read. The situation continued to muddle along under Mr Gleedman's somewhat deficient oversight until that gentleman retired in late 1977 on the grounds of ill health. I point out that, contrary to the assertion made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate Mr Gleedman insisted that his ill health did nothing to impair his ability to act. Unfortunately, as Mr Costigan points out, Mr Gleedman's successor was to prove even worse, resorting finally to his own bottom-of-the-drawer scheme by hiding files in his desk for something like five years.

Surely, one is permitted to wonder what the Attorney-General was doing during the years 1976 to 1980. Indeed, given the Commissioner's remarks with regard to the validity of the pre-1980 tax legislation, a view supported by the remarks of counsel consulted by Mr Gleedman, what was the Treasurer doing during those years? Why, in the public interest, was no test case picked up and followed through? Why were the stalling actions, the outright actions of sabotage of officers of the Perth Crown Solicitor's office, apparently unnoticed by anyone in the Attorney-General's Department or the Australian Taxation Office which, as had been pointed out repeatedly, had been aware of the problem since 1973. The reasons can only be total incompetence on the part of the officers involved and the Ministers concerned or a deliberate attempt by some people to keep the matter under wraps for personal or political motives. In any event, the cost to the Government of the failure of the departments concerned to act in the public interest has led to the Government, and thus the taxpayer, being defrauded of hundreds of millions of dollars.

I put to the Senate that this matter is at least as serious as the case of a Minister failing to pay duty on a television set and of another Minister condoning it, for which heinous crimes both have been relegated to the back benches. Surely, allowing the defrauding of the taxpayer of the sort of money to which Mr Costigan refers in his report is as important and culpable a misdeameanour as that of which the two unfortunate Ministers to whom I have referred were guilty. Between 1973, when the scheme was first uncovered, and 1980 when the Government took action to strengthen the laws relating to this form of behaviour-laws which, by the way, according to a number of eminent counsel needed no strengthening, merely enforcing-the number of companies involved grew from 27 to 1,412.

Mr Costigan leaves no doubt in the mind of anyone who reads his report that this was due entirely to lack of appropriate action by the government departments concerned. Again, one is forced to wonder why nothing was done, why the officers employed by the Government were, or appeared to be, so inept, so unsure of the law, so lacking in the background necessary to ensure that the interests of the public were looked after. It has concerned me for a number of years that somehow lawyers and accountants employed by big businesses, by tax evaders, are able enough, good enough, well qualified enough or just sneaky enough to identify and make use of loopholes, anomalies or omissions in the law but that the Government, with all its resources, is either not able or willing to identify the same problems and act to counter them or, better still, identify them before they are given effect by the Parliament and thus ensure that they are not availed of in the first instance.

The crux of the motion before us today is this: Either Ministers in this or any other government are responsible for their portfolios or they are not. Either they are responsible for the actions of their officers or they are not. If they are-certainly the present Prime Minister, as quoted by Senator Evans earlier, seems to believe that in most instances they are-they must accept the ultimate responsibility for the actions of their senior public servants. In this case that means tendering a resignation regardless of whether they knew-or admit they knew-about the actions of their officers. If Ministers are not held responsible for what happens in their portfolios we might just as well not have Ministers. We could certainly save the taxpayer a certain amount of money by simply allowing the public servants in the departments to run things the way they want to run them.

Whatever else is said to the contrary by honourable senators opposite or anyone else, both the Attorney-General and the Treasurer should have known about the schemes and about the investigations-or what passed for investigations-in the relevant Government departments. Section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the privacy provisions therein are no excuse. One is forced to view the photograph of the Attorney-General, which appeared on the front page of this morning's Sydney Morning Herald, as having some truth to it, as expressing some sort of prophesy. It was, for those honourable senators who did not see it, a delightful photograph of the Attorney-General with his finger in his ear. It seems to me that he did not want to hear what had been happening in his Department for six or seven years. As a consequence, he did not know what was going on either because he made no attempt to know or because he did not want to know.

I have no intention of canvassing the issue of the involvement of senior members of the Liberal Party in Western Australia in these bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. It is of very little moment to this motion. I, for one, do not believe that the Ministers concerned can be held responsible for the actions of Western Australian individuals, whether or not they belong to the Liberal Party-unless, of course, they were aware of them and were covering up for them. I have no intention of even suggesting that that was likely. The Minister may be foolish but I do not deny his integrity. However, it is without question that Ministers are responsible for the actions of their departmental officers. That the Ministers we are discussing today were ignorant of what was going on and, as a consequence, negligent indicates that they must resign. The announcement by the Government of the establishment of a task force is not a substitute for such resignations. It does nothing but close the door after the horse has bolted.

As I said yesterday during the debate on the report, there has been something less than total frankness on the part of some Government officials and some Government Ministers. There has been, to say the least, a lamentable lack of enthusiasm by officials and the Government to prosecute any of the 1,412 companies operating schemes up to 1980. I suggest that the Government has much to answer for and that the Commissioner, Mr Costigan, is to be commended for exposing the saga of negligence, misfeasance, arrogant disregard for the law and , I might add, the harm to the interests of the general public, a disregard that was probably best summed up by Mr Bercove. According to paragraph 3.59 of the report:
When it was put to him that this was intentionally dishonest, he was indifferent. In his view, 'everyone does it' and therefore it was good enough for him.

Any Minister who even suspects that this sort of attitude is rife in the community, much less in his own Department-I suggest that he would have had to have fingers in both ears to have missed the rumblings that were going on in the community-and still allows it to continue is not fit to have the oversight of a department which is expected to act in the public interest. Resignations under these circumstances, unfortunate as they are, are unavoidable. Resignation is the only honourable avenue open to both the Attorney-General and the Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is considering a motion to censure the Government for its grave failure, and the failure of the Attorney- General (Senator Durack) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in particular, in the administration of legislation relating to criminal and civil offences against the tax laws resulting in multi-billion dollar frauds against the Commonwealth, and calls for the resignation of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer. Conscious of the fact that the success or failure of this motion, for good or bad, may well depend on how I vote, I have listened carefully to every word that has been uttered in this debate. The debate follows the tabling of Interim Report No. 4, Volume 1, of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, referred to as the Costigan report. I believe that that report quite clearly reveals tax evasion on a massive scale which has been perpetrated against the citizens of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this censure motion misses the mark if the Parliament and the people of Australia are to tackle the problem of tax evasion. Following the McCabe-Lafranchi report the Government has already listed a number of things that it proposes to do in respect of this matter. People in the community can also do a number of things about it. Before I come to the question that is the key to the consideration of this motion of censure-that is to say, ministerial responsibility-I want to put on record that a number of institutions in this country ought to have regard to what Costigan has said in his report and take action accordingly. It is quite clear that professional people, employers and this union are involved in this type of racket. These types of tax evasion schemes on a massive scale could not operate without certain members of the professions being involved. Surely it is incumbent upon the institutions representing the legal fraternity to take action, to charge the persons responsible and to expel them from those institutions. That applies as well to accountants and I guess it also applies to the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party, with which the Ship Painters and Dockers Union is affiliated.
I have some understanding of what the Ship Painters and Dockers Union is like. Let us not forget what Mr Costigan said about that organisation. On page 109 of his report, he said:

This sad story is consistent with the image presented by the union to the community. The union has created for itself over the years a reputation for violence and for the community an atmosphere of fear. This has made it almost impossible to obtain evidence against members of the union in relation to their criminal activities. They in effect operate as a state within a state. This union has a positive policy of recruiting hardened criminals, at least in Victoria.
Presumably it never takes up its options under section 144 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The report continues:

Such people normally are unattractive to honest people, including the many honest and hard working trade unionists in this country. But to this union such criminals are desirable. It is probably for the purpose of making use of their dubious 'talents'.

I well recall that, as secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, I received a call one night from the Ship Painters and Dockers Union in Victoria to say that they would be over on the morning plane to grab what was rightfully theirs in the State of Tasmania. I recall also getting up early the next morning and getting hold of people who were allegedly doing their work, including the Waterside Workers Federation, the Marine Harbour Trust Employees Association and the shipwrights union, calling a meeting of the disputes committee and determining what ought to be done about it. Fortunately the representatives of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union left my State on the evening flight. After that, as a result of a court case, the Ship Painters and Dockers Union was not successful in gaining a foothold, at least in Hobart, at that stage. Nevertheless, it was recognised at that time, by us as an institution, that here was an organisation-the dogs were barking-full of criminals. Of course that has been borne out as a matter of statement by the Royal Commission. We all knew it. Not long before, the previous secretary of the union had been shot and the wags were saying: 'I suppose the committee of management will meet and put an ad in the newspaper saying ''Wanted, Ship Painters and Dockers Union Secretary-$200 a week plus lead bonus'' '. We all knew about it at that time and now the chickens have come home to roost officially.

It was not beyond those who were attacking the moderate element of the trade union movement at that time to use the Ship Painters and Dockers Union for their own ends. Though the official branch of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in my State, the TTLC, refused affiliation to the Ship Painters and Dockers Union, those who sought to split the trade union movement in my State-they are still seeking to split the trade union movement-granted the union affiliation and support against the opposition of myself at that time and against the continuing opposition of the current secretary of the Tasmanian Trades and Labour Council, who, incidentally, was expelled by the ALP. He called a point of order on this matter and was told by the representative of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union what would happen to him if he continued in that vein. I give that as an example of what institutions in this country ought to do with people who are robbing blind the community of Australia. As I said, in those institutions are the legal fraternity, the accountants, the ALP and anybody else who has some power to tackle the people concerned, not least of all the Government.

I turn to what I believe this motion turns on-ministerial responsibility. I believe that everything said by the Opposition in support of this proposition could have been said in so far as it deals with the censure of the Government, but when it calls for the resignation of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer it goes too far. That is because this goes to the so-called doctrine of ministerial responsibility. That doctrine is not something, as honourable senators will know, that is written into any Act of Parliament, nor is it something that is included in the Constitution of the Commonwealth.

It would, of course, be quite impossible to define for all time and for all occasions what constitutes the doctrine of ministerial responsibility and what are the limits and substance of that doctrine. Senator Haines referred to the most recent case, that of the two Ministers, Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore. I want also to refer to those cases, the last occasion on which the question of ministerial responsibility arose. It was in connection with the incident of the television set and the two Ministers, Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore, last April. A brief review of what happened on that occasion provides an opportunity to place this recent incident in proper perspective. I am now talking about the question of principle and not the question of amount.

Honourable senators will recall that the colour television set incident which resulted in the resignation of the two Ministers revolved around the failure of the then Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, himself to declare that the television set that he was bringing into Australia was not a black and white set but was a colour set and hence the subject of duty under the provisions of Commonwealth law. It also involved the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, knowing about the incident but not insisting upon the payment of duty.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he was advised that there was no duty payable.

—Yes, I understand that, but he knew of the situation. He may have been advised along certain lines but he ought to have known what the law was. Fundamentally, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) pointed out on 19 April, it appeared that a Minister was in a preferred position as compared with other Australians. I am stating this as a matter of principle. I have a high regard for the two members personally. Senator Evans, who today is calling for the resignation of not only the Attorney-General but also the Treasurer, commented in April after the resignation of Mr Moore and Mr MacKellar as follows :

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously they have paid a very serious price indeed, but so they should have paid a serious price because it was a spectacular lapse from the standards of probity, propriety, decency and honest behaviour that one expects of the Ministers of the Crown.

That was Senator Evans's statement on AM on 20 April 1982. The Melbourne Age, in a comment shortly before the resignation, referred to other aspects of ministerial responsibility. On 19 April 1982 it said:

Both Ministers, however, have so far chosen to ignore the convention which requires them to resign when called to account for 'serious derelictions of duty which erode the integrity of the Administration'.
Drawing on these comments we should ask: Where is the spectacular lapse from the standards of probity, propriety, decency and honesty of behaviour?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is culpable negligence in this case.
—I am quoting you, Senator Evans, from what you said at that time as constituting reasons why those Ministers ought to resign.
—That was culpable behaviour then. It is a different kind of culpable behaviour now.
—What I want to know is where those descriptions fit the Attorney-General. Where is the serious dereliction of duty? Senator Evans believes there has been serious dereliction of duty.
—Exactly.

—Senator Evans has to have it one way or the other. Either he is accusing the Attorney-General and the Treasurer on the grounds on which he accused Moore and MacKellar, namely, standards of probity, propriety, decency and honesty-they are his words-
—They were appropriate then. You are twisting on the end of it.
—So Senator Evans is not accusing the Attorney-General of dishonest behaviour.
—Not yet.
—He is not accusing-not yet.
—There may well be evidence which would support that.

—So Senator Evans is not saying that the Attorney-General lacks standards of probity, propriety, decency and honest behaviour that one expects of Ministers of the Crown. He it not making that accusation about the Treasurer. All right; let us put that aside. So it comes down to the question of serious dereliction of duty.
—Exactly. Culpable negligence.

—All right. Where is the serious dereliction of duty? Where is the advantage which Senator Durack has obtained personally? I refer to the Costigan report, which is quite clear on this matter. On pages 24 and 25 it says :

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary, before I proceed further, to draw the attention of those who may read this Report to the circumstances that the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act apply with equal force to the Ministers who have charge of the enforcement of the law in this area. I refer in particular to persons holding the office of Treasurer, and of Attorney-General. The events to which I am referring took place over a period of 10 years. It will be recalled that during that time there had been a number of incumbents of both those high offices in the State. All of them have been denied access to the detailed information which has now been provided to me, and which has identified the situation described in this report.
Costigan goes on to say:

It is sufficient to say, at this stage, that the secrecy provision has been an effective bar to proper ministerial supervision of the discharge of duty by both the Australian Taxation Office and the Crown Solicitor's Office.

I ask, therefore: Where is the dereliction of duty? The truth, as has been stated by Senator Durack-and I have to take it on the statement that he has made -is that he did not know about the matters referred to in the Costigan report until the McCabe-Lafranchi report came down, as I understand it, in May of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should have known.
—I have just quoted from Costigan, who indicated why the Attorney-General would not have known.
—Costigan got it wrong on section 16.

—I am not a lawyer so I cannot say whether Costigan got it wrong and whether Senator Evans got it right. All I can do is examine the things that have come across in this debate and the report that was put before us yesterday. When Senator Durack heard about this matter because of the McCabe- Lafranchi report-I might say that some contention exists between Senator Durack and me on a number of issues-he did not leave the file in a drawer for five years. He announced certain activities which he has detailed to the Senate. The people who are at fault are public servants employed in the Deputy Crown Solicitor's office in Perth. The story of the escort agency and the telephone number belongs to the world of farce or worse. I do not hold each and every Minister in this Parliament responsible for all the details of what goes on in the offices occupied by the hundreds of thousands of public servants in Australia. I do not think anybody here would hold them to account.
—Not necessarily, anyhow.

—As somebody says: 'Not necessarily anyhow'. I have taken the trouble to go through the number of censure motions calling on Ministers to resign that have been placed before the Parliament for some considerable time. The censure motions were moved against both sides. On any reasonable estimation of ministerial responsibility, one cannot hold a Minister responsible for all the detail of what goes on in the offices occupied by the hundreds of thousands of public servants, particularly in this case where both the Treasurer and the Attorney-General were denied access to the information by reason of the operation of an Act of Parliament in respect of the secrecy of taxation information. The immediate superiors of those public servants should know. If something is seriously amiss in a regional office the central administration should be informed immediately. In this episode the central administration was not so informed by the Perth office. How could any reasonable person claim that the Minister should have ferreted around and located all of this information?

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that on any reasonable estimation of the doctrine of ministerial responsibility this censure motion fails. I return to what I said at the beginning of my address: The Parliament and the people concerned now should track down those who have been responsible over the years for this rort. The professional institutions and others in the community have a responsibility to ensure that those who have been involved in these rackets are debarred provided there is proof, from participation in their affairs. This must happen if those institutions are to maintain their integrity. I propose not to support the censure motion. It calls for the resignation of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer and in my estimation of ministerial responsibility that call is not warranted on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a censure motion in the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Government for its grave failure, and the failure of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer in particular, in the administration of legislation relating to criminal and civil offences against the tax laws . . .

I acknowledge the contribution to the debate made by Senator Harradine. It has done a great deal to restore some balance to a debate which has tended to overlook many of the aspects of concern which have been raised by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. As one would expect, the Opposition has focused its attention on one chapter of the latest report which has been tabled in this Parliament. The Opposition has been careful to avoid reference to the broader questions raised by the reports which have been given to the Parliament. Not merely the tax system has been identified by the Costigan Royal Commission as being under threat from the Ship Painters and Dockers Union. If one looks at interim report No. 3, which was presented in February 1982, one will find a chronicle of other areas in which members of this union are alleged to have taken action which is clearly, and severely, against the public interest. The first area which was identified affected my department, the Department of Social Security. Under the heading 'Social Security Fraud' the report states:

Material already available to the Commission indicates that very large numbers of painters and dockers have been involved in imposition on the social security system. Such imposition involves the receipt of social security benefits whilst workers under false names are either in receipt of workers' compensation benefits or working at other employments. The Commission's ability to identify false names has enabled these investigations to be pursued and will result in the recovery by Government to a large extent of the amount illegally received. It is not possible at this stage of the investigation to state precisely the amount involved but it will be well over $1,000,000.

The first area identified was the Department of Social Security. We were advised by the Commission that there is a substantial imposition on that system. I suppose that had the members of the Opposition recalled interim report No. 3 they might well have included me in this motion and sought my resignation also. I make the point that these defalcations are made by people who are prepared to behave in a fraudulent way. In a society such as our own, when there are people who are prepared to behave in a fraudulent way it is inevitable that some of those people escape detection, at least for a time. We know that there has been fraud in the area of social security. That matter is being pursued by both my Department and the Australian Federal Police, with some success.

The next matter which was dealt with by the Royal Commission affected the workers' compensation system. Mr Costigan outlined that that system also has been subject to plunder by claims which are described as 'not justified, but also claims which are made involve payment of benefits for periods far in excess of what should be paid'. He states:
The amounts are very large. At the Williamstown Naval Dockyard alone the amount would be aproaching $200,000 per annum.
The report goes on to state:
There are a number of other areas including the traditional area of ''street crime'', which description covers offences ranging from stealing to murder.

It may be that the civil libertarians on the Australian Labor Party side of this chamber are not particularly concerned about street crimes and the possibility of murder. I would have thought there was nothing more serious in terms of the victim than the suggestion that people do not have even personal security because of the activities of members of this union. There has already been a reference-not by Opposition speakers, of course, but by Government speakers and by Senator Harradine-to some of the other parts of the report which was tabled yesterday-that is, interim report No. 4, Volume I. In chapter 4 of the report one finds an account of evidence given with respect to the Station Hotel which describes the physical fear of people who are trying to go about their lawful business and the demands that they engage in illegal behaviour. In chapter 5 under the heading 'Violence in the Union' reference was made to a string of major crimes against the person which are sheeted home to members of this union.

We are dealing with a situation which, in the course of a royal commission into the affairs of a union, has aroused rather widespread concern in the community. There are also very serious exposures of a breakdown in some areas of our own administration. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has not sought to minimise that. I do not think the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) speaking in the other place, have sought to minimise that. Indeed, the actions of the Government since these matters have come to light indicate the very serious way in which we view them. However, I want to make the point that we are in the middle of a period in which the concern about taxation and tax evasion is being used not merely to the proper effect of trying to ensure that the laws are adequate and that there is proper administration; that concern is also being used to great political effect and there is a great and open attempt to make everybody guilty by association. We have heard plenty of statements in the Senate and outside the Senate drawing attention to the affiliations of and the connections between people who are named as having been involved in tax avoidance-not tax evasion-and the Liberal Party. That is, of course, wonderful politics. But there has been really nothing said in this place , even by members of the Government, let alone by members of the Opposition, about the affiliations of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. I have no wish to indulge in this technique of guilt by association. I do not for a moment suggest--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean? I said that. It is not guilt by association . They are affiliated and the left wing mob in my State used them against me.

—I am grateful for the interjection by Senator Harradine. But I was going on to point out to honourable senators opposite that the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union is in fact a union which has affiliations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Trades and Labour Councils and the Australian Labor Party in the States of New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria . So if one can extend by association allegations of misconduct, let alone allegations of bloody murder as it was described by Senator Sir John Carrick, then I would suggest to honourable senators opposite that they ought very carefully to examine the affiliations which they themselves enjoy. I believe that we do not serve this country terribly well when we seek, for narrow political purposes, to exaggerate situations and wrongly to condemn people who have nothing to do with wrong doing and, indeed, in many cases have done nothing wrong at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I would certainly agree that the interim report No. 4, volume 1, of the Royal Commission which has been the subject of debate today, does expose that there have been serious problems in parts of the administration of the Commonwealth. I would simply say that these problems involve areas which have been either attacked before the publication of this report or, where they were not known of before the publication of this report, are now receiving careful attention. It is quite clear that long before the McCabe-Lafranchi report, for example, that very strong action was taken by the Government with respect to bottom-of-the- harbour schemes. I have very limited time in which to speak, but any honourable senator, and indeed any member of the public concerned about the Government's reaction to the bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, can have access to the very lengthy statement put out by the Treasurer on 27 June in which he detailed the history of his dealings with this matter and the Government's actions. I merely want to refer to what appears at page 8 of that Press release which sets out the legislative action which was taken by the Government. For the first time, this Government imposed sentences of imprisonment for taxation offences. I refer first to page 4. The Treasurer said:

When the Commissioner of Taxation first raised with me in May 1978 the prospect that criminal penalties might need to be introduced in order to deal with these practices, they were still being documented and the full extent of their use was not yet known. Priority was then being given to dealing with other established and damaging schemes, both by the Taxation Office in its administrative responses and advice to me and by the Government in its own legislative processes and response.

At page 8 the Treasurer goes on to point out that in his second reading speech on 26 November 1980-long before Costigan, long before McCabe-Lafranchi had reported-he introduced the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Bill which dealt with these specific schemes. As he said in the second reading:

As the task of artificial avoidance has become more difficult, the less scrupulous have added a new and I think most would agree, unacceptable dimension to endeavours to ensure that payment of tax is escaped . . .

The seriousness of the position cannot be overstated. For example, one promoter is known to have stripped some 2,086 companies during a recent period. In 733 of these cases, the result has been that the Commissioner of Taxation will be unable to collect tax on taxable incomes aggregating over $128m.

I emphasise that these are statements made long before McCabe-Lafranchi and long before the Costigan reports, and they indicate the sort of action which was being taken by the Government, by the Treasurer and, indeed, by the Attorney- General, who was intimately concerned with the preparation of this legislation against the very areas of abuse which are referred to in these Costigan reports. All that is relevant to this question of ministerial responsibility.

I thank Senator Harradine for his comments on that matter, which I think were practical and accord with the reality of that doctrine in Australia. It occurred to me as I was listening to him and indeed it occurred to me before when I was listening to the quite extraordinary propositions being put forward by Senator Haines on behalf of the Australian Democrats, just what an impossible test honourable senators opposite are trying to establish. A couple of days ago, for example, somebody died in Sydney. That person was found to have a whole series of false bank accounts, false birth certificates and to be claiming in multiple names on the Department of Social Security. That was a clear case of fraud. I sat there and thought that on the basis that has been submitted by the Opposition today I, too, should be resigning. I believe that that is not a standard which can be applied in this case. I believe that when one looks at the totality of action which has been taken, when one looks at the statement that the Treasurer made in June, and when one sees the history of this matter, it is quite clear that the Government, the Treasurer, and the Attorney-General have behaved in a proper manner. What is set out in that statement that the Treasurer made in June is in fact a statement of the painstaking work which has been done by the Government in this field. Earlier this afternoon Senator Sir John Carrick incorporated in Hansard a summary of the tax measures which have been introduced by this Government. I will not go through them again but that summary contains some five and a half pages of specific measures which have been taken year by year through the Parliament to close off tax loopholes.

The point has been made in the debate that that sits against the Labor Party's own record in this area where, after the 1974 announcement of Mr Crean, no action was in fact taken. I make that point not as an accusation of bad faith against Mr Crean, not as an accusation of bad faith against the Treasurer who succeeded him, not against the Treasurer who succeeded him again, Mr Hayden. I think that is simply a comment on the way that these processes have to be developed and on the difficulty of bringing forward legislation. While some would point to it as evidence of culpable negligence on the part of the Labor Government, I would simply say that it is evidence of the fact that this is a difficult area in which legislation which will meet the problems which have arisen is hard to produce. But we have produced an endless stream of legislation and I believe that any person who is interested in this field and who is familiar with the practitioners in this field would know that the flow of tax evasion has been reduced significantly if not totally stopped.

The point has been made in the debate that the instruments which are now being used to attack the Attorney-General and the Treasurer, the reports which have been brought out by McCabe-Lafranchi and by the Costigan Royal Commission are instruments which are available to government, to the public and to the Opposition only because of the initiative either of this Government or of a Liberal Government in Victoria. In other words, those very inquiries are part of a pattern of attention to this area of government which gives the lie to the claim in this motion that the Government has failed to come to grips with this area. I believe that the record of the Government in this field is very good. I believe the results are beginning to show and they showed up this year in the fact that no allowance was required to be made in the Budget figuring the loss to revenue because of tax avoidance.

There is one other item with which I wish to deal now. I know that after the dinner suspension we wish to move to the Budget debate. I refer to the action which has been taken since the report of the Costigan Royal Commission was made available to the Government. It is quite clear that that report exposed to the Government facts of which it had not previously been aware, some facts which had been in the knowledge of some relatively junior officers in the Attorney-General 's Department but not the Attorney-General himself or of more senior officers in the Department. I point to the statement which was put down yesterday by the Attorney-General in which he acknowledged that the findings must be taken seriously and that the matter of guilt or innocence of people who are said to be guilty of criminal matters is something to be determined by the courts.

He has set out in his statement the action which has been taken concerning the matters raised in that report. Attention has been given, as a matter of priority , to the prosecution of offences associated with bottom-of-the-harbour tax evasion schemes which are referred to in volume 1 of the report. In June of this year-that is, before receipt of the report-the Attorney-General and the Treasurer took steps to obtain advice from the Solicitor-General in regard to the availability of prosecution action in the particular case dealt with in chapter 3 of volume 1, the case which has received so much attention in debate today. The Solicitor-General has given an opinion saying that remedies are open, and advice was sought from senior counsel in June on possible criminal proceedings in relation to a major promoter in Sydney, with a final opinion being expected shortly.

The Crown Solicitor has sent an officer from his central office to work in association with the Taxation Office with respect to the case referred to in chapter 3 of the report. More generally, it has been decided to appoint a special prosecutor to concentrate special effort on action with a view to prosecution of persons who are directly involved in the promotion and execution of bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. The special prosecutor is to be assisted by a task force of lawyers, taxation officers and police.

I believe that the action taken by the Attorney-General is the action of a man who is determined to do his duty as Attorney-General. It is consistent with the actions of the Attorney-General over the whole period that I have known him. Indeed, there is a certain irony that the Attorney-General and the Treasurer should be the subject of complaint in this matter. I know of no ministers who have more assiduously devoted themselves to their duties, nor more successfully performed them. The fact that there are significant difficulties in the tax area the knowledge of which is not new is something we should all be prepared to face up to, to ensure that the laws are adequate, that the administration is adequate , and that we achieve the result which I believe is the one commonly desired in this chamber, namely, the proper collection of the taxes which are due to enable us to conduct the proper programs of government.

On behalf of the Government I reject the suggestion that it should be censured in the way put forward this afternoon by the Opposition. I support the actions of the Attorney-General and the Treasurer in the administration of their departments. I ask all honourable senators to support them in the same way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's response to this censure motion has been a mixture of abdication of responsibility, false assertion and false analogy. Two Government speakers used the defence, essentially, that tax evasion of this type started under the Whitlam Government, the Whitlam Government did not do anything about it, and therefore it is all right for the Fraser Government to do nothing about it. Even if that were true it does not, of course, exonerate the present Government. Senator Sir John Carrick asserted that Mr Costigan had said that the 1980 amendments to the Taxation Act had solved the problem. I quote from paragraph 3.89 of the report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Ship Painters and Dockers, in which the Royal Commissioner said:

SPEECH.PARA: The conduct to which they-
That is the 1980 amendments-
are directed is conduct which was already criminal.

What Mr Costigan said was that the 1980 amendments, upon which the Government has hung most of its defence, were irrelevant. The reason they were irrelevant, Costigan said, was that all laws which are not enforced are irrelevant. The Government was not enforcing the law as it existed prior to 1980 and therefore there was no need for any amendments. The problem was not in the inadequacies of the law but in the inadequacy of government will to enforce the law that existed . Senator Sir John Carrick seemed to say that the Government was not as bad as the painters and dockers. I guess it is not. However, the painters and dockers are not the subject of this censure motion, nor are they in government. I note in passing, with regard to Senator Harradine's comment about the murders for which the painters and dockers are responsible, that the previous Victorian Liberal Government just went through an election campaign in which it campaigned very heavily on the subject of no gun laws at all for Victoria. There seems to be a certain inconsistency. Senator Chaney cited the false analogy of the possibility of a major case of fraud within his Department where somebody had been making multiple fraudulent claims on social security benefits. That, of course, is not a legitimate analogy. It would have been if senior officers in Senator Chaney's Department were aware of such a fraud and did nothing about it, which is exactly what happened in this case.

Last Sunday the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) denounced tax evaders as ' recipients of stolen money'. Yesterday Senator Durack announced the formation of a crimes commission to prosecute tax evaders. So this Government, which for seven years has presided permissively over a multi-billion dollar tax cheating orgy, has now donned, at least in public, a mask of respectability. With this sort of stunt and rhetoric it hopes to erase the public's memory of the shocking disclosures by Costigan, by McCabe-Lafranchi, and by others of negligence and tax evasion at the highest levels of the Liberal Party. Australia does not need stunts. What it needs is a government with a will to flush the crooks out of their sanctuary in the Liberal Party and into the gaols where they belong.

For nearly seven years this Government has presided over a bureaucracy-for which, I stress, the Government is responsible-which sat on and covered up advice to prosecute and the evidence to support such prosecutions. For two and a half years from May 1978 the Treasurer sat, inert as a stuffed bullfrog, on advice from the Taxation Office which disclosed massive tax evasion. He has admitted that. His excuse for that gross negligence was that 'public attitudes to tax evasion were only in their formative stages'. In other words, the public was not angry enough. It was his duty to protect the public revenue. On his own admission, he knew for at least two and a half years, in this case alone, that there was serious leakage of the public revenue, and he did nothing. He is still Treasurer. That in itself is sufficient reason for censure of this Government. The Government was ultimately stung into forecasting limited and very belated action against tax cheats by the disclosures of McCabe-Lafranchi. It was moved not by moral outrage but by fear of electoral retribution, and by fear of that alone.

While the Government wages a pious but phoney war against the tax cheats, some of the most spectacular tax cheats continue to occupy positions of power in the Liberal Party and in public life. For example, the Perth Liberal Party bagman, Denis Horgan, personally evaded $750,000 tax in just one deal. He is one of the recipients of stolen money, a practice which the Prime Minister denounced on Sunday. This Denis Horgan is still a director of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, appointed by the Treasurer and retained by the Treasurer. As well as being a tax dodger, a tax cheat, as Managing Director of Treamog Ltd he set up the small shareholders to be fleeced by the Myer interests . Is that the level of directorial diligence and integrity which the Treasurer wants in a director of the AIDC? If it is, I would certainly advise small investors not to put any money into it. Denis Horgan is still a Commissioner of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, and I invite the ABC to report that fact instead of censoring it from the news, as it has done in the past. He still occupies five other sinecures. On 27 June the Treasurer, Mr Howard, excused his failure to take action under the Crimes Act against tax evasion with pusillanimous legal waffle about the problems of securing evidence of conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth. He does not need evidence of conspiracy to sack Denis Horgan. All he needs is guts. Asked last week about the sacking of Denis Horgan, he replied: 'Just because a man is named in a report doesn't mean he is guilty'.

Denis Horgan's name was not just mentioned in a report. He was identified as a participant, as managing director of a company which got involved in a tax evasion transaction as a result of which $1.7m of a current year tax liability was evaded. That evidence and Corporate Affairs Office documents in Perth record that Denis Horgan personally evaded three-quarters of a million dollars. The Treasurer's attitude in the face not of a mention of someone in a report but evidence to document the accuracy of what I have just said, seems to be: If Denis Horgan is not actually in gaol he is fit to remain a director of the AIDC. Perhaps Mr Howard is puzzled by the Prime Minister's sudden antipathy to people who are recipients of stolen money and wonders what has happened since 19 September 1980 to change the Prime Minister's mind. What has been said of Mr Howard, of course, applies to all other Ministers who appointed and retain Horgan in government sinecures.

Turning to Senator Durack, I leave aside at least for now the detailed facts presented in the Costigan report and reported on competently and in some detail by previous speakers on the Opposition side. I note, however, that the negligence which was documented in that report continues still. The report was received by the Government on 27 July. At midday last Wednesday, three weeks after the report was received, the Attorney-General got around to standing down O'Sullivan and Bercove in Perth. For three weeks at least those two officers whom the Attorney-General knew to have been shown to be grossly negligent if not worse-one, indeed, was described as 'a dishonest man'-were given the run of the files of the Solicitor-General's office in Perth and for that Senator Durack is entirely and inarguably responsible. How do we know that they did not shred the files in that three-week period when Senator Durack knew what the Costigan report had shown about them but took no action? I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
