PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 August, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Senate take note of the papers.
Motion (by Senator Sir John Carrick) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Button (the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate) speaking without limitation of time when speaking to the Motion that the Senate take note of the Budget Papers 1982-83.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) for enabling me to speak without limitation of time. It seems strange to say this at the end of a week since the Budget was brought down but this Budget is a sort of end of the road Budget. It is the end of the road for a government which has lived on rhetoric of one kind or another varying, of course, with each election over the last seven years-seven lean years for the people of Australia. Now in this Budget, the Government is scraping the bottom of the barrel for new and suitable rhetoric, having failed to find any in the economic field because everybody is waking up to the emptiness of that rhetoric. It is thrashing around in other areas of mischief-making; hence, the numerous attempts in the past week to introduce legislation into this Parliament which are intended to divide the political opposition, particularly in the Senate and elsewhere, as though the economy were something about which the Government was not even particularly concerned. I think a measure of the Government's desperation is the lack of priority it gives to economic issues.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth while looking at this Budget in the context of the previous Budgets. I remember being told in 1975 and 1977 that Budgets were about good housekeeping on behalf of the people of Australia, for whom the Government supposedly brings down Budgets. Let us look at the record in terms of the budgetary performances of the Fraser Government. It was said in 1977 that the election issue was tax cuts and tax indexation. Still dining out lavishly on the perceived sins of the Whitlam Government, about which we still get lectures even today from Senator Sir John Carrick-one wonders whether, if he were here till the year 2000, he would still be playing the same old tune-the Fraser Government said that the essence of the 1977 election campaign was that tax indexation was necessary to keep governments honest. It did not keep itself very honest for very long. Having achieved the objective of winning the 1977 election, the Government felt quite free to be dishonest. In July 1978, just seven months after the election and 12 months after the much vaunted introduction of full indexation of taxation, the Government reduced that to half indexation. It decided to be half honest, not fully honest. In addition to that, it discounted the consumer price index of 13.9 per cent by 3.3 per cent, thus excluding the combined effects of indirect taxes and the health insurance levy. How these extra tax imposts can fail to be regarded as additions to the cost of living quite escapes me and I am sure the Australian people who have to pay them.

A few months later in November 1978, 11 months after the election, the Fraser Government raised the marginal tax rate within each bracket by adding an extra temporary surcharge of 2.57c to each of the rates. That was a fundamental lesson in electoral dishonesty-a lesson which should be borne in mind by anyone who thinks that the income tax relaxations in this Budget will endure if this Government is re-elected. This Government cannot be trusted on questions of taxation policy.

In the 1977 context we also had the term 'rubbery' introduced in connection with Government figures by the inestimable Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch). That was his way of saying that some of the hype associated with the Budget came from the Prime Minister's Department and not from the Treasury. Even in this Budget the Government's arithmetic is suspect. The Budget Papers, for example, forecast rising unemployment perhaps as high as nine per cent. Yet, the average number of people receiving unemployment benefits is estimated in the Budget at 395,000 for the year. In July of this year, the first month of the year in which the average of 395,000 was struck, there were 405,000 people registered as unemployment beneficiaries.

No tax indexation was applied in 1979-80, a safe mid-year term between elections, but partial indexation was reintroduced in July 1980 with an election due in the latter half of that year. The tax brackets were increased by 3.8 per cent compared with the consumer price index increase of 9.7 per cent for that year. So again, the illusion of getting something back was created, while in fact the reform made up slightly only one-third of the CPI increase. But in that election year something else had to be drummed up, so the resources boom was summoned up from the deep. Vast and largely illusory sums were trumpeted. In 1980 before the election, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said:
Tens of thousands of new jobs will be generated.

The millenium was to arrive via a mining investment led recovery. New infrastructure was to be created. All was to be well. The country was going to take off again. Of course, the objective of all that was to push into the background the rising unemployment, the lack of action on jobs for school leavers, the continued high inflation and the basic underlying problems of the Australian economy. It was all cosmetic and it only worked by a squeak. In Fraser Government terms it was a successful policy because success is measured by the ability to win enough people over at election time. But again, after the election came the truth. There was some development in mining, of course, most of which was on the slipway long before and had little to do with the election or the policies of this Government. But the boom, the South Sea bubble bit, evaporated. After all, it had to subside. It would not have done to keep expectations up. They had to be lowered and the whole thing decently buried. The Government, for its own reasons, deflated its own boom. The mining industry helped a little but, for reasons of truthfulness, it was, I suspect, a little embarrassed about the whole process.

On 29 April 1981, after that election, the Government announced the future abolition of tax indexation. Mr Howard said that discretionary adjustments to taxation scales and allowances were preferable to tax indexation. What he really meant was that the Government had finally come to the conclusion that a great number of people did not understand tax indexation and, therefore, it was not a good election gimmick. The catch-cry 'Keep governments honest' had been exhausted because this Government had been so manifestly dishonest itself. Instead of tax indexation there was talk of discretionary adjustments to tax scales. The reason, no doubt, was that they could be introduced just before an election and the Government could make up for lost revenue in other ways or by changing the tax scales again after an election. The point I am making is that no one who looks at this Budget for the year 1982 and at its cynically manipulative tax cuts should forget that had the Government kept its simple promise of tax indexation taxpayers in this country would have benefited this year by $1,500m. Of course, that has not happened. I do not want to quote Professor Russell Mathews excessively but I do want to quote what he said about that and the administration of the tax system under this Government. He said:

. . . the Australian taxation and social welfare system, far from contributing to greater equality in the distribution of incomes and wealth, has become a major instrument for redistributing incomes from the poor to the rich and from wage and salary earners to other income recipients, as well as a major cause of the budgetary problems of all Australian governments and a source of growing social, business and economic instability.

We have been told by the master of economic theory, the landlord of Nareen, that there are two sides to a Budget. He says that a Budget involves good housekeeping; so there is a receipts side, the revenue side, and an expenditure side. If one takes not my words but the words of Professor Mathews, the receipts side is absolutely crucial to the heart of the economic management for this country. It is absolutely crucial in that sense and in the sense that it is at the heart of the issue of any social justice or equity. It is absolutely crucial in both those senses. According to Professor Mathews, the receipts side is in a mess. Professor Mathews did not have the advantage of the latest evidence, which was debated in the Senate this afternoon.

The backdrop to this Government's Budget is its record of broken promises. It has no credibility on the question of the revenue side of the Budget and not much on the expenditue side either; but I will come to that in a minute. It is only in the context of this Government's credibility, or lack of it, that this Budget can be understood. The whole history of this Government has been one of economic failure. Its slogan was 'turn on the lights'. Liberal politicians might whisper that quietly to their children in 1982 but there is no cry of 'turn on the lights' any more because seven years of disastrous economic management have rendered that slogan abortive.

This Government has had a chronic failure to bring about a recovery in the economy and a chronic failure to provide jobs for Australians. But at election time they have been a little more successful. We are now in 1982. The Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and his fellow jugglers such as Mr Eggleton, Mr Anthony, Mr Howard and whosoever happens to be in the reigning guru group in this Government sit down and say: 'What will we do this time in 1982?' The options are fewer; they have receded. A lot of whistles have been blown. Another mining boom is just not on; it cannot be reinvented at this stage. The situation is pretty desperate. There is widespread talk of recession. So it is back again to tax cuts. But this time there is to be a different way of going back on the income tax cuts and that is by the imposition of indirect taxes. So all the recoveries that have been projected in various Budgets of this Government in the past are now reduced to the sordid possibility of a tax evasion led recovery which is the only thing the Government has to fall back on at this point.

So what we have now is the introduction of increasing indirect taxes preceded by a campaign on the necessity to broaden the tax base, something which in principle I do not think there is any fundamental quarrel about; perhaps there is quarrel about the way in which it is done. Of course, those people I referred to a minute ago think that this may work. But at present they want to try a few sideshows as well in the hope that it will all blow away; hence the number of pieces of legislation and resolutions that have been introduced which have no relevance to the great matters of managing the economy of this country. It is considerations such as those-not good economic management, not proper government , nor any other responsible motive-that activate this Government because in the meantime the real problems continue.

From 1975 to 1980 income per head in Australia grew by 1.2 per cent per year while in the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as a whole it grew by 2.7 per cent-more than twice as fast as in Australia. Australia slipped from being fifth in 1950 in the income per head table among Western countries to being sixteenth in 1979. We slipped from fifth to sixteenth. By 1979 we were exceeded by Switzerland, Sweden, Denmark, Germany, Belgium, Norway, United States of America, Netherlands, France and Canada. Over the period 1970 to 1979 growth rates in Australia were lower than those in nine of the leading countries of South East Asia. Again, in the period from 1950 to 1973 our growth was about 20 per cent lower than the OECD average. The cumulative effect of that over 23 years of Liberal governments is very great indeed in terms of a country going down the hit parade. In that period we had a 20 per cent lower growth rate than the OECD average. What is the significance of that in a debate about the Budget of the Fraser Government in 1982? It is simply this: For 30 out of the last 33 years this sort of thing has gone on under Liberal-National Country Party governments-governments like Mr Fraser's Government-which are more interested in gimmickry and rhetoric than real government. They cannot escape responsibility for this. Indeed, the 23 years to which I refer correspond exactly with the Menzies, Gorton, McMahon and Fraser years.

This Government and this Budget is in that inglorious tradition, riding on mindless ideology, while the real problems run on. It purports to be a free enterprise government but, if so, it is not a good free enterprise government because the enterprises which should have made us world leaders, with the vast resources which this country has, have not prospered under this Government and have not prospered under Liberal governments in the past 30 years out of the 33 in which they have governed. The situation is similar with manufacturing industry. Australian manufacturing industry is sick. It passed its peak of employment in 1965 and has been going downhill ever since. In 1965, 28 per cent of the Australian work force was employed in manufacturing industry. It is now down to something of the order of 19 per cent. In only two years, 1973 and 1974, did that figure flutter up for a brief period.

Manufacturing industry is in the doldrums and the seven years of Fraser Government have done nothing to pull it out of the doldrums. There has been no investment led recovery-not even a jawboning led recovery, despite the Prime Minister's best efforts. There are real long term problems and the Budget Papers admit failure in relation to all of these problems. This is a no growth Budget. This Budget is an admission that the Government has no idea what to do next. It has surrendered control over the economy and it represents a turn-round in economic policy.

What the Government should have been doing in this Budget was to set a long term foundation for growth. It would have been a bit late. The Government should have done that in its first Budget in 1976 when it was elected with the biggest majority in Australian history. That was the time to lay the foundation for long term economic growth in Australia. But none of the Budgets to which I have referred have addressed themselves to that question. What is needed is a set of policies to get the economy back on the path of recovery, not the cynical ad hoc policies represented by this Budget. The Budget itself speaks of the Government' s failure. I refer now to some of the forecasts contained in it. First, there is to be a contraction in the building industry. We are promised that in the Budget Papers. Second, there is to be a decline in business investment. Third, there will be no growth at all in the non-farm sector of the economy. Fourth, inflation will increase to 11 per cent. Fifth, there will be continued high interest rates. Sixth, there will be no growth in employment. Seventh, there will be a massive rise in unemployment. These are not my predictions; they are contained in the Budget Papers.

The Government's answer to all of this is again to try to lay the blame elsewhere. A variety of scapegoats can always be invented by this Government to account for its own inefficiencies and ineptitude. For example, wage demands are currently a favourite scapegoat. I have no doubt that, in the current economic climate, it is quite true to say that many employers cannot meet higher wage demands. At the same time, it is not always so easy to blame unions for trying to maintain their real standards of living. They are not fooled by such underhandedness as the Government has shown, for instance by omitting from consumer price index figures the effect of indirect taxes-taxes which bear on the level of income of every family. A simplistic reaction to our situation is to blame high wages, to say that they make this country uncompetitive. It would be interesting-I note that no one in the Government has ever attempted it-to work out how low wages would have to be in Australia to make this country actually competitive with some of the countries that are used for comparison. Of course, the real culprit is lack of growth of the Australian economy because, by cutting back wages, the Government is also cutting back consumer spending- indirect taxes have the same effect and thus accentuating the downward spiral.

Part of the reason why the Government blames the excessive wage demands is that it has itself no wages policy. There are plenty of authorities for that proposition. I suppose that the closest to the heart of the Prime Minister would be the statement by Mr Andrew Peacock, the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Industrial Relations, who has said quite explicitly that the Fraser Government has no wages policy. What his country needs is more than anything else a sound approach to prices and incomes, based on some notion of social equity. The Labor Party's prices and incomes policy would take that path, as have all other countries of the OECD with successful or relatively successful economies in the early 1980s. That course is rejected by the present Government on what one can only presume to be ideological grounds.

Growth in the Australian economy would allow wages and spending to be maintained or increased and would also allow for business profitability. Yet after seven years we find in the Budget Papers, as recorded at page 137 of Hansard of 17 August 1982, the following statement:
. . . in 1981-82, the Australian economy moved into a period of low growth and high inflation . . . .
As if that was some dramatic development which had not been taking place for years. The statement continued:
The factors giving rise to that development persist and the outlook for 1982-83 therefore contains little to suggest improvement.

Such is the state to which we have come after seven years of this Government's administration. We have witnessed a series of electoral tricks, but the underlying problems of Australia remain untackled in this Budget, as in all other Budgets of this Government, though the Budget is the basic instrument of economic policy.

In planning for a no-growth economy, the Government is saying that every Australian who is out of a job will just have to get used to it. It is saying by way of comfort to the unemployed: 'Do not worry. You will soon be joined by many others.' The Government has failed to discharge its fundamental responsibility to provide for the Australian people. Apparently it lives on some sort of blind faith that if we can cut back everything enough, private investment will take over and we will have a recovery. It is not a government that should talk about recoveries. It has done so for too long, yet there have been no significant recoveries with any staying power at all. Only now, after having created the mess in which this country finds itself, does the Government show any signs of wavering in relation to those matters. Its policy has produced no positive results, rather an enormous negative effect at an equally enormous economic social cost. That social cost is before the Government's eyes in the form of lengthening dole queues, increasing poverty and falling living standards. No one denies that the increases provided in the Budget in respect of some social welfare benefits are necessary and very welcome. Nobody could deny that at all. But it should never be forgotten that they are not a proper substitute for prosperity, and in this regard the Government has failed. What they represent is a government saying: 'We can no longer manage this economy so we will try at least to look good by giving you increases to disguise our incompetence in economic management'.

Unemployment now runs at record levels and is likely to reach 9 per cent before the end of this year. That is just a figure but it represents an increase of 130 ,000 in the number of people who are out of work. That is not a mere statistic; it represents people. This is masked by a decline in the work force participation rate. Since September 1980 there has been a continuous decline in that rate from a figure of 61.6 per cent to 60.7 per cent at present. In other words, no longer are people bothering to look for jobs. That has become pointless because it is recognised that the jobs are not there. Even the Budget Papers admit it. At page 135 of Hansard of 17 August 1982, the following statement appears:
It follows that there is unlikely to be any growth in employment in 1982-83.

That is, no growth of employment, not withstanding that in excess of 100,000 people will come onto the labour market after the schools close at the end of the year. So, despite the rhetoric of seven years concerning fighting inflation first, we still have an enormous unemployment problem, one that is becoming worse while inflation continues largely unabated. The consumer price index is expected to rise by about 10.75 per cent during 1982-83-a figure which does not take account of the impact of indirect taxes. That figure is marginally greater than the 10.4 per cent rise experienced in 1982-83. The Budget Papers themselves predict:
Indirect taxes contained in the Budget will increase domestic prices, probably adding directly around 1 per cent to the consumer price index . . .

One of the most disreputable parts of the rhetoric of the Howard-Fraser Budget- or I guess one should call it the Fraser-Howard Budget this year-is its cynical insistence that it is a Budget for Australian families. The Treasurer has wheeled out the family in some sort of heart-on-the-sleeve fashion as though the Government had ever had any real concern for ordinary Australians. If it had it would have listened with a little greater diligence to what the Labor Opposition had been saying for four years now about the plight of Australian families. Since 1978, the Labor Party in this place has been drawing attention to the decline in the living standard of the average Australian family. For four years that call, which is supported by massive evidence, has gone unheeded by the Government. Yet at this time, when the country is in its greatest plight in regard to sense of direction, economic management and a government prepared to deal with basic realities of the economy, some genuine concessions have been made for the first time to those who have suffered as a result of declining living standards. Since 1975-76 living standards in this country have continually fallen. Australian families are $40 a week worse off. The indirect tax rises and the acknowledged high rate of inflation in this Budget will destroy any marginal gains to families, or anyone else, obtained through small income tax cuts.

Needless to say, the Government skips over the sneakier facts of other increased charges in the Budget. The classic illustration is the increase in telephone charges. The big losers out of the rise in telephone charges will be people in rural Australia, the Government's taken-for-granted supporters. People in rural Australia are obliged to make short distance subscriber trunk dialling calls, which are to rise by between 4c and 7c a call. The Budget contains a number of other impositions on people living in non-metropolitan Australia. The new petrol tax and the reduction of the freight cost subsidy will add 1.5c a litre to country petrol prices. The abolition of the exemption from excise duty on diesel fuel for off-road use will mean despite the rebates, a net cost of $ 176m will be borne by a wide range of rural industries. The Budget is another example of how this Government punishes country people by taking them for granted.

So despite the promises and the rhetoric, inflation, rising interest rates and lack of growth have affected the economy of this country as a whole since 1976. The Budget document speaks with a massive silence about any possible solution to those problems. Inequities and inequalities within this society have been magnified by this Government. The personal income tax system has placed a greater relative tax burden on lower and middle income earners. On the other hand, those on higher incomes of around $30,000 or more are now experiencing a lower average tax rate. For example, a single person earning $10,700, in 1980-81 figures, throughout the six years to 1981-82 experienced a rise of 21 per cent in the proportion of income paid as tax. For a person on the average wage the proportion increased by about 11 per cent. On the other hand, the rate for a person earning $32,000 remained the same. For higher incomes still, the rate actually fell.

Lest it be put about that this is a government with concern for families, it should be pointed out that that families too, if in the lower or middle income brackets, did not escape. A taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children, earning average wages, recorded a 73 per cent increase in the proportion of income paid in tax. By contrast, a person in the same family situation but earning $32,000 per annum saw an increase of only 3 per cent in the same period. The real policy of this Government is to transfer money to the better off, whether by Government action, by Government fiat by explicit policy or by ignoring tax evation. Perhaps it does this because of prejudice and general Liberal Party interest group pressures. But above that, if it has an economic policy it is just a hope that investment of that money will lead a recovery.

If anyone doubts its general party philosophy, as distinct from the cant of its members' speeches at election time, that person should look at what is happening inside the Liberal Party over tax evasion. From sheer embarrassment the Government has had to try to do something, after a little prodding from the Victorian Premier and others. What was going on was becoming just too obvious. Then reality within the party surpassed the real nature of much of the party itself. It all looked a bit serious, a bit too close to the bone, so now we have a very revealing debate within the Liberal Party about the issue of retrospectivity-even to the extent of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party coming out openly against it. That may be a technical matter, but of course it is a matter which indicates deep-seated division of views about all sorts of issues involving social equity and social morality in this country.

Because the majority of people in society are not well off the Liberals obviously cannot declare their real policy, so they have to think up excuses which disguise it, such as what they would do on tax indexation, as they did prior to previous elections, and like the resources boom which, prior to the election of 1980, they said would take place. There is no reason to believe that this Government has changed its colours in any way on these fundamental issues. The Budget continues the basic policy. All that has changed is the thinking up of a new public presentation. The issue is one of credibility. It is the issue over this Budget and over this Government, and will be the issue in the next election.

It is noteworthy that the newspaper reaction to the Budget played up the election gimmickry of it all. Of course this has happened before; election gimmickry in a Budget before an election is nothing new. People are being offered indirect taxes now with some income tax relief in the future, and so on. But, as the Australian Financial Review put it, 'It is no longer possible to deliver three-card tricks and not have them seen for what they are.' The Financial Review was talking about this Budget, and this Government's time is running out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has just heard a typical repetition of the remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, in the House of Representatives last night which, again, in truly panic-ridden and negative fashion, draws upon a bankrupt series of propositions which obviously do not stand in the public gaze. I hope a little later during my speech to attend to some of the points mentioned by Senator Button, but first of all I turn to some of the fundamental issues which he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: First and foremost Senator Button drew attention to the fact that growth rates in Australia in the last few years have been somewhat lower than those of our South East Asian neighbours. There is absolutely no argument about that, but the reasons that has occurred are an excessive wage push by the trade union movement and a lack of competitiveness of Australian industries which has developed in recent times. That is a very significant point which deserves repetition. But, of course, it underscores the fundamental premise of this Budget at this time. Senator Button has recognised very well, without saying so, the great truths which are written into this Budget-that it is aimed at assisting those most in need and, at the same time, assisting to restrain wage growth. Those things obviously have been recognised-I am sure unconsciously in Senator Button's case- as the fundamental truths behind this Budget. I will address myself to those issues a little later.

As for gimmickry, I am surprised to hear a member of the Australian Labor Party argue that assistance of the order being provided in this Budget for families can somehow be labelled as gimmickry. If any issue has been running around the community over the last year or so it has been issue of the difficulties of families meeting mortgage repayments due to rising interest rates and the problems of increased taxation. Since time immemorial the Opposition in this place has represented those problems as the fundamental issues which concern Australians. Yet when the Government addresses itself to those problems it is criticised by the Opposition on the ground that it is some kind of electorial gimmickry, a gerrymander or an attempt to get the electorate ready for an election. That seems to me to be so recognisably hypocritical that it does not even deserve comment, but it needs to be raised in this place in order to draw people's attention to the kind of cant that comes from the Opposition when it has nothing else to talk about. As I have said, the Opposition recognises the strengths of this Budget, and has supported it here tonight in the remarks of Senator Button.

If anyone was listening last night to Mr Hayden's remarks and expecting some kind of reasoned, rational criticism of the Budget, he would have been terribly disappointed. Furthermore, if he was looking for some kind of alternative economic program, he would have been even more disappointed. All we got from Mr Hayden was that over-rated, exaggerated stream of invective and unsubstantiated criticism which really stood up to no kind of criticism itself.

Let us look at a couple of the points. These things have been reiterated tonight by Senator Button. Senator Button mentioned, for instance, that unemployment would rise by 130,000 this year. What then is the basis of his figuring? This figure is gaining some currency around the community by virtue of the Labor Party reiterating a point which it is unable to substantiate in any way. It has criticised the way in which the Government has calculated the amount of unemployment benefit that will be paid, yet those figures rely upon expert Treasury opinion and expert Treasury calculations. Yet the Labor Party is prepared to come into this place knowing that it is free from criticism and spout out numbers off the top of the head which indicate what the level of unemployment might be this year. It has no expert advice, or if it has, it is not prepared to tell us what that advice is. Labor senators are not prepared to tell us who did the calculations. As I read the Bulletin today, perhaps they come from the gentleman in Mr Willis's office who is under so much strain at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, what a load of rubbish.

—Perhaps it is, but I am glad to hear that Senator Coleman is prepared to deny it. Let us proceed to one or two other matters which are of greater concern to Australians, and are the issues in this Budget. Without being terribly downcast by the proposition of the world recession which is about us, we have to develop a realism and sense of prudence based on what we expect to be international developments in the next year. Clearly there are problems overseas . We know that the international recession is deepening. We know that Australia' s overseas markets have shrunk; we see that every month from the export and import figures. We have seen unemployment rising. We see that inflation is far too high, higher than we accept. We know that interest rates are still unacceptably high. Yet the reasons why this is so and the reasons why these things are problems for us are clearly issues that we have to take into account in designing any Budget. It is not to be downcast at those propositions. It is indelibly clear that we need to be able to have clearly in our minds those factors when designing a Budget that will stimulate development in the longer run in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, we have a problem in competitiveness. Over the last few years we have seen a gradual decline in the ability of Australian industry to sell on world markets. Never could that be truer than in a situation in which we have a market that is shrinking on the world sceen in the way in which it is. Clearly that is as a result of excessive wage demands and developments that have occurred on the world scene. That is the kind of proposition to which the Budget addresses itself. It clearly recognises the fundamental problems associated with this difficulty of our lack of competitiveness on world markets. Clearly it offers a means by which that question can be addressed. It offers an opportunity for there to be a trade-off between tax cuts and benefits for families in such a way as can be taken into account in settling wage claims in the future.

If one is to have regard to those particular elements, one sees that these changes that have been occurring recently are very significant. To quote a particular comment of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) during his speech, after taking into account the benefits of the housing loan interest rebate, the family allowance increases-by the way, not introduced by the Labor Government but by this Government-and the family income supplement, and the effect of indirect tax increases, we find that a family on, say, $300 a week will benefit to the net extent of $17.76 a week. That is a very significant change in the net disposable income of families and clearly it is a very significant incentive for workers to take into account in any future wage claims. That kind of restraint which can be exercised by unions and by wage earners will be fundamental to the regaining of a degree of competitiveness in world markets for Australian industry. It is somthing which this Government is directly addressing and is strongly supporting in this Budget.

Looking at a family that is in less fortunate circumstances and perhaps has an income of only $180 a week, one finds that the net effect and net benefit to that family, after taking into account the new initiative of family income supplement, will be $30.10 more than the family would have had before the Budget . That means a change in its disposable income of about 17.5 per cent. That is a very significant change, and it clearly shows that the Budget is not only attempting to address itself to the fundamental problems of wage restraint but also is addressing itself to those on the lowest incomes who are in the greatest need. That is the other thrust of the Budget, to which I now turn.

Let us consider in some detail how the Government will be addressing itself to the issue of need. As to family allowances, we note that the rate for first and second children will be up by 50 per cent from November. The cost of that to the Government will be about $250m in this financial year. That, however, is not the major consideration. The major consideration is that there will be two million Australian families benefiting from that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —If they believe you, of course; if you deliver.

—They will believe us, no doubt, when the benefits are flowing to them. Those will be starting in November, as Senator Button acknowledges. That point must be fundamental to his understanding of the matter; but I find the point he seeks to make difficult to understand. The other special benefit in this whole area of relief for families was mentioned earlier-the family income supplement. That will assist families to a very considerable degree, and it is very important.
—What is the total cost in one year?
—The total cost of all these benefits in the family allowance area is $375m.
—No, of the supplement.

—I do not have that figure before me. The question and problems of unemployed youth, about which we hear a great deal in this place, are at present of very considerable concern. It is acknowledged that this has been so for some time. Expenditure on work experience during 1982-83 will rise to $74m. That will allow for 74,000 new work experience placements and increases of up to 36 per cent in the rate of subsidy to employers. In addition, the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training expenditure will rise to $84m, which will enable employers to receive assistance in respect of some 111,000 apprentices this year. That compares with the figure of 99,000 for last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to some of the very real problems of taxation which have been spoken of in this place by the Opposition and which are clearly areas of great concern within the community. A greater degree of assistance has been offered to low income families by the raising of the tax free threshold from $4,195 to $4,595.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is only if they are working.
—It affects about 300,000 pensioners and people on low incomes, who would otherwise have been paying tax but will not now do so. Is the honourable senator arguing that they should pay tax?
—No, I am not.

—It is a very strange point for him to make. In addition, the standard rate of tax will be reduced from 32 per cent to 30 per cent. Those who suffer problems by virtue of being denied the incentive to work overtime because they have reached the top of the 32 per cent scale will now find that they can earn up to $19,500 a year before having the tax rate of 46 per cent applied to them. At the same time, workers in this area will benefit from the tax free threshold being lifted to $4,595. What this means is that about 75 per cent of all Australian taxpayers will be on the new or lower standard rate of tax from 1 November.
—That is great! They no longer have to pay 46c in the last dollar. What a thing to be proud of.

—Senator Chipp has deliberately misrepresented the point I am making. I am talking about those people whose incomes range up to the point at which 46 per cent applies. Additionally, the Treasurer announced in March that there would be a scheme to help first home buyers. That has been discussed in this place for some months. This benefit represents a clear advantage to young couples and those seeking their first home. In addition, the Budget has brought in a new range of benefits for all taxpayers. People paying off a housing loan mortgage will be entitled to a rebate on the amount of interest they pay on the loan over and above 10 per cent up to a total limit of $60,000. Clearly that is a benefit aimed at assisting those who are most in need. To those families who are short of a deposit and are forced into borrowing the greatest amount of money, possibly at higher rates of interest than might otherwise apply, those in greatest need, this scheme represents a very significant advantage. The benefit that will apply for a family on average weekly earnings will be in the order of $5.05. This figure will be significantly higher in other groups of need.

SPEECH.PARA: In repatriation benefits for veterans, my area of responsibility, we have seen some very significant changes. I believe they will address many very long term needs of veterans, particularly as they grow older. Firstly, the Government will be undertaking major new works in two repatriation hospitals-one in Perth and one in Adelaide. We will be updating facilities and improving operating theatres and wards. Secondly, the Government will be undertaking the reopening of five wards in repatriation hospitals across Australia. They will be specifically nominated for veterans. This will require the creation of 115 nursing positions and 175 trainee positions within the hospital system across Australia. That is a very significant benefit. I am sure that it will contribute greatly to the reservoir of nursing and medical skills available in the community.

Probably the most significant benefit which has flowed from the Budget for veterans concerns a decision to disregard to the extent of 100 per cent-in other words, totally-the amount of a person's disability compensation in assessing eligibility for the service pension and fringe benefits. I believe that is a most welcome change in the approach of governments over the past few years. It follows the principles that have been established by this Government since 1980 in gradually relieving that situation. Furthmore, there has been an extension of free medical and hospital treatment to service pensioners who receive a disability pension of not less than 50 per cent. This benefit will provide treatment and care mainly for World War II veterans, people who are growing older as time goes by. I am sure that their minds will be eased to a great extent as they seek medical help and as the need for that help increases.

Other benefits based on the rate of inflation will be available to those in greatest need. I think of the most severely disabled veterans, those who need special care and aids from the Department to enable them to go about their normal lives. In that way this Government is contributing very worthily to those who are in greatest need. Of course, that is one of the fundamental questions to which this Budget addresses itself. It is clear that my area of repatriation is like a microcosm of the whole approach to the Government's Budget. It is seeking to help those who are the most disabled, those who are the most handicapped, those who face the greatest problems in the community and those who require the sorts of things which government can deliver.

I said earlier that nobody can deny the effects on Australia of the world recession or the fact that Australia's world markets have shrunk. It would seem axiomatic that Australian industry should be doing everything in its power to become more competitive in the international market. It is clear-even the Opposition, in its own way, has acknowledged this-that excessive growth in wages has undermined Australian competitiveness and has resulted in Australians pricing themselves and their jobs out of the market. Senator Walsh will acknowledge that in 1975 the average net disposable income in real terms was of the order of $12,742. This includes government supplements and so on. This was the figure after net medical and insurance costs had been taken into account. Let us compare that with the situation as it applied in 1981-82. Using the appropriate deflators, that figure had grown to $13,633. In other words, there was an increase in net disposable income over that time of the order $900. That demonstrates a significant growth in real incomes over this period. It also demonstrates that there has not been the kind of gloom and doom in the wage earning section of the community, that Senator Button, in his speech, would have had us believe there has been. In fact, there was a general improvement in living standards over that period. Senator Elstob may scoff, but the facts are demonstrated clearly in the figures that I have given. There was an improvement of some $900 in real terms in net disposable income over that period.

I believe the 1982-83 Budget will make a very positive effort in encouraging wage restraint in the Australian community. I assure the Senate that this is vital if the slide in competitiveness in our import competing industries is to be halted. We now have conditions for moderation and, therefore, the potential to hold down inflation and to maintain and develop competitiveness. We must not forget the other measures that have been taken in the Budget to assist an encourage Australian businesses. This should be read in direct relationship to these questions. These Budget measures include the rebate that has been provided for the first $1,000 of dividends paid by resident companies to shareholders. Secondly, there has been an extension of the retention allowance of up to 80 per cent from the previous level of 70 per cent for the purposes of Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This will be of major benefit-to the extent of some $30m-for small businesses and private companies in particular. In order to encourage the worker ownership of smaller businesses-and larger ones for that matter-employer companies approved under the schemes will be able to issue shares to employees in such a way that when those shares are resold for any purpose the profit on them will not be taxable.

Probably one of the most significant things that has been done, particularly in my State of South Australia, is the changed method of treating companies within company groups by offsetting losses against profits. This will now be done under the changed law. I draw the attention of honourable senators to that, particularly in relation to South Australia. It is a matter of concern to people in Whyalla who are worried about the future of the steel industry run in that town by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. The benefits in this area are of particular significance to them in terms of being able to offset profits against steel making losses in that town. This is all happening against the background of other industry measures which have been announced in previous weeks and which , of course, touch upon the question of changed methods of calculation of depreciation and deducations which will provide significant encouragement to manufacturers for capital spending and also for those engaged in mining and rural activities. This of course is again part of the overall package of industry assistance measures announced recently, which included the changed levels of protection for industry generally.

In summary, the Government has brought down a Budget, the key objectives of which are to assist families to meet unforeseen burdens, to give special help to those most in need, to boost employment where possible, to assist industry and to encourage wage restraint. In contrast, last night the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and tonight the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate ( Senator Button) attacked our policy on wage restraint and trotted out yet another arrangement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I quote from that respected economic commentator Syntec, in this regard. This comment appeared in the July edition of the monthly newsletter:

Thus in the absence of an international recovery much stronger than any that seems in prospect, recovery here depends on the speed with which we can cut the rate of increase in our domestic cost structure, particularly wages.

There is a very clear argument for wage restraint and it is clearly acknowledged by the Opposition, although it is not prepared to say so as clearly as all that. Furthermore, the Opposition in this place and in the House of Representatives has denigrated the assistance given through the Budget to those in need. Honourable senators opposite in fact called it gimmickry and electioneering. They used words of that kind. They have addressed it as being cynical and ad hoc . Yet clearly, as I have demonstrated tonight, these are very significant benefits. As I have said, a person receiving an income of $180 per week will benefit to the extent of an extra $30 per week in his hands. That is a very significant help and is clearly being exploited by the Opposition without studying the facts.

The Opposition has continued to put forward a vague package which no doubt the Leader of the Opposition sees as electorally attractive. Anybody can offer jobs on the scale that he has without having to back up his claims in any way or show any calculations as to how he may do it. He can make if appear that it is somehow economically viable. Yet of course we all recognise that as another economic fairy tale which he trots out in this place from time to time. The benefits to individuals, families, companies, the economy and those in greatest need are considerable. That is the thrust of the Government's Budget. The alternative Budget strategy put forward by the Opposition boils down, in the main-I think these figures are conservative-to a doubling of the Government's deficit, fully financed by the printing of money. Mr Hayden announced last night , quite clearly, that he expected to be able to fund the deficit by virtue of selling bills to the Reserve Bank of Australia. That is precisely how the Labor Government achieved its objective in 1974 and 1975. It is called printing money. That is precisely what it is about-the making of inflation through increasing the money supply. The limited Budget figuring that it has provided suggests that the deficit will be of the order of at least $3,000m. If one takes into account other figures which relate to what the Opposition claims are deficiencies in our calculations, that might add at least another $1,000m. But I do not acknowledge that at all at this stage. This clearly is an objective which is inimical to the kinds of objectives which the Labor Party claims it has, that is, to achieve lower interest rates. Clearly, there is no way that that kind of deficit, financed in the way that it is suggested it might be, will lead to lower interest rates. Nor will it, as the Opposition well knows, create more jobs. What it will do is create more inflation and not lead to more wage restraints which is the essential feature of our Budget. It is aiming towards a situation where we can achieve a more competitive position on overseas markets. The ALP economic package is a prescription for more and more inflation, not less. It is not a prescription for more growth; it is a prescription for a higher deficit and for higher interest rates, not lower interest rates. That is the message which we have to leave with the Australian people tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In spite of the comments by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), this Budget does not represent a change of direction by the Government. It may well be a vote catching Budget but it is not a Budget designed to stimulate the economy. The mirage of goodies conjured up by carefully contrived Budget leaks is nothing but a confidence trick. They are boiled lollies for the purpose of hiding the real medicine. Last year, in a speech on the 1981 Budget, I said that it was time for the Herbert Hoovers in the Government to be thrown out and for men of vision like Franklyn D. Roosevelt to come to the fore. Little did I realise how urgent that call was. But, alas, the Hoovers in Australia and around the world are still presiding over the destruction not only of our economy but also that of the United State of America , the greatest power-house in the world. We are now on the brink. An article by Maxwell Newton in the Australian on Monday last stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the economic policies of the administration-both tax and monetary-are daily taking on more the aspects of the policies implemented by President Hoover in the early 1930s.
Under Mr Hoover, the money supply was drastically restricted at a time of economic recession.

At that time, the American federal reserve, fearing inflation, strongly restricted bank reserves and starved the economic system of money. In 1932, the Hoover Administration increased income tax by $900m, or nearly 30 per cent, and a severe recession turned onto the Great Depression. I need hardly remind honourable senators of the result. Extremism flourished, demagogues who promised easy solutions came to power and the world was plunged into catastrophe.

I said we were on the brink of an abyss. Until this year nobody thought that was possible. Had we not learned from the past? Did we not know how to stimulate the economy when times were tough and dampen it down when times were good? The counter-cyclical approach has virtually been abandoned in this Budget. Instead, the Government has brought down a Budget which has been described by some commentators as neutral in its impact on the economy.

At a time when the economy is desperately short of demand and cash, a neutral Budget is the best that the Government can do. The critical problem of this Budget is the domestic surplus of $230m. This means that the economic screws are being tightened at a time when the economy demands that they be loosened. I quote from page 317 of Budget Paper No. 1:

The domestic deficit measures the Budget's immediate contribution to liquidity in the economy . . . the domestic deficit or surplus is of key significance for monetary conditions and monetary conditions and monetary management in the short term.

I intend to focus my remarks on the Government's domestic surplus. In simple terms the domestic surplus means that the Government is taking $230m more out of the economy in the form of various sorts of taxation than it is giving back to the people in the form of social welfare and other payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should we have a domestic deficit?

—I am coming to that. I ask the honourable senator to be patient . The Government is taking money out of the economy and restricting liquidity at a time when the economy is balanced on the brink. We have heard forecasts of 8 per cent unemployment. In fact, Senator Button said 9 per cent. The Government has not revealed these sorts of forecasts; in fact, it has gone out of its way to tell us that we are in for a bad time. What possible justification could the Government have for coming up with a Budget with a strategy almost identical this year to the strategy we had last year? Last year the Government was talking of a resources boom. If a domestic surplus was justified last year, how can the Government possibly justify a domestic surplus of about the same magnitude this year when the economic conditions are so much worse and everybody realises that they are?

SPEECH.PARA: The answer to this strategy by the Government is simply this: It is justified on the basis that the only way to get rid of inflation is to tighten the monetary screws, irrespective of the hardship that this approach can cause to the community generally and irrespective of whether it creates massive unemployment. The tragedy is that the Government has had three unfettered years to solve inflation its way-through tight money-and it has failed. The problem of inflation has not been solved in Australia. Let us look at other countries. In recent years Germany has budgeted for very substantial deficits. It has been one of the most successful countries in the Western world in fighting inflation. The same situation applies to Japan and Austria. Those countries have budgeted for domestic deficits well in excess of 3 per cent of gross domestic product. So we have to ask the question: How long is the Government going to persist with policies that are just not working? There is another way. It is a way that many financial institutions do not particularly like but it is the alternative. That way is to loosen the money screws.

Let us look at the Government's Budget strategy over recent years. Between 1974 and 1975 not once did Budget deficits as a percentage of gross domestic product fall below 3 per cent. Over the last three years Budget deficits have been dramatically different, as the deficit is this year. In the past three years the deficit has been respectively 1.8 per cent, 0.9 per cent, and 0.4 per cent of the gross domestic product. This year it is one per cent of GDP. So we see that since 1979 there has been a dramatic change of policy by the Government in its handling of the economy. The Government's tight money supply started then, and it has persisted with that policy right through to this Budget, in spite of our rapidly deteriorating economy.

Some weeks ago I advocated that this year the Government should budget for an overall deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product. We have seen that this was modest even by the Government's own standards. In 1976 its deficit was 3.1 per cent of gross domestic product, in 1977 it was 3.7 per cent, and in 1978 it was 3.4 per cent. One media commentator pointed out that a deficit of 3 per cent of GDP would represent the highest in this country's history. In purely money terms that is certainly true. Today, three per cent of GDP would represent a deficit of $4.8 billion, whereas a deficit of 4.2 per cent of GDP in 1974 represented only $4.5 billion. However, a $4.8 billion deficit in 1974 values is equivalent to a deficit of only $1.9 billion today. So in constant money terms a deficit of 3 per cent today would be less than the deficits brought down by this Government in 1977 and 1978.

I want to refer now to cyclical adjustments, a term used in economic management circles around the world, but not in this country. Earlier I said that one commentator claimed that the Budget was neutral in its effect on the economy. But is it neutral? I put it to honourable senators that it is in effect far from neutral on jobs, inflation and interest rates. A small exercise with a pocket calculator will show that on a constant employment basis, which is the only reasonable way to look at a Budget, this Budget is grossly contractionary. On a constant employment basis revenue in this Budget would be about $48 billion and expenditure about $46 billion. In other words, on this basis the Government has budgeted for something like a $2 billion surplus overall or a nearly $4 billion surplus domestically. What do I mean by a constant employment Budget? I put it to honourable senators that the nominal figures given in the Budget are a mere bookkeeping exercise, almost totally unrelated to the Budget's impact on the economy. This impact can be measured only by a constant employment analysis, which shows how the Budget would be if it were adjusted for a constant level of activity and employment. This sort of analysis evens out the distortions caused by swings in the economic cycle. Obviously in a recession this cuts tax revenues and boosts social security payments. In a boom the reverse happens. Constant employment analysis evens out these fluctuations.

In case honourable senators think this is a novel idea, I point out that it is widely used around the world, and even, I understand, in Mrs Thatcher's Britain. The Australian Treasury has consistently opposed such an analysis on the grounds that any adjustments are somewhat arbitrary and that the figures can be fudged. This is true. It is also true that the Treasury is getting away with the ultimate fudge in the form of crude and meaningless figures. If we modify the Budget to take account of the situation that would apply under constant employment of, say, 2 per cent and 5 per cent greater economic activity-these aims surely are quite modest-we get the sorts of surpluses I mentioned.

I now turn briefly to government sector borrowing. I want to do this before I comment on one or two specific features of the Budget. We have heard on many occasions that we have to be concerned about Government sector borrowing to make way for private sector borrowing. There is one point that completely explodes this shibboleth. If we look at the national debt indexed for inflation, the facts of the matter are that Australia has been reducing its national debt since the conservative Government came to power and this is a feat that has not been achieved by any other member country of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that a good thing?

—Where has that got us? Australia has applied the monetarist policy more rigidly than any other OECD country and what do we have? Where has it got us? Where has the big deal got us? In November 1975 the level of inflation was 14.6 per cent. In 1982 inflation is rising dramatically. In November 1975, 232,400 people or 5 per cent of the work force were registered as unemployed. At the beginning of 1983 it is anticipated that at least 8 per cent will be unemployed. In November 1975 the overdraft rate charged by trading banks was 11.5 per cent and the interest rate on the average home loan was 8.5 per cent. Today the interest rate on overdrafts is 13.5 per cent and the interest rate on the average home loan is 14.5 per cent. All taxes and revenues collected by the Federal Government in 1975-76 were only 23 per cent of gross domestic product. Today they are 29 per cent of GDP. To rub salt into the wound we are getting less for it. We do not even have Medibank for a start.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a way that we can have a synthesis between Keynesian and supply-side economics. The argument generally applied against deficits is that they create excessive liquidity and therefore contribute to inflation. In a time of unused capacity such as we have at the moment I doubt that this argument is valid. But just assuming it is, I suggest that the Government could readily soak up any excess liquidity that a large deficit or even a modest deficit may provoke by the sale of bonds indexed for inflation. For instance, if we had a domestic deficit of, say, $3 billion this would, of course, increase liquidity in the economy by $3 billion. But this could be reduced if, for instance, the Government were prepared to offer, say, $2 billion worth of bonds indexed for inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But who would buy them?

—I am coming to that. One might ask whether this would put pressure on the loan market, whether it would increase interest rates and whether the economy is capable of taking up $2 billion worth of government bonds . The answer to that last question is, yes, the economy would be capable of taking up $2 billion worth of indexed bonds for the simple reason that we would have already put $3 billion into the economy via the deficit and we are taking out $2 billion via the sale of the bonds. One might ask: Why put money in and take it out? There is a very simple answer to that.
—But haven't you got a $5 billion deficit by this stage?

—The Government has budgeted for a domestic surplus. I can only go on the figures as they are set out in the Budget. I am not commenting on whether the figures are rubbery or not. I am saying that the Government's strategy is based on a domestic surplus, and that is what I am commenting on. What is achieved by putting money in and taking it out? It achieves this: If we put money into circulation via a deficit this money goes directly to where it is needed most. Say, for instance, $1 billion of a $3 billion deficit went to the social security area where it is urgently needed. This money would be spent there immediately and this would immediately stimulate demand and consumption. Further, $1 billion of a $3 billion deficit could be directed towards reducing payroll tax-an iniquitous tax on labour-which would immediately stimulate production and have an immediate effect on unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Would such a deficit increase interest rates? First, the major factor affecting interest rates in this country is the level of interest rates overseas, particularly those interest rates in the United States of America. So selling bonds will not affect interest rates one way or the other. The other major factor causing high interest rates is undoubtedly inflation. The level of inflation will not go down until unemployment is reduced and unemployment, of course, represents an enormous unproductive cost to the community. If bonds were indexed for inflation they would be a very attractive investment to the public even at very low rates of interest-say, 2 per cent. The report of the Commitee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System-the Campbell Committee- recommended the sale of indexed bonds. This leads us to the question: Why has the Government been so quiet on this aspect of the Campbell report? I suggest there can be only one answer to this: The Government itself does not believe it can get inflation down quickly. The Government's financial advisers cannot have it both ways. If they are confident that a tight money strategy is the way to reduce inflation they should be delighted at the chance to sell inflation indexed bonds at low rates of interest. I challenge the Government to explain why else it has refused to index the sale of its bonds. I conclude with these comments: The price of economic bigotry is high. Does this country, does the Western world, have to plunge into the abyss before this Government sees the light?
