DEFENCE FORCE DISCIPLINE BILL
Since World War II repeated efforts have been made to consolidate and modernise the disciplinary law of this country which applies to the Services.
This Bill provides new disciplinary legislation for the Defence Force and contains, for the first time in one Act, the disciplinary law applicable to the 3 arms of the Defence Force.

The Bill replaces the existing legislation which has come in for well-merited criticism over many years on various grounds. I will deal with the existing legislation briefly before describing the contents of the Bill.
The existing legislation is contained in the following:
3 United Kingdom acts, 2 of which have ceased to operate in the United Kingdom.
4 sets of United Kingdom rules or regulations, all of which have ceased to operate in the United Kingdom.
3 Australian Acts.
9 sets of regulations under the Australian Acts.

The United Kingdom acts, rules and regulations do not apply in their original form but are subject to extensive modifications, adaptations, exceptions and additions prescribed in the Australian regulations.
Oddities and inconsistencies abound. I will give some examples:

In the case of the Navy and the Air Force, some provisions of the United Kingdom legislation apply in parallel with corresponding but not identical provisions of the Australian legislation, with conflicting directions in the latter as to which is to prevail.

The basic law for the Navy is contained in a modern United Kingdom statute (the naval Discipline Act 1957) whereas Army and Air Force law has its basis in, or is modelled on, the superseded United Kingdom Army Act of 1881, with all its archaisms, such as offences of ''duelling'': ''Behaving in a scandalous manner unbecoming the character of an officer and a gentleman''; ''by beating drums negligently occasioning false alarms on the march''; and ''conniving at the exaction of any exorbitant price for a house or stall let to a sutler''. I would have thought that one who follows an army and sells provisions to soldiers-an activity which held some prominence in the 16th century-commands little relevance today. Sutlery may have brought its own unique perils. Contemporary Australia gives me the impression it is not greatly troubled by them.

The Army is provided with 2 sets of disciplinary laws, one of which applies when members are serving in Australia in peace time; the other when members are serving outside Australia or on war service.
Civil offences may be tried by Service tribunals, but not by Army tribunals in Australia in peace time.
The civil offences that may be tried are offences against the laws of England, but Navy tribunals may also try offences against the laws of the Commonwealth.
Army and Air Force tribunals apply the English rules of evidence but Navy tribunals apply the rules of evidence applicable in the Australian Capital Territory.

Offences involving stealing are dealt with according to the concepts of theft in the United Kingdom Theft Act 1968, except in the case of trials by Army tribunals in Australia in peace time when the common law concepts of larceny are applied.
The maximum punishments that Navy commanding officers may impose greatly exceed the powers of Army and Air Force commanding officers.
The maximum punishment imposable by an Army court martial in Australia in peace time is imprisonment for 3 months regardless of the nature of gravity of the offence.

It is fair to say that any person who is not familiar, through practice, with the operation of these laws, who tries to find a way through the labyrinth of statutes, regulations and extensively modified United Kingdom legislation, faces a daunting task indeed.

The existing law requires Service lawyers to maintain a continuing and full awareness not only of Australian law and its developments, but also of English criminal law and its developments, a task more difficult and demanding than may be generally recognised.

A change to a United Kingdom criminal statute or to the English law of evidence may take place, temporarily passing unnoticed in Australia. Such a change may cause an offence to be tried quite wrongly and thereby rendered nugatory.

The admixture of United Kingdom and Australian law provides ample scope for errors to occur. This is no fantasy. There has, in fact, been one naval conviction quashed because the judge advocate advised the court martial on the basis of an English decision which had not been followed in Australia by the High Court.

Returning now to the Bill, this is based on the report of the 1973 working party on the Defence Force Disciplinary Code which was tabled in Parliament on 2 April 1974. The Bill takes account of subsequent work done by the working party as a result of comments by members of parliament, the public and members of the Defence Force.

It also has regard to guidelines determined at a conference chaired by the then Minister for Defence in November 1978 and attended by three Judge Advocates General of the Services, Senior Service Officers of the Attorney-General's Department.

The working party attempted to produce a Bill that would be Australian, modern and uniform. The Bill that I am now introducing is Australian and modern but it is not quite uniform. I will have more to say on that point later.
The Bill deals with 3 principal matters and a number of ancillary matters. These may be briefly described as follows:
It prescribes offences that apply to members of the Defence Force and certain civilians who accompany the Defence Force.
It creates tribunals for the trial, conviction and punishment of such offences.
It provides machinery for appeals against, and reviews of, convictions and punishments.
It deals with ancillary matters such as investigation of offences, trial procedures, and serving of sentences.
Against that background I will now discuss the Bill in more detail.

The offences have been completely revised and several new offences have been included, for example, offences involving the use of vehicles or the possession and use of narcotic drugs. Obsolete offences have been eliminated and all offences have been restated in modern language.

The maximum punishments have been reduced to modern levels and serious offences have been distinguished from mere breaches of discipline by the provision of much lighter maximum punishments for the latter.
The scale of punishments has been revised and several kinds of punishments have been abolished, such as cashiering and dismissal from ship.

The law of the Australian Capital Territory has been substituted for the law of England as the appropriate law for the purposes of civil offences triable by Service tribunals and for the law of evidence and the principles of criminal responsibility that are to apply.

With regard to the investigation of offences, the Bill applies, with some exceptions, the Criminal Investigation Bill. The Bill also reduces the present powers to arrest alleged offenders and retain them in custody.

All the differences between the Service with regard to the kinds of court martial and their procedures, including review procedures, have been abolished. Two levels of court martial are provided. A new form of tribunal is that of the Defence Force magistrate who is to have jurisdication equivalent to that of the lower level of court martial.

Provision is made for a Service lawyer to be appointed as judge advocate at every court martial and to make rulings on questions of law or mixed law and fact. Such rulings will be binding on the court martial.

Three levels of summary authorities are provided. The extensive summary powers conferred on Navy commanding officers have been substantially reduced and there has been some increase in the powers of Army and Air Force summary authorities. Greater supervision has been provided over the imposition of the more severe summary punishments.

Several new procedures and requirements in relation to trials and reviews have been provided. A judge advocate may conduct a preliminary hearing to dispose of certain legal issues. Service tribunals are to be required to observe sentencing criteria. Provision is made for recording a conviction but no punishment, for suspending the punishment of a fine and for setting non-parole periods. Provision is also made for automatic reviews of convictions and punishments and for ordering a retrial.

As a safeguard on the restriction of the right to elect trial by court martial or Defence Force Magistrate where the exigencies of service dictate, a reviewing authority is required to quash a summary punishment where, in his opinion, trial by court martial or Defence Force Magistrate should have been arranged.

Certain requirements or rules under existing Army and Air Force law are abolished. These are the requirement for the proceedings of a court martial to be confirmed before coming into force; the rule that conviction by an Army or Air Force court martial is not a bar to subsequent trial by civil court for the same offence; and the rule that the condoning of an offence by competent Service authority is a bar to subsequent trial for the offence.

Provision is made for one Judge Advocate General for the Defence Force and for the appointment of Deputy Judge Advocates General. It is the function of the Judge Advocate General, when disciplinary proceedings are reviewed by reviewing authorities, to be the final arbiter on questions of law, or mixed law and fact, that may have arisen at a trial by a Service tribunal.

A Bill such as this necessarily has regard to the organisation, administraton and operation of the Defence Force. When there are substantial differences in this regard between the three arms of the Defence Force on a matter to which a provision of the Bill relates, the difference is liable to be reflected in the Bill.

For example, because Naval Police do not serve at sea, it is necessary for the Bill to retain the special powers of arrest conferred on members of the regulations staff or the staff of the officer of the watch of a ship.

Again, because promotion from the rank of captain to the rank of major in the Army takes into account service in rank instead of seniority, it is necessary to provide a special punishment called 'forfeiture of service for the purposes of promotion' because the punishment of forfeiture of seniority cannot apply.

The only important area in which the Bill fails to achieve uniformity is in the powers of summary punishment conferred on commanding officers and subordinate summary authorities in relation to sailors, soldiers and airmen. The powers conferred on these authorities in relation to sailors exceed those conferred in relation to soldiers and airmen.
Closely related to this is the right to elect trial by court martial or by Defence Force Magistrate. The right provided in the Bill is more restricted for sailors than it is for soldiers and airmen.

The reason for conferring more extensive powers on commanding officers in relation to sailors and restricting the right of sailors to elect trial by court martial or Defence Force Magistrate is the difficulty that would be encountered in conducting numerous such trials without adversely affecting navy operations or, alternatively, causing lengthy delays in bringing offenders to trial.

In the case of subordinate summary authorities, the relevant factors are the organisation of the Navy; the command structure in Navy ships and establishments ; and the nature of the duties of and responsibilities of commanding officers of ships.

A matter in the 1973 report that engendered particular comment was the treatment of the question of obedience to superior orders as a defence to a charge of committing an offence. The report restated the traditional position under British Service law that a member of the armed forces can be convicted of disobeying a superior order only if it is lawful and cannot be convicted for the consequences of obeying a superior order unless the order was clearly unlawful.
Consideration was given to whether there should be a provision imposing an obligation on a serviceman to refuse to obey an order which is unlawful.

However, such a provision would impose on every serviceman the impossible burden of knowing whether obedience to a particular order would contravene some obscure customary law of war. Not all customary laws have been codified nor, on some questions, is the law settled.
The Bill gives effect to the traditional position, except that it excludes the traditional defence where the accused knew or ought to have known in the circumstances that the order was unlawful.

Finally, I mention the Courts-Martial Appeals Act 1955, which provides a convicted person with a right to appeal against his conviction to the Courts Martial Appeal Tribunal. This Act is being retained with necessary consequential amendments and certain improvements that will be made by the Defence Force ( Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill that I will introduce next.

The Defence Force Discipline Bill is the result of a prolonged and thorough review of the existing law involving officers of the Defence Force, the Department of Defence and the Attorney-General's Department.

The Bill will, when it comes into force, provide a much needed modernisation and simplification of the law in this area. It moderates the severity of the existing law yet should be more effective for the reasons I have given and because it has been designed for present day circumstances of service in the Defence Force.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
DEFENCE FORCE (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL

This Bill is complementary to the Defence Force Discipline Bill 1982. It deals with three matters. In the first place, it repeals existing Defence Force disciplinary legislation and makes other amendments to various Acts consequent on the enactment of the Defence Force Discipline Bill.

Secondly, it makes amendments of a policy nature to the Courts-Martial Appeals Act 1955 designed to widen the right of access to the Courts-Martial Appeals Tribunal, to expand the range of powers available to the Tribunal, to improve certain procedures relating to the Tribunal and to provide a right of appeal to the Federal Court of Australia.
Finally, it provides transitional provisions for the disposal of offences committed under existing Defence Force disciplinary legislation.
Apart from amendments designed to achieve consistency between the Defence Force Discipline Bill and the Courts-Martial Appeals Act, significant changes to the Courts-Martial Appeals Act include:
A person convicted by a Defence Force Magistrate will be entitled to appeal to the Courts-Martial Appeal Tribunal.

A person acquitted on the ground of unsoundness of mind at the time of the offence will be entitled to appeal against the acquittal, provided that the defence of unsoundness of mind was not raised by him.

A convicted person will not be required to petition a Service reviewing authority before becoming entitled to appeal to the tribunal; instead his right to appeal will arise when the automatic review by the Service reviewing authority is completed or the period allowed for automatic review expires.
An appellant or a Chief of Staff may appeal to the Federal Court of Australia on a question of law from a decision of the appeal tribunal.
The appeal tribunal will be empowered to substitute a conviction of an alternative offence of which the appellant might have been convicted on the evidence.
The appeal tribunal will be empowered to quash a conviction and order a new trial in appropriate cases.
A reserved decision of the appeal tribunal may be delivered by one member of the tribunal sitting alone.
The membership of the appeal tribunal will be restricted to the holders of judicial office.

The amendments proposed to the Courts-Martial Appeals Act 1955 include a retitling of the Act as the Defence Force Discipline Appeals Act 1955 and a renaming of the appeal tribunal as the Defence Force Discipline Appeal Tribunal.
This is a consequence of the provision of a right to appeal to the tribunal against convictions by Defence Force Magistrate.
The other amendments and transitional provisions made by the Bill do not warrant detailed mention in a second reading speech.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Honourable senators will recall that on 21 April 1982 I announced that, following a study of the approach adopted by United States of America authorities, I had concluded there was scope for helping Vietnam veterans who feel alienated from the 'system' by setting up facilities separated from departmental premises and staffed by personnel who know well the Vietnam experience. I now wish to inform the Senate of the present situation with the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service.

SPEECH.PARA: A centre has now been established in each State capital city and Darwin. The first was opened in Adelaide on 29 January this year and the last to open was in Brisbane on 21 July. Except in Hobart the service operates from premises which are physically separate from normal departmental premises and contact with counsellors is provided in an informal atmosphere at locations as accessible as possible to veterans and their families.

The establishment of the centres is clear evidence of the Government's genuine concern to establish communication with Vietnam veterans and their families who have difficulties. The Government's approach has been to concern itself not necessarily with the cause of whatever problems exist but rather to acknowledge that there are problems, to seek out those with difficulties and to assist them.

Consideration is being given to the need to provide the service in areas away from the capital cities. Initially these areas will be catered for by visits to from the capitals and by establishing service contacts in them and I have sought advice as to whether facilities of some more discreet kind should be available in areas such as Townsville and Canberra.

Each centre can provide or is developing the following activities: Firstly, counselling services in matters such as marital relations, genetics, vocations, education, finance and careers, and parental skills. Other activities include self-help programs, pensions and legal help, community relations and crisis help . Each centre has developed extensive contacts with community and departmental facilities so that specialised professional assistance may be sought where necessary. Through the service wives and children of Vietnam veterans have access to repatriation general hospitals at no cost for emergency treatment. Vietnam veterans themselves can obtain emergency treatment at no cost at these hospitals and also at country hospitals.

From the latest figures available to me, 448 individual clients have contacted the service, involving 3,321 client contacts. These may vary from lengthy face- to-face interviews or form part of a series of counselling sessions with a veteran over a period which may involve not only the veteran but also his dependants. The centres have proven valuable and are busy and I have therefore approved the extension of the employment contracts for the 22 staff to be extended to the end of 1983.

I want to give the Senate some indication of the nature of the problems which are presenting at the counselling centres. Broadly speaking the most common problem, occurring in 26 per cent of cases, is family matters embracing both marital and parent/child relationships. Next, at 25 per cent are what might be termed behavioural problems, covering such things as violent behaviour, withdrawal, irritability or moodiness, insomnia, bad dreams and flashbacks and depression. Finally, 22 per cent of cases have reported problems of a social nature such as housing and accommodation, employment and finance.

The experience to date enables my advisers to draw tentative conclusions about the causes of the problems which many Vietnam veterans are experiencing and I want to outline briefly the nature of those conclusions. Many veterans have suffered psychological torment over their involvement. That torment seems to stem from anger at the fact that they did not receive proper community recognition or support for their efforts. In many cases, the veteran was translated from the service environment in which he was trained to be aggressive , violent and single-minded back into a normal civilian situation without the benefit of any deprogramming. In the civilian situation many people either wanted to ignore the fact of the war altogether or did not support the veteran who took part in it and so the veteran had little choice other than to suppress the fact of it and his feelings. It is that suppression which seems to be at the base of many present difficulties.

Another suggested cause is called post traumatic stress disorder. This is a label used by professionals to describe the symptoms which flow from being involved in an event outside the range of usual human experience. Its symptoms may include problems such as as anxiety, rage, isolation, depression, sleep disturbance and recurrent nightmares or flashbacks which, as I have mentioned earlier, the statistics indicate as being major problems in the Service's clientele. This disorder can occur at any stage after the trauma. Many of the veterans attending the centres seem to be suffering from it and, as a consequence, are experiencing marital or family problems and relationship difficulties.

Now they feel that there is an agency to help them and that they are not alone in their problems. They feel too that they are owed this service and they welcome the easy access and the centres' non-bureaucratic style. Some have never talked of their experiences to anybody but they see this service as their own. There is an air of confidence in the counsellors. Many veterans have been assisted through this service and every effort is being made to ensure that its existence is known to all Vietnam veterans. It has been a most worthwhile exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I wish to make a few brief remarks about the statement. The Opposition welcomes the extension of the contracts of those involved in the Counselling Service and accepts the remarks of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) that the Counselling Service has been successful in dealing with the problems of some Vietnam veterans. I have, therefore, no objection to the first part of the statement. I wish to comment briefly, however, on the second part of the statement. It seems to be so typical of statements that the Minister has made in recent times. What the Minister says is that as a result of four months experience of these counselling services, he can quite confidently, apparently, state that most of the problems of Vietnam veterans are, firstly, psychological, and secondly, are due to what he calls the post traumatic stress disorder-which I believe is also partly a psychological condition.

In the language of the statement and in the rather glib way in which the Minister refers to the problems which he lists in these two generic groups, I suggest that he is trying, as he has done so often in the past, in letters recently to members of this Parliament and in addresses to various organisations , particularly the Vietnam veterans organisations, to gloss over the very real problems which face the Vietnam veterans. First, he glosses over the problems which are not explicable in terms of these two groups of syndromes which the Minister describes tonight. Secondly, he glosses over the problem which faces many Vietnam veterans as to what happened to them as a result of their exposure to herbicides and the contaminants of those herbicides, particularly dioxin.

I cannot let this statement go without pointing out that there is no reference to that potential problem in it. First, there is no reference to the very real concern of Vietnam veterans in this country that they may have been affected by their exposure to herbicides, their exposure to it in concentrations far higher than were ever used in commercial use in this country, and their exposure without proper protection. Secondly, there is no reference to the very real anxiety in the minds of these people as to what has happened to them and what may happen to their children as a result of that exposure.

I do not believe that four months' experience of the Counselling Service and the records of the people who have been in that Service allow the Minister to imply, as he certainly implies in this statement, that all of the veterans' problems are due to psychological torment and to the posttraumatic stress disorder. There is a grave disquiet among Vietnam veterans in Australia that they have been affected by their exposure to herbicides and maybe to pesticides in Vietnam, and that anxiety can be relieved only by a proper inquiry into, first, their exposure and, secondly, the possible results of that exposure, an inquiry that can look at the vast amount of information available about the effects of these substances since they were first produced in the late 1940s-and they were first produced as a weapon of war.

Although I welcome the extension of the contracts of the people involved in the Counselling Service and although I believe that with some modifications the Counselling Service will continue to provide a very useful service to Vietnam veterans, I would not like anyone in this place to believe that my welcoming of that detracts from the call that I have made on behalf of the Labor Party for a proper independent judicial inquiry into just what happened in Vietnam and what may happen to these veterans in the future. That is the only reason I rose to speak to the motion tonight.

As Senator Messner knows, there are problems with the Counselling Service. I accept that in consultation with the Vietnam veterans' organisations, those problems will be alleviated. But in no way does the establishment of this Counselling Service detract from the very real desires of the Vietnam veterans to sort out just what happened to them and what may happen to them and their successors in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to comment on the statement of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and to express some support for the view that the work that the centres have done to date has been as beneficial as the Minister has suggested. It seems to me, as it must seem to all who have been concerned about this matter, a matter of relief that indeed we may have hit on a reasonable approach to what has been in Australia a problem of great concern to a very large number of people. My concern is somewhat similar to that of Senator Grimes, but also I wish to comment on the last part of the Minister's statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that we in this country have at least, and very begrudgingly, turned our attention back to the Vietnam veterans. When one speaks to them, one still finds them extremely angry at the way in which they have been treated. Having become increasingly vocal and increasingly visible, refusing just to fade away with the war, those veterans themselves are in large measure responsible for the types of government attention that is now being paid to them. There is no doubt that with the paucity of support that has been given in the past, the very weakness of any coherent approach to the problem and the continuing unwillingness on the part of the Government to accept its responsibilities for many of the veterans' problems, particularly those which flow from agent orange, it is incumbent on those people to continue prodding the conscience of Australia so that it will respond to the types of problems that those veterans are suffering. I supose that in many ways veterans of all wars have felt that they have not been accepted for what they have done, but in what probably must be the most morally suspect war that we have ever encountered, I think the Vietnam Veterans feel this acutely within our society.

The Minister's statement refers to post traumatic stress syndrome-or, in the American terminology, delayed stress syndrome-about which an enormous amount has been written. I do not wish to enter into a discussion on that except to raise one point: It does seem to me that in many cases we put psychological labels on to something which we do not wish to face ourselves. When one contemplates that many of these veterans saw their comrades killed in a brutal war and then could not settle back into an even society and accept the glossy television commericials, one should not necessarily believe that such a person is psychologically unbalanced or is difficult to comprehend. It seems to me to be a rather natural approach of trying to find an even keel after what must have been a most traumatic type of experience. If we believe we are superior we could, in the long run, defeat the purpose for which these centres are being set up.

I wish to raise one image that probably all of us have tucked away. It is raised constantly in my mind when I think about it in a very strong way. I refer to the image of men, women and children trying to clamber on to those last helicopters which flew out of Saigon and seeing women and children falling off to their death as the helicopters rose into the air. That type of image, if its horror affects us, at least assists us in some way to capture what those veterans have been through. I believe that society in general must be very careful not to take an approach of looking down, an approach of kindly assistance to a group of people who have faced and have seen so much. As far as we can, we should go with them; where we cannot, possibly we should follow. It may be that they have a wisdom to offer that we find it very difficult to grasp. In response to the last part of the Minister's statement, as these counselling services go on, I hope that we do not use them as an excuse to talk down the experiences that those veterans have had but rather we should accept that they have had access to a wisdom that we do not have and that it might be something from which we can all learn rather than something we should treat as an illness.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the 1982-83 Budget. This is the seventh Budget which has been brought down while I have been a member of parliament. It is easily the best accepted Budget yet. I wish to cover a few matters relative to it. Before I do I draw the attention of the Senate to the news reports. Generally they have treated the Budget very well. I only compare that with the rather pathetic coverage in today's Press of the non-response that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) made last night.

SPEECH.PARA: I was somewhat surprised tonight when I heard Senator Button make comments to the effect that it was a Budget designed to transfer money from the poor to the better-off. Had he had time to read the Budget he may well have found that that was an unwise thing to say. Many aspects of the Budget show the complete reverse to be the case. We have only to look at the way in which the Government dealt with matters such as housing, pensions, education and tax rates to see what an unfortunate comment that was. I entered the chamber when he was talking about deep seated divisions of views within the party. I think we could all be excused for believing that he was talking about the Australian Labor Party. From the news reports that are available at the moment one can see that in my State of Tasmania-as Senator Grimes would certainly attest-and in Victoria there are deep seated divisions within the Labor Party on a variety of issues such as a capital gains tax and uranium. I venture to suggest that if Senator Button really tried to find the sorts of matters on which he claimed there are vast and deep divisions he would stretch to find them.

The first point I wish to raise in the Budget context concerns housing. In the seven years that I have been a member of parliament many changes have been made to housing policy. Every one of those changes has been required to meet the changing sociological and economic conditions of the country. As the conditions have varied so has the need to change the housing policy. In that time there have been many changes in the costs of housing, housing sizes and facilities, land prices, mobility of the family unit, the size of the family unit and so on. Anybody who has followed the housing market will know that the demand for various types of accommodation has changed very consistently. In these few years it became obvious that we needed to change the policies from time to time to match up with these changes. As far as I am concerned, the changes that have been made in 1982 have been in keeping with the needs of 1982.

In the housing package that started two or three months ago and included the Budget an amount of $571m was allocated for housing, which is an increase of almost 25 per cent on last year. The increase of 25 per cent in funding represents the second highest rate in any division of the Budget. This increase includes interest rate subsidies, first home deposit assistance grants and higher direct housing assistance for those who are in need. I do not think Senator Button could say that that represents a means of transferring money from the poor to the better-off. The same situation applies with respect to the housing interest relief. The interest rebates will represent a saving to the average mortgagor of between $5 and $8 a week. That is very good. A 30 per cent rebate will be payable on all housing loan interest above 10 per cent on loans up to $60,000.

Expenditure on welfare housing will be $333m, which is an increase of 27 per cent. Of course, $147m will go to first home buyers. The package which was anounced on 18 March provided first home buyers with a rebate of $700 for the first year and with a reduction of $100 a year thereafter. Statutory reserve deposits in the banks have been reduced by one per cent so that there will be money in addition to the $400m announced on 18 March. There will be an increased supply of money for housing whether it be in the welfare area or in the ordinary home ownership area. For those at the lower end of the scale, contrary to what Senator Button would have us believe, the rental subsidy increase has been increased from $112m a year to $150m a year, a rise of 34 per cent.

Basically, business generally will benefit from this Budget. In this country we depend very heavily on small business and for small business there is a considerable amount of good news. Not all of it is good news but a considerable amount of it is. Business in Australia depends very heavily on equity involvement and private investment is necessary. We need to encourage private investment so that we can accommodate the risk that is needed. Business has not been easy for many years, and it became necessary that we should do something to improve opportunities and to encourage people to intensify their investment in this area. Accordingly, there has now been a move to remove the double taxation of dividends, and a 30 per cent rebate on the first $1,000 invested will make a great deal of difference to many small businesses.

I do not know how many representations I have made to the Government in the last few years about the depreciation allowance which allows the claiming of depreciation on non-residential income producing buildings. I am very pleased to see that such an allowance has now been introduced. It will make a lot of difference to many people and encourage them to develop or expand their business , as will the improvement under Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which deals with retention of profits earned. The retention allowance is now to be increased to 80 per cent. This will allow more money to be retained in the businesses, as will the groupings of profits and losses in the 100 per cent common ownership of companies. Then there is the general reduction in the basic tax rates in the area where small business is usually associated. That will help small businesses even further. That is a pretty good bundle for business generally. I hope that the people concerned will seize the opportunity, make the most of it and plan now for the time ahead.

I was recently travelling outside Australia. In one country I visited I found that considerable work was being done to encourage people by way of advertising along the lines 'while we are down is the time to develop. Be ready for when we are on top and you will be there first'. I would encourage many people here who are in the position to be able to, to be ready for when the world economic situation makes it possible for them to get back into business in a big, profitable and better way.

I would like to make one or two comments on the benefits in the Budget relating to Tasmania. Tasmania has four major airports Hobart, Launceston, Devonport and Wynyard, all of which have received assistance in the Budget. Air services are absolutely vital to Tasmania for the Tasmanian who moves about only occasionally , for the businessman who moves regularly, the tourist who comes into Tasmania for special occasions and, of course, for the freight business. It is necessary that Tasmania should have an airport capable of dealing with aircraft from overseas, particularly to cater for the freight aspects. It is possible for Tasmania to participate in various world markets provided it does not have to trans-ship and suffer the extra costs involved. Provided we have one airport in Tasmania that is capable of catering for aircraft from overseas of sufficent size to be used in this trade, the other three airports need be of a standard that they can adequately cope with suitable jetliners to look after the passenger trade. I think all Tasmanians should remember this and be quite thankful that their needs in this regard have been so adequately recognised in this Budget.

This year there is also a special allocation for tourist roads. The $10m which has been allocated especially for Tasmania will allow the beauty and individuality of Tasmania to be opened up further. This will allow more and more lucky people to be able to share with Tasmanians the beauty of their State. We hope that it enables many people from interstate and overseas to have a better look around Tasmania. Again, every Tasmanian will benefit from this expenditure. The greatest single benefit that has ever been provided to Tasmania from the Federal Government, of course, is the freight equalisation scheme. The freight equalisation scheme is the means by which the extra disadvantages Tasmania suffers by virtue of its dependence on expensive sea transport are reduced to some extent. A renewal of this scheme for another year will have tremendous benefit and, again, I think every Tasmanian will thank the Liberal Government for the implementation and continuation of this scheme.

There are a couple of other groups I would like to mention which have improved their situation as a result of good representation. The beef producers of Australia have had the $23m debit for their brucellosis and tuberculosis account written off. This will certainly remove quite a burden which has been behind them for some time now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it affect all breeders?

—Yes, it will affect all breeders in every State. The other group I mention is fishermen. In this Budget fishermen receive $6.1m, an increase of 56 per cent on the $3.9m they received last year. In my opinion they received that money as a result of good representation and unity of approach. I congratulate them on being able to get together sufficiently to be able to carry their case and to get greater recognition. The industry is expanding and developing. It has a mass of problems. I believe that the recognition the fishermen have had of the methods to be adopted and the recognition the Government has given the industry should now be able to make the operation work in partnership very well.

SPEECH.PARA: In the trade area export expansion grants and the export market development grants have been allocated $255m. This will provide for improvements in many areas. Trade is absolutely vital to Australia. We must compete and we must have access to the markets of the world. We must be able to do this as expeditiously as possible. We have a lot of water to cover. Access is very expensive and it is necessary for the exporters from Australia to be able to visit countries to do their promotions. This is expensive, and the extra money allocated in this Budget will allow them to spend more time establishing these markets. I deal with many exporters; they are a rather diverse group. It can be a very expensive operation for people to go overseas to try to merchandise one product. Amongst the people with whom I associate are clothing manufacturers, who may be exporting only a very limited line of two or three items; specialty cheese manufacturers; a gentleman who makes rock breakers; and people who export cut flowers and things like that. As well, there is a person who exports fruit cake.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish we could export you.

—We will see about that. There may be an opportunity somewhere. All these types of industries can really expand only with a little encouragement and assistance. The encouragement and assistance the Government is giving them will certainly improve their chances.

SPEECH.PARA: In the industrial research and development area $50m has been allocated this year. I will certainly do all I can to see that it is not only fully spent but also, in fact, overspent if possible. We have a rather poor performance record by world standards in research and development. So many magnificent projects are possible in Australia that we need to look at them more carefully and treat them in a much broader way. I am always looking for more and more projects where people are trying to get industry and export going. They need assistance to obtain the sort of information they require. Most of them are first-up operators and we cannot possibly run the risk in an economy such as ours of allowing them to get into economic difficulties before they have even got off the ground. Our whole approach to industrial research and development needs to be revitalised. We need to be able to deal with prospects quickly and effectively. I believe that we need to do a lot more in this area.

I should like to say a little about employment, education and training. The economic and social implications of Australia in a global situation are, I think , clear to all. It pays us to look back a little and realise that anybody who is younger than I am really does not have any idea of even the tail end of the Depression, and anybody who is less than 40 years old does not even really remember what the war was all about. Since then there has been a remarkable downhill run, almost all the way. Not many young people have had an opportunity to face such difficult times and to learn the strengths that come from adversity of that sort.

The education system and social perceptions have accepted the situation. While the educators of the country have gone a long way towards trying to give the rising generation a new range of concepts and subjects, I believe that they may have taken things a little far in some directions. Educators and schools generally need help from outside. I believe that people whose lives have been spent in the field of education are inclined to the theory that education may best be for education's sake. There is a lot of difference between that and the perception the community has about the purpose of education. I am impressed far more by the range of studies at the higher school certificate level than I am by the application of those subjects at a practical level. I have seen teaching computer studies to students who probably have no idea of ordinary arithmetical tables or who in some cases may not even be able to count the change in their pockets. It is a bit like building a spire on a building that does not have a foundation.

With the dramatic numbers of unfortunate people looking for work, it surprises me every day to find that vacancies exist that apparently we cannot fill. We need to take account of the fact that education should fit people for the world and that, whether we like it or not, the world includes work. More concentration on this aspect is certainly desirable. I am just as appalled in 1982 as I was in 1979 when in answer to a question during the Estimates committee hearings I was told by a representative of the National Capital Development Commission that the Commission was buying word processors because it was unable to get typists. I am equally appalled in one respect and gratified in another that I now have a secretary to one of my Senate committees who, having been in Australia from England for two weeks, was engaged as a typist because no other typists in Canberra were capable of doing the work. I find that absolutely extraordinary.

I have a regular routine that on Wednesdays, as a rule, I read the job vacancies in the Age. Today was no different from usual. There are five pages of job vacancies in today's Age. Not all of these are jobs that require enormous qualifications. Most of them are very ordinary jobs. I took out a few figures. There are 15 typists' jobs, 53 secretaries' jobs, 25 cooks' jobs, 29 advertisements for clothing operatives which, on previous investigations, would indicate vacancies for possibly 200 people, 16 drivers' jobs and a great collection of jobs for waiters, watchmen, painters, bricklayers, butchers, cleaners, nightwatchmen and virtually the whole gamut. It surprises me that there can be five pages of vacancies listed of which, say, three pages would be available to people of moderate skills if they wished to do the work. I believe that we need to make much more of this, not only at the political level of consideration for retraining and so on but also at the fundamental education level. In the employment scene, more and more employers seem to be turning to older people. In the case of females, married women are employed instead of junior girls because their basic credentials are so much better. I think this is most unfortunate. Some of the time that is spent on broadening people's education would be better spent on providing a better basis for their education. In later years it becomes important that the marketable skills and the realisable goals be brought together.

I cut an advertisement out of the newspaper a couple of years ago. It says a great deal. It states: 'Mature 16-year-old girl, higher school certificate with passes in ancient history, social psychology, English literature, credit art, wants work. Will do anything.' Frankly, I ask honourable senators: What can she do? It is very difficult for a girl like that to place herself on the market with absolutely no marketable skills and a very narrow range of talents. Higher education in particular needs to give some consideration to work skills. Lower education has to be regenerated into providing the fundamental basic necessities . If a person is no good with figures and letters, the opportunities are limited . Unless we are able to match up the desires of the educators with the necessities of the world at large and the market in general, the gap will only increase. There has to be some talking between the two groups to provide the best that is possible.

Anybody who looks at the Budget can see that quite deliberately it helps people at the lower end of the scale. It helps the people who need the help most. It has been well received. It is appropriate for 1982 and I certainly support it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill to amend the income tax law covers a range of subjects.
It contains amendments to effect income tax exemptions for certain foreign pensions payable in consequence of persecution during the Second World War.
The proposal announced on 23 July 1982 to exempt profits from the sale or redemption of discounted securities acquired on or before 30 June 1982 is also being given statutory expression.
Exemption is being provided for income derived by the phosphate mining company of Christmas Island Limited.
Some extensions of the gift provisions, foreshadowed in recent announcements, are being made.
Amendments foreshadowed on 9 February 1982 to deal with further tax avoidance arrangements of the 'expenditure recoupment' type are included.

Other provisions of the Bill will clarify the operation of anti-avoidance provisions enacted in 1978 to deal with schemes which circumvent the sufficient distribution requirements for private companies
Finally, a minor amendment to the secrecy provisions of the income tax law concerning the supply of information to the Australian Statistician is also being made.
I turn now to the details of these measures.
Foreign Pensions Related to War-time Persecution

On 3 March 1982, the Treasurer announced the Government's intention to extend an existing exemption of pensions paid from the Federal Republic of Germany to Australian residents in compensation for Nazi persecution.

The Bill will extend the exemption so that it applies to payments of pensions from the Federal Republic where the entitlement arises wholly or partly because periods of Nazi persecution, or flight from such persecution, have been treated as periods during which the recipient contributed to the Republic's pension scheme.
Had such contributions actually been made there would have been relief from Australian tax under other provisions of our law.

As also announced on 3 March, the extended exemption will also specifically cover pensions from the Netherlands paid as compensation in respect of Second World War persecution by, or disablement from resistance to, enemy forces occupying the Netherlands or the former Dutch East Indies.
There is, however, a need to give the concepts underlying the extended exemption a general application.

For this reason, the Bill provides that the exemption will apply to other foreign pensions received by residents of Australia, which are found to relate to, or take into account, Second World War persecution or disability arising from participation in a resistance movement.
The exemption will apply to payments made to the person who suffered or to his or her dependants.
The Bill provides that payments derived on or after the date of the foreshadowing announcement-3 March 1982-will be within the scope of the extended exemption.
Sale or Redemption of Discounted Securities

Earlier this year, the Commissioner of Taxation publicly affirmed the view that profits arising from the sale or redemption at par of securities issued or acquired at a discount are assessable income.

It is accepted by the Government, however, that a significant number of small investors had purchased discounted securities in the bona fide belief that the profit on sale or redemption would not be assessable.

Indeed, the tap stock prospectus of May this year, which contains no indication that the discount component of the amount receivable on redemption of the stock is assessable income, may have contributed to this belief.

Accordingly, it is proposed by this Bill to amend the income tax law to exempt from tax profits made on redemption or sale of any securities acquired at a discount on or before 30 June 1982, other than profits made by traders or dealers and profits to which section 26AAA, section 26C or paragraph 26 (a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act applies.
The exemption will not affect the tax treatment of profits on the sale or redemption of securities purchased after 30 June 1982.
Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Limited

As part of new arrangements for the mining of Christmas Island phosphate, the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Limited-an Australian Government owned and controlled company-was incorporated on 25 June 1981 to replace the British phosphate commissioners as managing agents for the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission.
Honourable senators will recall that amendments incorporated in the Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Act 1981 made this replacement possible.
The new company has been acting as managing agents since July 1981.
That was an initial step pending the winding-up of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission.

The next step under the proposed arrangements is to obtain the Parliament's approval of a new Christmas Island Agreement between Australia and New Zealand which, together with an exchange of notes between the two governments, will enable the Phosphate Commission to be wound-up and the company to assume resonsibility for the mining operation.
Introduction of the necessary Christmas Island Agreement Amendment Bill is proposed for the current sittings of the Parliament.
Income of the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission is exempt from income tax under the Christmas Island Agreement Act 1958.
The amendment proposed in the present Bill will provide a corresponding exemption from income tax for the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Limited.
The exemption will apply to income derived by the company on or after a date to be notified in the Gazette.
The date intended to be notified is that on which the company replaces the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission as the Island's mining operator.
Until then, of course, the income from the operations will remain that of the Commission and will continue to be exempt under existing provisions.
Gifts
The gift provisions of the income tax law allow deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more to specified funds, authorities or institutions.
Details of each of the proposed extensions of this concession have been the subject of previous statements and I need mention them only briefly now.
One extension will authorise deductions for gifts made after 31 May 1982 to the Connellan Airways Trust.
Another will authorise deductions for gifts made after 30 June 1982 to the Queensland Cultural Centre Trust.
Further changes will authorise deductions for gifts made in the 1981-82 financial year to Polish relief appeals and to relief appeals established in response to the cyclone disaster in Tonga.

Finally, there are provisions which will authorise deductions for gifts made during the 1981-82 and 1982-83 financial years to appeals established for the provision of relief to Falkland Islanders, British servicemen or the families of islanders or servicemen affected by the Falkland Islands dispute.
Expenditure Recoupment Schemes
Anti-avoidance provisions of the income tax law apply to a wide range of losses and outgoings with effect from 24 September 1978.

Put broadly, the legislation denies a deduction for a designated loss or outgoing that is incurred under an arrangement whereby the taxpayer or an associate obtains a benefit the value of which, taken with the sought-for tax savings, effectively recoups the claimed loss or outgoing.

Variants of recoupment schemes with which this Bill deals are ones that attempted to exploit the income tax rebates and deductions for calls paid on shares in afforestation companies and the rebate for moneys paid on shares in petroleum exploration companies.
The amendments proposed by the Bill will extend the expenditure recoupment provisions so that no rebate or deduction will be allowed in these further categories of schemes.
The amendments are to apply with respect to expenditure incurred after 24 September 1978 under tax avoidance schemes entered into after that date.
The decision to do this follows the clear warning given on that day and repeated on several subsequent occasions.

Although I think it is now generally recognised that the Government's unrelenting campaign against blatant forms of tax avoidance, culminating in the enactment of the general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVA, has put paid to such activities, the obligation to the general body of taxpayers to prevent the success of any expenditure recoupment type of tax avoidance scheme entered into after 24 September 1978 must, however, be recognized and assumed.

Mr President, I point out that any schemes which seek deductions for calls paid on shares in an afforestation company and which are entered into after 27 May 1981 will not be subject to the proposed amendments.
Such schemes would be struck down by the general anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVA which took effect on 28 May 1981.
The provisions I now introduce will also ensure that there can be no remaining incentive for proliferation of rebate schemes that are outside the scope of Part IVA.

As foreshadowed in the Treasurer's statement of 9 February 1982, any rebate scheme entered into after that date that comes to be covered by the expenditure recoupment provisions of the law will attract 200 per cent additional tax on the same basis as do schemes covered by Part IVA.
Dividends Satisfied by Share or Debenture Issue
A private company is liable to pay additional tax on its undistributed profits if it does not, by way of dividends, make a sufficient distribution of profits to its shareholders.

Anti-avoidance measures were introduced in 1978 to counter arrangements under which a dividend, which was not capable of being taxed in the shareholders' hands, was formally paid and that ensured that a substantial benefit flowed back to the company.
In these circumstances there was no real distribution of profits.
The 1978 measures may, however, operate too widely where dividends are satisfied by an issue of shares or debentures that legitimately have a market value appreciably less than their face value.
If such dividends are effectively taxed in the hands of the shareholders, there is no tax avoidance.

A reduced market value may legitimately exist, for example, because of factors such as lack of security, lack of ready marketability or uncertainty as to the date of redemption of the debentures or redeemable shares.
The Government is concerned that the law should clearly not compel private companies to pay cash dividends in such cases.

Appropriate relief will be provided by the Bill so that, where the Commissioner of Taxation considers it unreasonable for the anti-avoidance provisions to apply to a dividend paid after 20 January 1982 and satisfied by an issue of shares or debentures, the dividend will be taken into account in determining whether or not a sufficient distribution has been made.
Disclosure of Additional Taxation Information to the Australian Statistician

Under the secrecy provisions of the income tax law, information available to the Commissioner of Taxation about the name, address and industry classification of an employer can be provided to the Australian Statistician, but only for purposes related to employment statistics.

Consistently with its policy of seeking to reduce, wherever practicable, the burden on businesses of responding to statistical requirements, the Government has decided to amend these provisions in two respects.
Firstly, the limitation to use in employment statistics will be removed in order to enable the information supplied to be used for a number of related statistical purposes.

Secondly, the Bill will authorise the provision of additional employment information to the Statistician, namely the numbers of male and female employees of persons who are employers for PAYE purposes.
An explanatory memorandum providing fuller details of the various measures contained in the Bill has been made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2375) Senator Siddons asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to the concern expressed by senior members of the Australian computer industry about the possible retrospective application of a sales tax to packaged computer software? Can the Minister explain why the computer software industry has been told repeatedly over the past 14 years that its products were service and not goods and were therefore not eligible for research and development grants, grants in aid or tax incentives? Can the Minister further explain why in the last 12 months several- but only a tiny minority-of the firms have been told the opposite? Why has computer software suddenly become a good and thus liable for sales tax? Will the Treasurer examine the possibility of exempting computer software from sales tax as an incentive to a rapidly developing industry which uses Australian technological skills, which is labour intensive and for which Australia is rapidly acquiring a high international reputation?
The Treasurer has supplied the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that certain types of packaged computer software are goods in their own right and have always been subject to sales tax. There is no retrospectivity involved. Other types of software are not goods and are not, therefore, subject to sales tax. In the absence of details the Commissioner is unable to offer any comment on the cases to which the honourable senator has referred and which are said to be ones where, in the last 12 months, firms have been advised that sales tax is payable on computer packaged software.

The honourable senator's request for all computer software to be made exempt from sales tax has been noted but I cannot give any assurance that the Government would find it appropriate to meet the request.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1576) Senator Siddons asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is Australia's sovereignty over Christmas Island and the Cocos ( Keeling) Islands contested respectively by Indonesia and Singapore? Does the Australian Government regard these islands as an integral part of Australia? Would Australian forces be asked to defend this country's sovereignty over these islands if sovereignty were contested by force?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Australia's sovereignty over Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands is not contested by Indonesia and Singapore.

The Government has obligations and responsibilities to protect Australia's territory which includes Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. there is no current threat of attack on any Australian territory. In the event that there were, the Government of the day would carefully consider what action would be appropriate to defend Australia's interests.
